"[267-cantapresto] [He]267-cantapresto had vanished before [Odo]234-odo could look round . [The latter]870-the latter still wavered ; but as [he]234-odo did so [he]234-odo caught [Trescorre]254-trescorre 's face through [the crowd]1568-the crowd . [The minister]4767-the minister 's eye was fixed on [him]234-odo ; and the discovery was enough to make [him]234-odo plunge through the narrow wake left by [[Cantapresto]267-cantapresto 's retreat]4768-cantapresto 's retreat . [Odo]234-odo made [his]234-odo way unhindered to [the ante - room]4769-the ante - room , which was also thronged , [ecclesiastics]4770-ecclesiastics , [servants]748-servants and [even beggars from [the courtyard]1745-the courtyard]4772-even beggars from the courtyard jostling [each other]3086-each other in [their]3086-each other struggle to see what was going forward . The confusion favoured [his]234-odo escape , and a moment later [he]234-odo was hastening down [the tapestry gallery]4775-the tapestry gallery and through [the vacant corridors of [the palace]768-the palace]4776-the vacant corridors of the palace . [He]234-odo was familiar with half - a - dozen short - cuts across [this network of passages]4778-this network of passages ; but in [his]234-odo bewilderment [he]234-odo pressed on down the great stairs and across [the echoing guard - room]4779-the echoing guard - room that opened on [the terrace]4571-the terrace . [A drowsy sentinel]4781-a drowsy sentinel challenged [him]234-odo ; and on [Odo]234-odo 's explaining that [he]234-odo sought to leave , and not to enter , [the palace]768-the palace , replied that [he]234-odo had [[his]234-odo Highness]941-his highness 's orders to let [no one]725-no one out that night . For a moment [Odo]234-odo was at a loss ; then [he]234-odo remembered [his]234-odo passport . It seemed to [him]234-odo an interminable time before [the sentinel had scrutinised it by the light of a guttering candle]4785-the sentinel had scrutinised it by the light of a guttering candle , and to [his]234-odo surprise [he]234-odo found [himself]234-odo in a cold sweat of fear . The rattle of the storm simulated footsteps at [his]234-odo heels and [he]234-odo felt the blind rage of [a man within shot of invisible foes]4786-a man within shot of invisible foes . The passport restored , [he]234-odo plunged out into the night . It was pitch - black in [the gardens]8159-the gardens and the rain drove down with the guttural rush of a midsummer storm . So fierce was its fall that it seemed to suck up the earth in its black eddies , and [he]234-odo felt [himself]234-odo swept along over a heaving hissing surface , with wet boughs lashing out at [him]234-odo as [he]234-odo fled . From [one terrace]4788-one terrace to another [he]234-odo dropped to lower depths of buffeting dripping darkness , till [he]234-odo found [his]234-odo hand on the gate - latch and swung to [the black lane below the wall]4789-the black lane below the wall . Thence on a run [he]234-odo wound to [the tanners ' quarter by [the river]2315-the river]4790-the tanners ' quarter by the river : [a district commonly as foul - tongued as it was ill - favoured , but tonight clean - purged of both evils by the vehement sweep of the storm]4792-a district commonly as foul - tongued as it was ill - favoured , but tonight clean - purged of both evils by the vehement sweep of the storm . Here [he]234-odo groped [his]234-odo way among slippery places and past [huddled out - buildings]4793-huddled out - buildings to the piles of [the wharf]4794-the wharf . The rain was now subdued to a noiseless vertical descent , through which [he]234-odo could hear the tap of [the river]2315-the river against the piles . [Scarce]453-scarce knowing what [he]234-odo fled or whither [he]234-odo was flying , [he]234-odo let [himself]234-odo down the steps and found the flat of [a boat]9515-a boat 's bottom underfoot . [A boatman]4797-a boatman , distinguishable only as [a black bulk in the stern]4798-a black bulk in the stern , steadied [his]4797-a boatman descent with outstretched hand ; then the bow swung round , and after a labouring stroke or two [they]4799-they caught the current and were swept down through the rushing darkness . BOOK III . THE CHOICE . The Vision touched [him]234-odo on the lips and said : Hereafter [thou]4800-thy shalt eat [me]0-i in [thy]4800-thy bread , Drink [me]0-i in all [thy]4800-thy kisses , feel [my]0-i hand Steal ' twixt [thy]4800-thy palm and Joy 's , and see [me]0-i stand Watchful at every crossing of the ways , [The insatiate lover of [thy]4800-thy nights and days]4801-the insatiate lover of thy nights and days . 3.1 . It was at [Naples]59-naples , some two years later , that the circumstances of [his]234-odo flight were recalled to [Odo Valsecca]234-odo by the sound of a voice which at once mysteriously connected itself with the incidents of that wild night . [He]234-odo was seated with [a party of gentlemen in [the saloon of [Sir William Hamilton]454-sir william hamilton 's famous villa of [Posilipo]120-posilipo]4803-the saloon of sir william hamilton 's famous villa of posilipo , where [they]4799-they were sipping [the ambassador]4804-the ambassador 's iced sherbet and examining certain engraved gems and burial - urns recently taken from the excavations]4802-a party of gentlemen in the saloon of sir william hamilton 's famous villa of posilipo , where they were sipping the ambassador 's iced sherbet and examining certain engraved gems and burial - urns recently taken from the excavations . The scene was such as always appealed to [Odo]234-odo 's fancy : [the spacious room]4805-the spacious room , luxuriously fitted with carpets and curtains in the English style , and opening on a prospect of classical beauty and antique renown ; in [his]234-odo hands the rarest specimens of that buried art which , like some belated golden harvest , was now everywhere thrusting itself through [the Neapolitan soil]4806-the neapolitan soil ; and about [him]234-odo [men of taste and understanding]4807-men of taste and understanding , discussing the historic or mythological meaning of the objects before [them]4799-they , and quoting [Homer]455-homer or [Horace]456-horace in corroboration of [their]4799-they guesses . [Several visitors]4808-several visitors had joined the party since [Odo]234-odo 's entrance ; and it was from [a group of these later arrivals]4809-a group of these later arrivals that the voice had reached [him]234-odo . [He]234-odo looked round and saw [a man of refined and scholarly appearance , dressed en abbe]4810-a man of refined and scholarly appearance , dressed en abbe , as was the general habit in [Rome]11-rome and [Naples]59-naples , and holding in one hand the celebrated blue vase cut in cameo which [Sir William]454-sir william hamilton had recently purchased from [the Barberini family]4811-the barberini family . " These reliefs , "[4812-the stranger] [the stranger]4812-the stranger was saying , " whether cut in the substance itself , or afterward affixed to the glass , certainly belong to the Grecian period of cameo - work , and recall by the purity of their design the finest carvings of [Dioskorides]457-dioskorides . "[4812-the stranger] [His]234-odo beautifully - modulated Italian was tinged by a slight foreign accent , which seemed to connect [him]234-odo still more definitely with the episode [his]234-odo voice recalled . [Odo]234-odo turned to [a gentleman at [his]234-odo side]4813-a gentleman at his side and asked [the speaker]2090-the speaker 's name . " That , "[234-odo] was the reply , " is the abate de Crucis , [a scholar]1352-a scholar and cognoscente , as [you]234-odo perceive , and at present attached to [the household of [the Papal Nuncio]9523-the papal nuncio]9522-the household of the papal nuncio . "[234-odo] Instantly [Odo]234-odo beheld the tumultuous scene in [[the Duke]682-the duke 's apartments]3612-the duke 's apartments , and heard the indictment of [Heiligenstern]397-heiligenstern falling in tranquil accents from the very lips which were now , in the same tone , discussing the date of a Greek cameo vase . Even in that moment of disorder [he]234-odo had been struck by the voice and aspect of [the agent of the Holy Office]4817-the agent of the holy office , and by a singular distinction that seemed to set [the man]1626-the man [himself]1626-the man above the coil of passions in which [his]1626-the man action was involved . To [Odo]234-odo 's spontaneous yet reflective temper there was something peculiarly impressive in the kind of detachment which implies , not obtuseness or indifference , but a higher sensitiveness disciplined by choice . Now [he]234-odo felt a renewed pang of regret that such qualities should be found in the service of [the opposition]4285-the opposition ; but the feeling was not incompatible with a wish to be more nearly acquainted with [[their]4285-the opposition possessor]4820-their possessor . The two years elapsing since [Odo]234-odo 's departure from [Pianura]4-pianura had widened if [they]4285-the opposition had not lifted [his]234-odo outlook . If [he]234-odo had lost something of [his]234-odo early enthusiasm [he]234-odo had exchanged it for a larger experience of [cities]4821-cities and [men]8356-men , and for the self - command born of varied intercourse . [He]234-odo had reached a point where [he]234-odo was able to survey [his]234-odo past dispassionately and to disentangle the threads of the intrigue in which [he]234-odo had so nearly lost [his]234-odo footing . The actual circumstances of [his]234-odo escape were still wrapped in mystery : [he]234-odo could only conjecture that [the Duchess]899-the duchess , foreseeing the course events would take , had planned with Cantapresto to save [him]234-odo in spite of [himself]234-odo . [His]234-odo nocturnal flight down [the river]2315-the river had carried [him]234-odo to [Ponte di Po]121-ponte di po , [the point where [the Piana]94-the piana flows into [the Po]45-the po]4825-the point where the piana flows into the po , the latter river forming for a few miles [the southern frontier of [the duchy]1310-the duchy]4826-the southern frontier of the duchy . Here [his]234-odo passport had taken [him]234-odo safely past [the customs - officer]4828-the customs - officer , and following the indications of [the boatman]4829-the boatman , [he]234-odo had found , outside [the miserable village]4830-the miserable village clustered about the customs , a travelling - chaise which brought [him]234-odo before the next night - fall to [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro . Of the real danger from which this timely retreat had removed [him]234-odo , [Gamba]282-gamba 's subsequent letters had brought ample proof . It was indeed mainly against [himself]234-odo that [both parties]9306-both parties , perhaps jointly , had directed [their]9306-both parties attack ; designing to take [him]234-odo in the toils ostensibly prepared for the Illuminati . [His]234-odo evasion known , [the Holy Office]458-the holy office had contented itself with imprisoning [Heiligenstern]397-heiligenstern in [one of [the Papal fortresses near [the Adriatic]122-the adriatic]4833-the papal fortresses near the adriatic]4832-one of the papal fortresses near the adriatic , while [[his]234-odo mistress]8825-his mistress , though bred in the Greek confession , was confined in [a convent of [the Sepolte Vive]459-the sepolte vive]4835-a convent of the sepolte vive and [[his]234-odo Oriental servant]4836-his oriental servant sent to [[the Duke]682-the duke 's galleys]4838-the duke 's galleys . As to [those suspected of affiliations with the forbidden sect]4839-those suspected of affiliations with the forbidden sect , fines and penances were imposed on [a few of the least conspicuous]4840-a few of the least conspicuous , while [the chief offenders , either from motives of policy]4841-the chief offenders , either from motives of policy or thanks to [their]4841-the chief offenders , either from motives of policy superior adroitness , were suffered to escape without a reprimand . After this , [Gamba]282-gamba 's letters reported , [the duchy]1310-the duchy had lapsed into [its]1310-the duchy former state of quiescence . [Prince Ferrante]414-prince ferrante had been seriously ailing since the night of the electrical treatment , but [the Pope]1248-the pope having sent [[his]1248-the pope private physician]4844-his private physician to [Pianura]4-pianura , [the boy]839-the boy had rallied under [the latter]870-the latter 's care . [The Duke]682-the duke , as was natural , had suffered an acute relapse of piety , spending [his]682-the duke time in expiatory pilgrimages to [the various votive churches of [the duchy]1310-the duchy]4848-the various votive churches of the duchy , and declining to transact any public business till [he]682-the duke should have compiled with [his]682-the duke own hand a calendar of the lives of [the saints]1218-the saints , with the initial letters painted in miniature , which [he]682-the duke designed to present to [[his]682-the duke Holiness]4851-his holiness at Easter . Meanwhile [Odo]234-odo , at [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro , found [himself]234-odo in surroundings so different from those [he]234-odo had left that it seemed incredible [they]4852-they should exist in [the same world]4853-the same world . [The Duke of [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro]9388-the duke of monte alloro was that rare survival of a stronger age , [a cynic]4855-a cynic . In a period of sentimental optimism , of fervid enthusiasms and tearful philanthropy , [he]9388-the duke of monte alloro represented [the pleasure - loving prince of the Renaissance]4856-the pleasure - loving prince of the renaissance , crushing [[his]9388-the duke of monte alloro people]1264-his people with taxes but dazzling [them]1264-his people with festivities ; infuriating [them]1264-his people by [his]9388-the duke of monte alloro disregard of the public welfare , but fascinating [them]1264-his people by [his]9388-the duke of monte alloro good looks , [his]9388-the duke of monte alloro tolerance of old abuses , [his]9388-the duke of monte alloro ridicule of [the monks]1356-the monks , and by [the careless libertinage which had founded the fortunes of [more than one middle - class husband]4860-more than one middle - class husband and [father]1441-father]4859-the careless libertinage which had founded the fortunes of more than one middle - class husband and father -- for [the Duke]682-the duke always paid well for what [he]682-the duke appropriated . [He]682-the duke had grown old in [his]682-the duke pleasant sins , and these , as such raiment will , had grown old and dingy with [him]682-the duke ; but if no longer splendid [he]682-the duke was still splendour - loving , and drew to [his]682-the duke court [the most brilliant adventurers of [Italy]5-italy]4863-the most brilliant adventurers of italy . Spite of [his]682-the duke preference for such company , [he]682-the duke had a nobler side , the ruins of a fine but uncultivated intelligence , and a taste for all that was young , generous and high in looks and courage . [He]682-the duke was at once drawn to [Odo]234-odo , who instinctively addressed [himself]234-odo to these qualities , and whose conversation and manners threw into relief the vulgarity of [[the old Duke]4864-the old duke 's cronies]4865-the old duke 's cronies . [The latter]870-the latter was the shrewd enough to enjoy the contrast at the expense of [his]682-the duke sycophants ' vanity ; and [the cavaliere Valsecca]8650-the cavaliere valsecca was for a while [the reigning favourite]4868-the reigning favourite . It would have been hard to say whether [[his]682-the duke patron]4869-his patron was most tickled by [his]682-the duke zeal for economic reforms , or by [his]682-the duke faith in the perfectibility of [man]2185-man . Both these articles of [Odo]234-odo 's creed drew tears of enjoyment from [the old Duke]4864-the old duke 's puffy eyes ; and [he]682-the duke was never tired of declaring that only [his]682-the duke hatred for [[his]682-the duke nephew of [Pianura]290-pianura]4872-his nephew of pianura induced [him]682-the duke to accord [his]682-the duke protection to so dangerous [an enemy of society]4873-an enemy of society . [Odo]234-odo at first fancied that it was in response to a mere whim of [the Duke]682-the duke 's that [he]234-odo had been despatched to [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro ; but [he]234-odo soon perceived that the invitation had been inspired by [Maria Clementina]413-maria clementina 's wish . Some three months after [Odo]234-odo 's arrival , [Cantapresto]267-cantapresto suddenly appeared with a packet of letters from [the Duchess]899-the duchess . Among them [[her]899-the duchess Highness]8209-her highness had included a few lines to [Odo]234-odo , whom [she]899-the duchess briefly adjured not to return to [Pianura]4-pianura , but to comply in all things with [[her]899-the duchess uncle]9184-her uncle 's desires . Soon after this [the old Duke]4864-the old duke sent for [Odo]234-odo , and asked [him]234-odo how [his]234-odo present mode of life agreed with [his]234-odo tastes . [Odo]234-odo , who had learned that frankness was the surest way to [the Duke]682-the duke 's favour , replied that , while nothing could be more agreeable than the circumstances of [his]234-odo sojourn at [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro , [he]234-odo must own to a wish to travel when the occasion offered . " Why , this is as [I]682-the duke fancied , "[682-the duke] replied [the Duke]682-the duke , who held in [his]682-the duke hand an open letter on which [Odo]234-odo recognised [Maria Clementina]413-maria clementina 's seal . " [We]9524-we have always , "[682-the duke] [he]682-the duke continued , " spoken plainly with [each other]3086-each other , and [I]4881-i will not conceal from [you]234-odo that it is for [your]234-odo best interests that [you]234-odo should remain away from [Pianura]290-pianura for the present . [The Duke]682-the duke , as [you]234-odo doubtless divine , is anxious for [your]234-odo return , and [[her]682-the duke Highness]8209-her highness , for that very reason , is urgent that [you]234-odo should prolong [your]234-odo absence . It is notorious that [the Duke]682-the duke soon wearies of those about [him]682-the duke , and that [your]234-odo best chance of regaining [his]682-the duke favour is to keep out of [his]682-the duke reach and let [[your]234-odo enemies]9352-your enemies hang [themselves]9352-your enemies in the noose [they]9352-your enemies have prepared for [you]234-odo . For [my]4881-i part , [I]4881-i am always glad to do an ill - turn to [that snivelling friar]9530-that snivelling friar , [[my]4881-i nephew]9531-my nephew , and the more so when [I]4881-i can seriously oblige [a friend]8895-a friend ; and , as [you]234-odo have perhaps guessed , [the Duke]682-the duke dares not ask for [your]234-odo return while [I]4881-i show a fancy for [your]234-odo company . But this , "[4881-i] added [he]4881-i with an ironical twinkle , " is a tame place for [a young man of [your]234-odo missionary temper]9534-a young man of your missionary temper , and [I]4881-i have a mind to send [you]234-odo on a visit to [that arch - tyrant Ferdinand of [Naples]59-naples]9535-that arch - tyrant ferdinand of naples , in whose dominions [a man]8112-a man may yet burn for heresy or be drawn and quartered for poaching on [[a nobleman]1351-a nobleman 's preserves]9538-a nobleman 's preserves . [I]4881-i am advised that some rare treasures have lately been taken from the excavations there and [I]4881-i should be glad if [you]234-odo would oblige [me]4881-i by acquiring a few for [[my]4881-i gallery]9539-my gallery . [I]4881-i will give [you]234-odo letters to [a cognoscente of [my]4881-i acquaintance , who will put [his]9540-a cognoscente of my acquaintance , who will put his experience at the disposal of your excellent taste experience at the disposal of [your]234-odo excellent taste]9540-a cognoscente of my acquaintance , who will put his experience at the disposal of your excellent taste , and the funds at [your]234-odo service will , [I]4881-i hope , enable [you]234-odo to outbid [the English brigands who , as [the Romans]9542-the romans say , would carry off the Colosseum if it were portable]9541-the english brigands who , as the romans say , would carry off the colosseum if it were portable . "[4881-i] In all this [Odo]234-odo discerned [Maria Clementina]413-maria clementina 's hand , and an instinctive resistance made [him]234-odo hang back upon [[his]234-odo patron]4869-his patron 's proposal . But the only alternative was to return to [Pianura]4-pianura ; and every letter from [Gamba]282-gamba urged on [him]234-odo ( for the very reasons [the Duke]682-the duke had given ) the duty of keeping out of reach as the surest means of saving [himself]234-odo and the cause to which [he]234-odo was pledged . Nothing remained but a graceful acquiescence ; and early the next spring [he]234-odo started for [Naples]59-naples . [His]234-odo first impulse had been to send [Cantapresto]267-cantapresto back to [the Duchess]899-the duchess . [He]234-odo knew that [he]234-odo owed [his]234-odo escape [me]0-i grave difficulties to [the soprano]1599-the soprano 's prompt action on the night of [Heiligenstern]397-heiligenstern 's arrest ; but [he]234-odo was equally sure that such action might not always be as favourable to [his]234-odo plans . It was plain that [Cantapresto]267-cantapresto was paid to spy on [him]234-odo , and that whenever [Odo]234-odo 's intentions clashed with those of [[his]234-odo would - be protectors]4886-his would - be protectors [the soprano]1599-the soprano would side with [the latter]870-the latter . But there was something in the air of [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro which dispelled such considerations , or at least weakened the impulse to act on them . [Cantapresto]267-cantapresto as usual had attracted notice at [court]8243-court . [His]267-cantapresto glibness and versatility amused [the Duke]682-the duke , and to [Odo]234-odo [he]267-cantapresto was as difficult to put off as a bad habit . [He]267-cantapresto had become so accomplished [a servant]4735-a servant that [he]267-cantapresto seemed a sixth sense of [[his]267-cantapresto master]2377-his master 's ; and when [the latter]870-the latter prepared to start on [his]267-cantapresto travels [Cantapresto]267-cantapresto took [his]267-cantapresto usual seat in the chaise . To [a traveller of [Odo]234-odo]4894-a traveller of odo 's temper there could be few more agreeable journeys than the one on which [he]234-odo was setting out , and [the Duke]682-the duke being in no haste to have [his]682-the duke commission executed , [[his]682-the duke messenger]4896-his messenger had full leisure to enjoy every stage of the way . [He]234-odo profited by this to visit [several of [the small principalities north of [the Apennines]124-the apennines]4898-the small principalities north of the apennines]4897-several of the small principalities north of the apennines before turning toward [Genoa]23-genoa , whence [he]234-odo was to take [ship]4899-ship for [the South]4900-the south . When [he]234-odo left [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro [the land]8269-the land had worn the bleached face of [February]460-february , and it was amazing to [his]234-odo northern - bred eyes to find [himself]234-odo , on [the sea - coast]4902-the sea - coast , in the full exuberance of summer . Seated by [this halcyon shore]4903-this halcyon shore , [Genoa]23-genoa , in [its]23-genoa carved and frescoed splendour , just then celebrating with the customary gorgeous ritual the accession of [a new Doge]4904-a new doge , seemed to [Odo]234-odo like the richly - inlaid frame of some Renaissance " triumph . "[234-odo] But [the splendid houses with [their]4905-the splendid houses with their marble peristyles , and the painted villas in their orange - groves along the shore marble peristyles , and the painted villas in [their]4905-the splendid houses with their marble peristyles , and the painted villas in their orange - groves along the shore orange - groves along [the shore]4906-the shore]4905-the splendid houses with their marble peristyles , and the painted villas in their orange - groves along the shore , housed [a dull and narrow - minded society , content to amass wealth and play biribi under the eyes of [[their]4905-the splendid houses with their marble peristyles , and the painted villas in their orange - groves along the shore ancestral Vandykes]4908-their ancestral vandykes , without any concern as to the questions agitating [the world]844-the world]4907-a dull and narrow - minded society , content to amass wealth and play biribi under the eyes of their ancestral vandykes , without any concern as to the questions agitating the world . A kind of fat commercial dulness , a lack of that personal distinction which justifies magnificence , seemed to [Odo]234-odo the prevailing note of [the place]1030-the place ; nor was [he]234-odo sorry when [[his]234-odo packet]4911-his packet set sail for [Naples]59-naples . Here indeed [he]234-odo found all the vivacity that [Genoa]23-genoa lacked . [Few cities]4912-few cities could at first acquaintance be more engaging to [the stranger]4812-the stranger . Dull and brown as it appeared after the rich tints of [Genoa]23-genoa , yet so gloriously did [sea and land]4914-sea and land embrace [it]4915-it , so lavishly the sun gild and the moon silver it , that it seemed steeped in the surrounding hues of nature . And what a nature to eyes subdued to the sober tints of [the north]4916-the north ! Its spectacular quality -- that studied sequence of effects ranging from the translucent outline of [Capri]125-capri and [the fantastically blue mountains of [the coast]4918-the coast]4917-the fantastically blue mountains of the coast , to [Vesuvius]126-vesuvius lifting its torch above [the plain]1139-the plain -- this prodigal response to fancy 's claims suggested the boundless invention of [some great scenic artist]4920-some great scenic artist , some Olympian Veronese with [sea]4921-sea and sky for a palette . And then [the city]2261-the city itself , huddled between [bay and mountains]4923-bay and mountains , and seething and bubbling like [a Titan 's cauldron]4924-a titan 's cauldron ! Here was life at [its]2261-the city source , not checked , directed , utilised , but gushing forth uncontrollably through every fissure of the brown walls and reeking [streets]4925-streets -- love and hatred , mirth and folly , impudence and greed , going naked and unashamed as the lazzaroni on [the quays]4926-the quays . The variegated surface of it all was fascinating to [Odo]234-odo . It set free [his]234-odo powers of purely physical enjoyment , keeping all deeper sensations in abeyance . These , however , presently found satisfaction in that other hidden beauty of which [city]2282-city and plain were but the sumptuous drapery . It is hardly too much to say that to the trained eyes of the day the visible [Naples]59-naples hardly existed , so absorbed were [they]4928-they in the perusal of [her]59-naples buried past . The fever of excavation was on every one . No social or political problem could find a hearing while the subject of the last coin or bas - relief from [Pompeii]127-pompeii or Herculanaeum remained undecided . [Odo]234-odo , at first [an amused spectator]4929-an amused spectator , gradually found [himself]234-odo engrossed in the fierce quarrels raging over the date of an intaglio or the myth represented on an amphora . The intrinsic beauty of the objects , and the light they shed on one of the most brilliant phases of human history , were in fact sufficient to justify the prevailing ardour ; and the reconstructive habit [he]234-odo had acquired from [Crescenti]234-odo lent a living interest to the driest discussion between [rival collectors]4930-rival collectors . Gradually other influences reasserted [themselves]4931-themselves . At [the house of [Sir William Hamilton]454-sir william hamilton]4932-the house of sir william hamilton , then [the centre of [the most polished society in [Naples]59-naples]4934-the most polished society in naples]4933-the centre of the most polished society in naples , [he]234-odo met not only [artists]4163-artists and [archeologists]4936-archeologists , but [men of letters and of affairs]4937-men of letters and of affairs . Among these , [he]234-odo was peculiarly drawn to [the two distinguished economists]4938-the two distinguished economists , [the abate [Galiani]323-galiani and [the cavaliere Filangieri]4940-the cavaliere filangieri , in whose company [he]234-odo enjoyed for the first time sound learning unhampered by pedantry]4939-the abate galiani and the cavaliere filangieri , in whose company he enjoyed for the first time sound learning unhampered by pedantry . [The lively Galiani]323-galiani proved that social tastes and a broad wit are not incompatible with more serious interests ; and [Filangieri]325-filangieri threw the charm of a graceful personality over any topic [he]234-odo discussed . In the latter , indeed , courtly , young and romantic , [a thinker whose intellectual acuteness was steeped in moral emotion]4941-a thinker whose intellectual acuteness was steeped in moral emotion , [Odo]234-odo beheld the type of the new chivalry , [an ideal leader of the campaign against social injustice]4942-an ideal leader of the campaign against social injustice . [Filangieri]325-filangieri represented the extremest optimism of the day . [His]325-filangieri sense of existing abuses was only equalled by [his]325-filangieri faith in [their]4943-their speedy amendment . Love was to cure all evils : the love of [man]2185-man for [man]2185-man , the effusive all - embracing sympathy of [the school of [the Vicaire Savoyard]461-the vicaire savoyard]4946-the school of the vicaire savoyard , was to purge the emotions by tenderness and pity . In [Gamba]282-gamba , the victim of the conditions [he]234-odo denounced , the sense of present hardship prevailed over the faith in future improvement ; while [Filangieri]325-filangieri 's social superiority mitigated [his]325-filangieri view of the evils and magnified the efficacy of the proposed remedies . [Odo]234-odo 's days passed agreeably in such intercourse , or in the excitement of excursions to [the ruined cities]4947-the ruined cities ; and as [the court]814-the court and [the higher society of [Naples]59-naples]4949-the higher society of naples offered little to engage [him]234-odo , [he]234-odo gradually restricted [himself]234-odo to [the small circle of chosen spirits gathered at [the villa Hamilton]4951-the villa hamilton]4950-the small circle of chosen spirits gathered at the villa hamilton . To these [he]234-odo fancied [the abate de Crucis]4750-the abate de crucis might prove an interesting addition ; and the desire to learn something of [this problematic person]4953-this problematic person induced [him]234-odo to quit [the villa]4954-the villa at the moment when [the abate]624-the abate took leave . [They]4956-they found [themselves]4956-they together on the threshold ; and [Odo]234-odo , recalling to the other the circumstances of [their]4956-they first meeting , proposed that [they]4956-they should dismiss [[their]4956-they carriages]4957-their carriages and regain [the city]2261-the city on foot . [De Crucis]462-de crucis readily consented ; and [they]4956-they were soon descending [the hill of [Posilipo]120-posilipo]4959-the hill of posilipo . Here and there a turn in [the road]726-the road brought [them]4956-they to an open space whence [they]4956-they commanded [the bay from [Procida]129-procida to [Sorrento]130-sorrento]4961-the bay from procida to sorrento , with [Capri]125-capri afloat in liquid gold and the long blue shadow of [Vesuvius]126-vesuvius stretching like a menace toward [the city]2261-the city . The spectacle was one of which [Odo]234-odo never wearied ; but today it barely diverted [him]234-odo from the charms of [[his]234-odo companion]840-his companion 's talk . [The abate de Crucis]4750-the abate de crucis had that quality of repressed enthusiasm , of an intellectual sensibility tempered by self - possession , which exercises the strongest attraction over a mind not yet master of itself . Though all [he]234-odo said had a personal note [he]234-odo seemed to withhold [himself]234-odo even in the moment of greatest expansion : like [some prince who should enrich [his]4965-some prince who should enrich his favourites from the public treasury but keep his private fortune unimpaired favourites from the public treasury but keep [his]4965-some prince who should enrich his favourites from the public treasury but keep his private fortune unimpaired private fortune unimpaired]4965-some prince who should enrich his favourites from the public treasury but keep his private fortune unimpaired . In the course of [their]4956-they conversation [Odo]234-odo learned that though of Austrian birth [[his]234-odo companion]840-his companion was of mingled English and Florentine parentage : a fact perhaps explaining the mixture of urbanity and reserve that lent such charm to [his]234-odo manner . [He]234-odo told [Odo]234-odo that [his]234-odo connection with [the Holy Office]3229-the holy office had been only temporary , and that , having contracted a severe cold the previous winter in [Germany]131-germany , [he]234-odo had accepted a secretaryship in the service of [the Papal Nuncio]9523-the papal nuncio in order to enjoy the benefits of a mild climate . " By profession , "[234-odo] [he]234-odo added , " [I]234-odo am [a pedagogue]9543-a pedagogue , and shall soon travel to [Rome]11-rome , where [I]234-odo have been called by [Prince Bracciano]464-prince bracciano to act as governor to [[his]464-prince bracciano son]3683-his son ; and meanwhile [I]234-odo am taking advantage of [[my]234-odo residence]9545-my residence here to indulge [my]234-odo taste for antiquarian studies . "[234-odo] [He]234-odo went on to praise [the company [they]4970-our had just left]4969-the company they had just left , declaring that [he]234-odo knew no better way for [a young man]3366-a young man to form [his]3366-a young man mind than by frequenting the society of [men of conflicting views and equal capacity]4972-men of conflicting views and equal capacity . " Nothing , "[234-odo] said [he]234-odo , " is more injurious to the growth of character than to be secluded from argument and opposition ; as nothing is healthier than to be obliged to find good reasons for [one]8494-one 's beliefs on pain of surrendering them . "[234-odo] " But , "[234-odo] said [Odo]234-odo , struck with this declaration , " to [a man of [your]9547-a man of your cloth cloth]9547-a man of your cloth there is one belief which never surrenders to reason . "[905-the other] [The other]905-the other smiled . " True , "[234-odo] [he]234-odo agreed ; " but [I]234-odo often marvel to see how little [[our]4970-our opponents]9548-our opponents know of that belief . The wisest of [them]9548-our opponents seem in the case of [those children at [[our]4970-our country]9550-our country fairs who gape at the incredible things depicted on the curtains of [the booths]9551-the booths , without asking [themselves]9549-those children at our country fairs who gape at the incredible things depicted on the curtains of the booths , without asking themselves whether the reality matches its presentment whether the reality matches its presentment]9549-those children at our country fairs who gape at the incredible things depicted on the curtains of the booths , without asking themselves whether the reality matches its presentment . The weakness of human nature has compelled [us]4970-our to paint the outer curtain of [the sanctuary]9552-the sanctuary in gaudy colours , and the malicious fancy of [[our]4970-our enemies]8629-our enemies has given a monstrous outline to these pictures ; but what are such vanities to [one who has passed beyond , and beheld the beauty of [[the King]658-the king 's daughter]9556-the king 's daughter]9554-one who has passed beyond , and beheld the beauty of the king 's daughter , all glorious within ? "[234-odo] As though unwilling to linger on such grave topics , [he]234-odo turned the talk to the scene at [their]4974-their feet , questioning [Odo]234-odo as to the impression [Naples]59-naples had made on [him]234-odo . [He]234-odo listened courteously to [the young man]2380-the young man 's comments on the wretched state of [the peasantry]8358-the peasantry , the extravagances of the court and [nobility]4977-nobility and the judicial corruption which made [the lower classes]4978-the lower classes submit to any injustice rather than seek redress through the courts . [De Crucis]462-de crucis agreed with [him]234-odo in the main , admitting that the monopoly of corn , the maintenance of feudal rights and [the King]658-the king 's indifference to the graver duties of [his]658-the king rank placed [the kingdom of [Naples]59-naples]4980-the kingdom of naples far below [such states as [Tuscany]18-tuscany or [Venetia]132-venetia]4981-such states as tuscany or venetia ; " though , "[234-odo] [he]234-odo added , " [I]234-odo think [[our]9557-our economists]9558-our economists , in praising [one state]9559-one state at the expense of another , too often overlook those differences of character and climate that must ever make it impossible to govern different races in the same manner . [[Our]9557-our peasants]4207-our peasants have a blunt saying : Cut off the dog 's tail and [he]658-the king is still a dog ; and so [I]234-odo suspect the most enlightened rule would hardly bring [this prompt and choleric people]9561-this prompt and choleric people , living on a volcanic soil amid a teeming vegetation , into any resemblance with [the clear - headed Tuscan]9562-the clear - headed tuscan or [the gentle and dignified Roman]9563-the gentle and dignified roman . "[234-odo] As [he]234-odo spoke [they]4982-they emerged upon [the Chiaia]133-the chiaia , where at that hour the quality took the air in [[their]4982-they carriages]4957-their carriages , while [the lower classes]4978-the lower classes thronged the footway . A more vivacious scene [no city of]4985-no city of [Europe]40-europe could present . The gilt coaches drawn by six or eight of the lively Neapolitan horses , decked with plumes and artificial flowers and preceded by running footmen who beat [the foot - passengers]4986-the foot - passengers aside with long staves ; [the richly - dressed ladies seated in this never - ending file of carriages , bejewelled like miraculous images and languidly bowing to [[their]4987-the richly - dressed ladies seated in this never - ending file of carriages , bejewelled like miraculous images and languidly bowing to their friends friends]4988-their friends]4987-the richly - dressed ladies seated in this never - ending file of carriages , bejewelled like miraculous images and languidly bowing to their friends ; [the throngs of [citizens]4990-citizens and [[their]4990-citizens wives]639-their wives in holiday dress]4989-the throngs of citizens and their wives in holiday dress ; the sellers of sherbet , ices and pastry bearing [their]4987-the richly - dressed ladies seated in this never - ending file of carriages , bejewelled like miraculous images and languidly bowing to their friends trays and barrels through [the crowd]1568-the crowd with strange cries and the jingling of bells ; [the friars of every order in [their]4993-the friars of every order in their various habits various habits]4993-the friars of every order in their various habits , [the street - musicians]4994-the street - musicians , [the half - naked lazzaroni]4995-the half - naked lazzaroni , cripples and [beggars]756-beggars , who fringed [the throng like the line of scum edging a fair lake;--this medley of sound and colour , which in fact resembled some sudden growth of the fiery soil]4997-the throng like the line of scum edging a fair lake;--this medley of sound and colour , which in fact resembled some sudden growth of the fiery soil , was an expressive comment on [the abate]624-the abate 's words . " Look , "[624-the abate] [he]624-the abate continued , as [he]624-the abate and [Odo]234-odo drew aside to escape the mud from an emblazoned chariot , " at the gold - leaf on the panels of [that coach]9564-that coach and the gold - lace on the liveries of those lacqueys . Is there [any other city in [the world where gold is so prodigally used]9566-the world where gold is so prodigally used]9565-any other city in the world where gold is so prodigally used ? Where [the monks]1356-the monks gild [their]1356-the monks relics , [the nobility]1665-the nobility [[their]1356-the monks servants]8441-their servants , [the apothecaries]9570-the apothecaries [their]1356-the monks pills , [the very butchers]9571-the very butchers [their]1356-the monks mutton ? One might fancy [their]1356-the monks bright sun had set [them]1356-the monks the example ! And how cold and grey [all soberer tints]9572-all soberer tints must seem to [these children of [Apollo]395-apollo]9573-these children of apollo ! Well -- so it is with [their]1356-the monks religion and [their]1356-the monks daily life . [I]624-the abate wager [half those naked wretches yonder]9574-half those naked wretches yonder would rather attend a fine religious service , with abundance of gilt candles , music from gilt organ - pipes , and incense from gilt censers , than eat a good meal or sleep in a decent bed ; as [they]9574-half those naked wretches yonder would rather starve under [a handsome merry King]9575-a handsome merry king that has the name of being [the best billiard - player in [Europe]40-europe]9576-the best billiard - player in europe than go full under one of [[your]9577-your solemn reforming Austrian Archdukes]9578-your solemn reforming austrian archdukes ! "[624-the abate] The words recalled to [Odo Crescenti]234-odo 's theory of the influence of character and climate on the course of history ; and this subject soon engrossing [both speakers]4999-both speakers , [they]4999-both speakers wandered on , inattentive to [their]4999-both speakers surroundings , till [they]4999-both speakers found [themselves]4999-both speakers in [the thickest concourse of [the Toledo]134-the toledo]5000-the thickest concourse of the toledo . Here for a moment [the dense crowd]5001-the dense crowd hemmed [them]4999-both speakers in ; and as [they]4999-both speakers stood observing the humours of the scene , [Odo]234-odo 's eye fell on the thick - set figure of [a man in [doctor]5003-doctor 's dress , who was being led through the press by [two agents of the Inquisition]5004-two agents of the inquisition]5002-a man in doctor 's dress , who was being led through the press by two agents of the inquisition . The sight was too common to have fixed [his]234-odo attention , had [he]234-odo not recognised with a start [the irascible red - faced professor who , on [his]5005-the irascible red - faced professor who , on his first visit to vivaldi , had defended the diluvial theory of creation first visit to [Vivaldi]362-fulvia , had defended the Diluvial theory of creation]5005-the irascible red - faced professor who , on his first visit to vivaldi , had defended the diluvial theory of creation . The sight raised a host of memories from which [Odo]234-odo would gladly have beaten a retreat ; but [the crowd]1568-the crowd held [him]234-odo in check and a moment later [he]234-odo saw that [the doctor]2437-the doctor 's eyes were fixed on [him]234-odo with an air of recognition . A movement of pity succeeded [his]234-odo first impulse , and turning to [de Crucis]462-de crucis [he]234-odo exclaimed:--"I see [yonder]9579-yonder [an old acquaintance who seems in an unlucky plight and with whom [I]905-the other should be glad to speak]9580-an old acquaintance who seems in an unlucky plight and with whom i should be glad to speak . "[905-the other] [The other]905-the other , following [his]234-odo glance , beckoned to one of [the sbirri , who made [his]905-the other way through the throng with the alacrity of one summoned by [a superior]5010-a superior]5009-the sbirri , who made his way through the throng with the alacrity of one summoned by a superior . [De Crucis]462-de crucis exchanged a few words with [him]905-the other , and then signed to [him]905-the other to return to [his]905-the other charge , who presently vanished in some fresh shifting of [the crowd]1568-the crowd . " [[Your]234-odo friend]8799-your friend , "[462-de crucis] said [de Crucis]462-de crucis , " has been summoned before the Holy Office to answer a charge of heresy preferred by [the authorities]2448-the authorities . [He]8799-your friend has lately been appointed to the chair of physical sciences in [the University]9247-the university here , and has doubtless allowed [himself]8799-your friend to publish openly views that were better expounded in the closet . [His]8799-your friend offence , however , appears to be a mild one , and [I]462-de crucis make no doubt [he]8799-your friend will be set free in a few days . "[462-de crucis] This , however , did not satisfy [Odo]234-odo ; and [he]234-odo asked [de Crucis]462-de crucis if there were no way of speaking with [the doctor]2437-the doctor at once . [[His]234-odo companion]840-his companion hesitated . " It can easily be arranged , "[234-odo] said [he]234-odo ; " but -- pardon [me]234-odo , [cavaliere]8111-cavaliere -- are [you]8111-cavaliere well - advised in mixing [yourself]8111-cavaliere in such matters ? "[234-odo] " [I]234-odo am well - advised in seeking to serve [a friend]8895-a friend ! "[234-odo] [Odo]234-odo somewhat hotly returned ; and [de Crucis]462-de crucis , with a faint smile of approval , replied quietly : " In that case [I]462-de crucis will obtain permission for [you]234-odo to visit [[your]234-odo friend]8799-your friend in the morning . "[462-de crucis] [He]234-odo was true to [his]234-odo word ; and the next forenoon [Odo]234-odo , accompanied by [an officer of police]5014-an officer of police , was taken to [the prison of the Inquisition]5015-the prison of the inquisition . Here [he]234-odo found [[his]234-odo old acquaintance]5016-his old acquaintance seated in [a clean commodious room]5017-a clean commodious room and reading [Aristotle]431-aristotle 's " History of Animals , "[234-odo] the only volume of [[his]234-odo library]2686-his library that [he]234-odo had been permitted to carry with [him]234-odo . [He]234-odo welcomed [Odo]234-odo heartily , and on [the latter]870-the latter 's enquiring what had brought [him]234-odo to this plight , replied with some dignity that [he]234-odo had been led [there]606-there in the fulfilment of [his]234-odo duty . " Some months ago , "[234-odo] [he]234-odo continued , " [I]234-odo was summoned hither to profess the natural sciences in [the University]9247-the university ; a summons [I]234-odo readily accepted , since [I]234-odo hoped , by the study of [a volcanic soil]9588-a volcanic soil , to enlarge [my]234-odo knowledge of [the globe]9589-the globe 's formation . Such in fact was the case , but to [my]234-odo surprise [my]234-odo researches led [me]234-odo to adopt the views [I]234-odo had formerly combated , and [I]234-odo now find [myself]234-odo in the ranks of [the Vulcanists]8557-the vulcanists , or believers in the secondary origin of [the earth]1750-the earth : a view [you]9592-you may remember [I]234-odo once opposed with all the zeal of inexperience . Having firmly established every point in [my]234-odo argument according to the Baconian method of investigation , [I]234-odo felt it [my]234-odo duty to enlighten [[my]234-odo scholars]9593-my scholars ; and in the course of [my]234-odo last lecture [I]234-odo announced the result of [my]234-odo investigations . [I]234-odo was of course aware of the inevitable result ; but [the servants of Truth]9594-the servants of truth have no choice but to follow where [she]9595-she calls , and [many]3899-many have joyfully traversed stonier places than [I]234-odo am likely to travel . "[234-odo] Nothing could exceed the respect with which [Odo]234-odo heard this simple confession of faith . It was as though [the speaker]2090-the speaker had unconsciously convicted [him]234-odo of remissness , of cowardice even ; so vain and windy [his]234-odo theorising seemed , judged by the other 's deliberate act ! Yet placed as [he]234-odo was , what could [he]234-odo do , how advance [their]5022-their common end , but by passively waiting on events ? At least , [he]234-odo reflected , [he]234-odo could perform the trivial service of trying to better [[his]234-odo friend]2124-his friend 's case ; and this [he]234-odo eagerly offered to attempt . [The doctor]2437-the doctor thanked [him]234-odo , but without any great appearance of emotion : [Odo]234-odo was struck by the change which had transformed [a heady and intemperate speaker]5025-a heady and intemperate speaker into [a model of philosophic calm]5026-a model of philosophic calm . [The doctor]2437-the doctor , indeed , seemed far more concerned for the safety of [[his]2437-the doctor library]2686-his library and [his]2437-the doctor cabinet of minerals than for [his]2437-the doctor own . " Happily , "[2437-the doctor] said [he]2437-the doctor , " [I]2437-the doctor am not [a man of family]9597-a man of family , and can therefore sacrifice [my]2437-the doctor liberty with a clear conscience : a fact [I]2437-the doctor am the more thankful for when [I]2437-the doctor recall the moral distress of [[our]5030-our poor friend]9598-our poor friend [Vivaldi]362-fulvia , when compelled to desert [his]9598-our poor friend post rather than be separated from [[his]9598-our poor friend daughter]1475-his daughter . "[2437-the doctor] The name brought the colour to [Odo]234-odo 's brow , and with an embarrassed air [he]234-odo asked what news [the doctor]2437-the doctor had of [[their]5030-our friend]2974-their friend . " Alas , "[905-the other] said [the other]905-the other , " the last was of [his]9598-our poor friend death , which happened two years since in [Pavia]12-pavia . [The Sardinian government]2179-the sardinian government had , as [you]9601-you probably know , confiscated [his]9598-our poor friend small property on [his]9598-our poor friend leaving [the state]2921-the state , and [I]905-the other am told [he]9598-our poor friend died in great poverty , and in sore anxiety for [[his]9598-our poor friend daughter]1475-his daughter 's future . "[905-the other] [He]234-odo added that these events had taken place before [his]234-odo own departure from [Turin]17-turin , and that since then [he]234-odo had learned nothing of [Fulvia]362-fulvia 's fate , save that [she]362-fulvia was said to have made [her]362-fulvia home with [an aunt who lived in [a town of [the Veneto]135-the veneto]5034-a town of the veneto]5033-an aunt who lived in a town of the veneto . [Odo]234-odo listened in silence . The lapse of time , and the absence of any links of association , had dimmed [the girl]2319-the girl 's image in [his]234-odo breast ; but at the mere sound of [her]2319-the girl name it lived again , and [he]234-odo felt [her]2319-the girl interwoven with [his]234-odo deepest fibres . The picture of [[her]2319-the girl father]1415-her father 's death and of [her]2319-the girl own need filled [him]234-odo with an ineffectual pity , and for a moment [he]234-odo thought of seeking [her]2319-the girl out ; but [the other]905-the other could recall neither the name of [the town [she]2319-the girl had removed to]5038-the town she had removed to nor that of [the relative who had given [her]2319-the girl [a home]5040-a home]5039-the relative who had given her a home . To aid [the good doctor]5041-the good doctor was a simpler business . The intervention of [de Crucis]462-de crucis and [Odo]234-odo 's own influence sufficed to effect [his]234-odo release , and on the payment of a heavy fine ( in which [Odo]234-odo privately assisted [him]234-odo ) [he]234-odo was reinstated in [his]234-odo chair . The only promise exacted by [the Holy Office]3229-the holy office was that [he]234-odo should in future avoid propounding [his]234-odo own views on questions already decided by [Scripture]465-scripture , and to this [he]234-odo readily agreed , since , as [he]234-odo shrewdly remarked to [Odo]234-odo , [his]234-odo opinions were now well - known , and [any who wished farther instruction]5043-any who wished farther instruction had only to apply to [him]234-odo privately . [The old Duke]4864-the old duke having invited [Odo]234-odo to return to [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro with such treasures as [he]234-odo had collected for [the ducal galleries]5045-the ducal galleries , [the young man]2380-the young man resolved to visit [Rome]11-rome on [his]2380-the young man way to [the North]136-the north . [His]234-odo acquaintance with [de Crucis]462-de crucis had grown into something like friendship since [their]5047-their joint effort in behalf of [the imprisoned sage]5048-the imprisoned sage , and [the abate]624-the abate preparing to set out about the same time , [the two]812-the two agreed to travel together . [The road leading from [Naples]59-naples to [Rome]11-rome]5051-the road leading from naples to rome was at that time one of the worst in [Italy]5-italy , and was besides so ill - provided with [inns]5052-inns that there was no inducement to linger on the way . [De Crucis]462-de crucis , however , succeeded in enlivening even this tedious journey . [He]234-odo was [a good linguist]5053-a good linguist and [a sound classical scholar]5054-a sound classical scholar , besides having , as [he]234-odo had told [Odo]234-odo , a pronounced taste for antiquarian research . In addition to this , [he]234-odo performed agreeably on the violin , and was well - acquainted with the history of music . [His]234-odo chief distinction , however , lay in the ease with which [he]234-odo wore [his]234-odo accomplishments , and in a breadth of view that made it possible to discuss with [him]234-odo many subjects distasteful to [most men of [his]234-odo cloth]5055-most men of his cloth . The sceptical or licentious ecclesiastic was common enough ; but [Odo]234-odo had never before met [a priest who united serious piety with this indulgent temper]5056-a priest who united serious piety with this indulgent temper , or who had learning enough to do justice to the arguments of [[his]234-odo opponents]5057-his opponents . On [his]234-odo venturing one evening to compliment [de Crucis]462-de crucis on these qualities , [the latter]870-the latter replied with a smile : " Whatever has been lately advanced against [the Jesuits]2221-the jesuits , it can hardly be denied that [they]2221-the jesuits were [good school - masters]9605-good school - masters ; and it is to [them]2221-the jesuits [I]234-odo owe the talents [you]234-odo have been pleased to admire . Indeed , "[234-odo] [he]234-odo continued , quietly fingering [his]234-odo violin , " [I]234-odo was [myself]234-odo bred in [the order]9160-the order : a fact [I]234-odo do not often make known in the present heated state of public opinion , but which [I]234-odo never conceal when commended for any quality that [I]234-odo owe to [the Society]8939-the society rather than to [my]234-odo own merit . "[234-odo] Surprise for the moment silenced [Odo]234-odo ; for though it was known that [Italy]5-italy was full of [former Jesuits who had been permitted to remain in [the country]818-the country as [secular priests]4098-secular priests , and even to act as [tutors]5062-tutors or [professors in private families]5063-professors in private families]5059-former jesuits who had been permitted to remain in the country as secular priests , and even to act as tutors or professors in private families , [he]234-odo had never thought of [de Crucis]462-de crucis in this connection . [The latter]870-the latter , seeing [his]234-odo surprise , went on : " Once [a Jesuit]9608-a jesuit , always [a Jesuit]9608-a jesuit , [I]870-the latter suppose . [I]870-the latter at least owe [the Society]106-the society too much not to own [my]870-the latter debt when the occasion offers . Nor could [I]870-the latter ever see the force of the charge so often brought against [us]9610-our : that [we]9610-our sacrifice everything to the glory of the order . For what is the glory of [the order]9160-the order ? [Our]9610-our own motto has declared it : Ad majorem Dei gloriam -- who works for [the Society]8939-the society works for [its Master]1242-its master . If [our]9610-our zeal has been sometimes misdirected , [our]9610-our blood has a thousand times witnessed to its sincerity . In [the Indies]87-the indies , in [America]137-america , in [England]49-england during the great persecution , and lately on [[our]9610-our own unnatural coasts]9614-our own unnatural coasts , [the Jesuits]336-the jesuits have died for [Christ]264-christ as joyfully as [[His]264-christ first disciples]9615-his first disciples died for [Him]264-christ . Yet these are but a small number in comparison with [the countless servants of the order who , labouring in [far countries]9617-far countries among [savage peoples]9618-savage peoples , or surrounded by [the heretical enemies of [our]9610-our faith]9619-the heretical enemies of our faith]9616-the countless servants of the order who , labouring in far countries among savage peoples , or surrounded by the heretical enemies of our faith , have died the far bitterer death of moral isolation : setting [themselves]9616-the countless servants of the order who , labouring in far countries among savage peoples , or surrounded by the heretical enemies of our faith to [their]9616-the countless servants of the order who , labouring in far countries among savage peoples , or surrounded by the heretical enemies of our faith task with the knowledge that [their]9616-the countless servants of the order who , labouring in far countries among savage peoples , or surrounded by the heretical enemies of our faith lives were but so much indistinguishable dust to be added to the sum of human effort . What [association founded on human interests]9620-association founded on human interests has ever commanded such devotion ? And what merely human authority could count on such unquestioning obedience , not in a mob of [poor illiterate monks]9621-poor illiterate monks , but in [men chosen for [their]9622-men chosen for their capacity and trained to the exercise of their highest faculties capacity and trained to the exercise of [their]9622-men chosen for their capacity and trained to the exercise of their highest faculties highest faculties]9622-men chosen for their capacity and trained to the exercise of their highest faculties ? Yet there have never lacked [such men]9623-such men to serve [the Order]9160-the order ; and as [one of [[our]9610-our enemies]8629-our enemies]9625-one of our enemies has said -- [[our]9610-our noblest enemy]9627-our noblest enemy , [the great Pascal--'je crois volontiers aux histoires do nt les temoins se font egorger]9628-the great pascal--'je crois volontiers aux histoires do nt les temoins se font egorger . ' "[870-the latter] [He]5065-he did not again revert to [his]5065-he connection with [the Jesuits]336-the jesuits ; but in the farther course of [their]5066-their acquaintance [Odo]234-odo was often struck by the firmness with which [he]5065-he testified to the faith that was in [him]5065-he , without using the jargon of piety , or seeming , by [his]5065-he own attitude , to cast a reflection on that of [others]1388-others . [He]5065-he was indeed master of that worldly science which [the Jesuits]336-the jesuits excelled in imparting , and which , though it might sink to hypocrisy in smaller natures , became in a finely - tempered spirit , the very flower of Christian courtesy . [Odo]234-odo had often spoken to [de Crucis]462-de crucis of the luxurious lives led by [many of [the monastic orders in [Naples]59-naples]5069-the monastic orders in naples]5068-many of the monastic orders in naples . It might be true enough that [the monks]1356-the monks [themselves]1356-the monks , and even [[their]1356-the monks abbots]5071-their abbots , fared on fish and vegetables , and gave [their]1356-the monks time to charitable and educational work ; but it was impossible to visit [the famous monastery of [San Martino]138-san martino]5072-the famous monastery of san martino , or that of [the Carthusians]466-the carthusians at [Camaldoli]139-camaldoli , without observing that [the anchoret 's cell]5073-the anchoret 's cell had expanded into [a delightful apartment]5074-a delightful apartment , with [bedchamber , library and private chapel]5075-bedchamber , library and private chapel , and [his]5065-he cabbage - plot into [a princely garden]5076-a princely garden . [De Crucis]462-de crucis admitted the truth of the charge , explaining it in part by the character of [the Neapolitan people]5077-the neapolitan people , and by the tendency of [the northern traveller]5078-the northern traveller to forget that such apparent luxuries as [spacious rooms]5079-spacious rooms , shady groves and the like are regarded as necessities in a hot climate . [He]462-de crucis urged , moreover , that the monastic life should not be judged by a few isolated instances ; and on the way to [Rome]11-rome [he]462-de crucis proposed that [Odo]234-odo , by way of seeing the other side of the question , should visit [the ancient foundation of [the Benedictines]467-the benedictines on [Monte Cassino]142-monte cassino]5080-the ancient foundation of the benedictines on monte cassino . [The venerable monastery]5081-the venerable monastery , raised on [its]5081-the venerable monastery height over [the busy vale of [Garigliano]141-garigliano]5082-the busy vale of garigliano , like some contemplative spirit above the conflicting problems of life , might well be held to represent the nobler side of Christian celibacy . For nearly a thousand years [its]5081-the venerable monastery fortified walls had been the stronghold of the humanities , and [generations of [students]5084-students]5083-generations of students had cherished and added to the treasures of [the famous library]5085-the famous library . But the Benedictine rule was as famous for good works as for learning , and its comparative abstention from dogmatic controversy and from the mechanical devotion of some of the other orders had drawn to it [men of superior mind]5086-men of superior mind , who sought in the monastic life the free exercise of the noblest activities rather than a sanctified refuge from action . This was especially true of [the monastery of [Monte Cassino]142-monte cassino]5087-the monastery of monte cassino , whither many [scholars]5088-scholars had been attracted and where [the fathers had long had the highest name for learning and beneficence]5089-the fathers had long had the highest name for learning and beneficence . [The monastery]1571-the monastery , moreover , in addition to [its]1571-the monastery charitable and educational work among [the poor]8713-the poor , maintained a school of theology to which [students]5084-students came from [all parts of [Italy]5-italy]5093-all parts of italy ; and [their]5084-students presence lent an unwonted life to the great labyrinth of [courts]5094-courts and [cloisters]5095-cloisters . [The abbot]3267-the abbot , with whom [de Crucis]462-de crucis was well - acquainted , welcomed [the travellers]1059-the travellers warmly , making [them]1059-the travellers free of [the library]2154-the library and [the archives]5099-the archives and pressing [them]1059-the travellers to prolong [their]1059-the travellers visit . Under the spell of these influences [they]1059-the travellers lingered on from day to day ; and to [Odo]234-odo they were the pleasantest days [he]462-de crucis had known . To be waked before dawn by the bell ringing for lauds -- to rise from the narrow bed in [[his]462-de crucis white - washed cell]5100-his white - washed cell , and opening [his]462-de crucis casement look forth over [the haze - enveloped valley]5101-the haze - enveloped valley , [the dark hills of [the Abruzzi]143-the abruzzi]5102-the dark hills of the abruzzi and [the remote gleam of sea]5103-the remote gleam of sea touched into being by the sunrise -- to hasten through [hushed echoing corridors]5104-hushed echoing corridors to [the church]1212-the church , where in a grey resurrection - light [the fathers]1227-the fathers were intoning the solemn office of renewal -- this morning ablution of the spirit , so like the bodily plunge into clear cold water , seemed to attune the mind to the fullest enjoyment of what was to follow : the hours of study , the talks with [the monks]1356-the monks , the strolls through cloister or [garden]5108-garden , all punctuated by the recurring summons to devotion . Yet for all its latent significance it remained to [him]462-de crucis a purely sensuous impression , the vision of a golden leisure : not a solution of life 's perplexities , but at best an honourable escape from them . 3.2 . " To know [Rome]11-rome is to have assisted at the councils of destiny ! "[462-de crucis] This cry of [a more famous traveller]5109-a more famous traveller must have struggled for expression in [Odo]234-odo 's breast as [the great city]5110-the great city , [the city of cities]5111-the city of cities , laid [her]5110-the great city irresistible hold upon [him]462-de crucis . [His]462-de crucis first impression , as [he]462-de crucis drove in the clear evening light from [the Porta del Popolo]5112-the porta del popolo to [[his]462-de crucis lodgings]2818-his lodgings in [the Via Sistina]5114-the via sistina , was of a prodigious accumulation of architectural effects , a crowding of century on century , all fused in the crucible of the Roman sun , so that each style seemed linked to the other by some subtle affinity of colour . Nowhere else , surely , is [the traveller]5115-the traveller 's first sight so crowded with surprises , with conflicting challenges to eye and brain . Here , as [he]462-de crucis passed , was a fragment of the ancient Servian wall , there [a new stucco shrine embedded in the bricks of [a medieval palace]5117-a medieval palace]5116-a new stucco shrine embedded in the bricks of a medieval palace ; on one hand [a lofty terrace crowned by a row of mouldering busts]5118-a lofty terrace crowned by a row of mouldering busts , on the other [a tower with machicolated parapet]5119-a tower with machicolated parapet , [its]5119-a tower with machicolated parapet flanks encrusted with bits of Roman sculpture and the escutcheons of [seventeenth - century Popes]5120-seventeenth - century popes . Opposite , perhaps , one of [[Fuga]468-fuga 's golden - brown churches , with windy saints blowing out of [their]5121-fuga 's golden - brown churches , with windy saints blowing out of their niches niches]5121-fuga 's golden - brown churches , with windy saints blowing out of their niches , overlooked the nereids of a barocco fountain , or [an old house]5122-an old house propped itself like [a palsied beggar against a row of Corinthian columns]5123-a palsied beggar against a row of corinthian columns ; while everywhere flights of steps led up and down to [hanging gardens]5124-hanging gardens or under archways , and each turn revealed some distant glimpse of convent - walls on the slope of [a vineyard]5125-a vineyard or of red - brown ruins profiled against [the dim sea - like reaches of [the Campagna]144-the campagna]5126-the dim sea - like reaches of the campagna . Afterward , as order was born out of chaos , and [he]462-de crucis began to thread [his]462-de crucis way among the centuries , this first vision lost something of its intensity ; yet it was always , to the last , through the eye that [Rome]11-rome possessed [him]462-de crucis . [Her]11-rome life , indeed , as though in obedience to such a setting , was an external , a spectacular business , from the wild animation of the cattle - market in [the Forum]5127-the forum or [the hucksters]5128-the hucksters ' traffic among [the fountains of [the Piazza Navona]5130-the piazza navona]5129-the fountains of the piazza navona , to the pompous entertainments in [[the cardinals]5131-the cardinals ' palaces]5132-the cardinals ' palaces and the ever - recurring religious ceremonies and processions . [Pius VI]469-pius vi . , in the reaction from [Ganganelli]429-ganganelli 's democratic ways , had restored the pomp and ceremonial of [the Vatican]5133-the vatican with the religious discipline of [the Holy Office]3229-the holy office ; and never perhaps had [Rome]11-rome been more splendid on the surface or more silent and empty within . [Odo]234-odo , at times , as [he]462-de crucis moved through [some assemblage of cardinals]5135-some assemblage of cardinals and [nobles]8360-nobles , had the sensation of walking through [a huge reverberating palace]5137-a huge reverberating palace , decked out with all the splendours of art but long since abandoned of [men]8356-men . The superficial animation , the taste for music and antiquities , all the dilettantisms of [an idle and irresponsible society]5139-an idle and irresponsible society , seemed to [him]462-de crucis to shrivel to dust in the glare of that great past that lit up every corner of the present . Through [his]462-de crucis own connections , and the influence of [de Crucis]462-de crucis , [he]462-de crucis saw all that was best not only among [the nobility]1665-the nobility , but in that ecclesiastical life now more than ever predominant in [Rome]11-rome . [Here]8091-here at last [he]462-de crucis was face to face with [the mighty Sphinx]5142-the mighty sphinx , and with the bleaching bones of [those who had tried to guess [her]5142-the mighty sphinx riddle]5143-those who had tried to guess her riddle . Wherever [he]462-de crucis went these " lost adventurers "[462-de crucis] walked [the streets]744-the streets with [him]462-de crucis , gliding between [the Princes of [the Church]1212-the church]5145-the princes of the church in the ceremonies of [Saint Peter]440-saint peter martyr 's and [the Lateran]5147-the lateran , or mingling in the company that ascended [the state staircase at [some cardinal 's levee]5149-some cardinal 's levee]5148-the state staircase at some cardinal 's levee . [He]462-de crucis met [indeed many accomplished and amiable ecclesiastics]5150-indeed many accomplished and amiable ecclesiastics , but it seemed to [him]462-de crucis that [the more thoughtful among [them]5150-indeed many accomplished and amiable ecclesiastics]5151-the more thoughtful among them had either acquired [their]5151-the more thoughtful among them peace of mind at the cost of a certain sensitiveness , or had taken refuge in a study of the past , as [the early hermits]5152-the early hermits fled to [the desert]5153-the desert from [the disorders of [Antioch]145-antioch and [Alexandria]146-alexandria]5154-the disorders of antioch and alexandria . [None]1118-none seemed disposed to face the actual problems of life , and this attitude of caution or indifference had produced a stagnation of thought that contrasted strongly with the animation of [Sir William Hamilton]454-sir william hamilton 's circle in [Naples]59-naples . The result in [Odo]234-odo 's case was a reaction toward the pleasures of [his]234-odo age ; and of these [Rome]11-rome had but few to offer . [He]462-de crucis spent some months in the study of the antique , purchasing a few good examples of sculpture for [the Duke]682-the duke , and then , without great reluctance , set out for [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro . Here [he]462-de crucis found a changed atmosphere . [The Duke]290-pianura welcomed [him]462-de crucis handsomely , and bestowed the highest praise on the rarities [he]462-de crucis had collected ; but for the moment [the court]814-the court was ruled by a new favourite , to whom [Odo]234-odo 's coming was obviously unwelcome . [This adroit adventurer]5158-this adroit adventurer , whose name was soon to become notorious throughout [Europe]40-europe , had taken [the old prince]5159-the old prince by [his]5159-the old prince darling weaknesses , and [Odo]234-odo , having no mind to share in the excesses of [the precious couple]5160-the precious couple , seized the first occasion to set out again on [his]234-odo travels . [His]234-odo course had now become one of aimless wandering ; for prudence still forbade [his]234-odo return to [Pianura]4-pianura , and [[his]234-odo patron]4869-his patron 's indifference left [him]234-odo free to come and go as [he]234-odo chose . [He]234-odo had brought from [Rome]11-rome -- that [albergo d'ira]470-albergo d'ira -- a settled melancholy of spirit , which sought refuge in such distractions as the moment offered . In such a mood change of scene was a necessity , and [he]234-odo resolved to employ the next months in visiting [several of [the mid - Italian cities]5163-the mid - italian cities]5162-several of the mid - italian cities . Toward [Florence]88-florence [he]234-odo was specially drawn by the fact that [Alfieri]306-alfieri now lived [there]606-there ; but , as often happens after such separations , the reunion was a disappointment . [Alfieri]306-alfieri , indeed , warmly welcomed [[his]306-alfieri friend]2124-his friend ; but [he]306-alfieri was engrossed in [his]306-alfieri dawning passion for [the Countess of [Albany]148-albany]5166-the countess of albany , and that [lady]5167-lady 's pitiable situation excluded all other interests from [his]306-alfieri mind . To [Odo]234-odo , to whom the years had brought an increasing detachment , this self - absorption seemed an arrest in growth ; for [Alfieri]306-alfieri 's early worship of liberty had not yet found its destined channel of expression , and for the moment [his]306-alfieri enthusiasms had shrunk to the compass of a romantic adventure . [The friends]5168-the friends parted after a few days of unsatisfying intercourse ; and it was under the influence of this final disenchantment that [Odo]234-odo set out for [Venice]41-venice . It was the vintage season , and [the travellers]1059-the travellers descended from [the Apennines]5170-the apennines on [a landscape diversified by the picturesque incidents of the grape - gathering]5171-a landscape diversified by the picturesque incidents of the grape - gathering . On every slope stood [some villa with awnings]5172-some villa with awnings spread , and [merry parties]5173-merry parties were picnicking among the vines or watching [the peasants]8472-the peasants at [their]8472-the peasants work . [Cantapresto]267-cantapresto , who had shown great reluctance at leaving [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro , where , as [he]267-cantapresto declared , [he]267-cantapresto found [himself]267-cantapresto as snug as an eel in a pasty , was now all eagerness to press forward ; and [Odo]234-odo was in the mood to allow any influence to decide [his]234-odo course . [He]234-odo had an invaluable courier in [Cantapresto]267-cantapresto , whose enormous pretensions generally assured [him]234-odo the best lodging and the fastest conveyance to be obtained , and who was never happier than when outwitting [a rival emissary]5175-a rival emissary , or bribing [a landlord]5176-a landlord to serve up on [Odo]234-odo 's table the repast ordered in advance for [some distinguished traveller]5177-some distinguished traveller . [His]234-odo impatience to reach [Venice]41-venice , which [he]234-odo described as the scene of all conceivable delights , had on this occasion tripled [his]234-odo zeal , and [they]5178-they travelled rapidly to [Padua]109-padua , where [he]234-odo had engaged [a burchiello]5179-a burchiello for the passage down [the Brenta]149-the brenta . Here , however , [he]234-odo found [he]234-odo had been outdone at [his]234-odo own game ; for [the servant of [an English Duke]5181-an english duke]5180-the servant of an english duke had captured the burchiello and embarked [his]234-odo noble party before [Cantapresto]267-cantapresto reached [the wharf]4794-the wharf . This being the season of the villeggiatura , when [the Venetian nobility]5183-the venetian nobility were exchanging visits on [the mainland]5184-the mainland , every conveyance was in motion and [no other boat]5185-no other boat to be had for a week ; while as for the " bucentaur "[267-cantapresto] or public bark , which was just then getting under way , it was already packed to the gunwale with [Jews]1581-jews , [pedlars and such vermin]5187-pedlars and such vermin , and [the captain]5188-the captain swore by the three thousand relics of [Saint Justina]471-saint justina that [he]5188-the captain had no room on board for so much as a hungry flea . [Odo]234-odo , who had accompanied [Cantapresto]267-cantapresto to [the water - side]5189-the water - side , was listening to these assurances and to [the soprano]1599-the soprano 's vain invectives , when [a well - dressed young man]5191-a well - dressed young man stepped up to [the group]1903-the group . [This gentleman , whose accent and dress]5193-this gentleman , whose accent and dress showed [him]5191-a well - dressed young man to be [a Frenchman of quality]5194-a frenchman of quality , told [Odo]234-odo that [he]5191-a well - dressed young man was come from [Vicenza]150-vicenza , whither [he]5191-a well - dressed young man had gone to engage [a company of actors for [[his]5191-a well - dressed young man friend]2124-his friend the Procuratore Bra , who was entertaining a distinguished company at [[his]2124-his friend villa on [the Brenta]149-the brenta]5197-his villa on the brenta]5195-a company of actors for his friend the procuratore bra , who was entertaining a distinguished company at his villa on the brenta ; that [he]2124-his friend was now returning with [[his]2124-his friend players]5198-his players , and that [he]2124-his friend would be glad to convey [Odo]234-odo so far on [[his]5191-a well - dressed young man road]5199-his road to [Venice]41-venice . [[His]5191-a well - dressed young man friend]2124-his friend 's seat , [he]5191-a well - dressed young man added , was near [Oriago]151-oriago , but [a few miles above [Fusina]152-fusina]5201-a few miles above fusina , where a public conveyance might always be found ; so that [Odo]234-odo would doubtless be able to proceed the same night to [Venice]41-venice . This civil offer [Odo]234-odo at once accepted , and [the Frenchman thereupon]5202-the frenchman thereupon suggested that , as [the party]1452-the party was to set out the next day at sunrise , [the two]812-the two should sup together and pass the intervening hours in such diversions as [the city]2261-the city offered . [They]812-the two returned to [the inn]1050-the inn , where [the actors]5207-the actors were also lodged , and [[Odo]234-odo 's host]5208-odo 's host having ordered a handsome supper , proposed , with [[his]5208-odo 's host guest]5209-his guest 's permission , to invite [the leading members of [the company]1753-the company]5210-the leading members of the company to partake of it .
