[His]234-odo youth , [his]234-odo good looks , [his]234-odo open mien , [his]234-odo known affability of manner , were so many arguments in [his]234-odo favour with [an impressionable and impulsive people]6507-an impressionable and impulsive people ; and it was perhaps natural that [he]234-odo should interpret as a tribute to [his]234-odo principles the sympathy which [[his]234-odo person]6508-his person aroused . It is certain that [he]234-odo fancied [himself]234-odo , at that time , as well - acquainted with [[his]234-odo subjects]8419-his subjects as [they]8419-his subjects believed [themselves]8419-his subjects to be with [him]234-odo ; and the understanding supposed to exist was productive of equal satisfaction to both sides . [The new Duke]6510-the new duke had thrown [himself]234-odo with extraordinary zeal into the task of loving and understanding [[his]234-odo people]1264-his people . It had been [his]234-odo refuge from a hundred doubts and uncertainties , the one clearly - defined object in an obscure and troubled fate . And [their]8419-his subjects response had , almost immediately , turned [his]234-odo task into a pleasure . It was so easy to rule if [[one]8494-one 's subjects]6513-one 's subjects loved [one]8494-one ! And so easy to be loved if only one loved enough in return ! If [he]234-odo did not , like [the Pope]1248-the pope , describe [himself]234-odo to [[his]234-odo people]1264-his people as [the servant of [the servants of [God]249-god]6518-the servants of god]6517-the servant of the servants of god , [he]234-odo at least longed to make [them]1264-his people feel that this new gospel of service was the base on which all sovereignty must henceforth repose . It was not that [his]234-odo first year of power had been without moments of disillusionment . [He]234-odo had had more than one embittering experience of intrigue and perfidy , more than one glimpse of the pitfalls besetting [his]234-odo course ; but [his]234-odo confidence in [his]234-odo own powers and [his]234-odo faith in [[his]234-odo people]1264-his people remained unshaken , and with two such beliefs to sustain [him]234-odo it seemed as though no difficulties would prove insurmountable . Such at least was the mood in which , on the morning of [his]234-odo entry into [Pianura]4-pianura , [he]234-odo prepared to face [[his]234-odo subjects]8419-his subjects . Strangely enough , the state entry began at [Ponte di Po]121-ponte di po , [the very spot where , on a stormy midnight some seven years earlier , [the new Duke]6510-the new duke had landed]6521-the very spot where , on a stormy midnight some seven years earlier , the new duke had landed , [a fugitive from [[his]234-odo future realm]6524-his future realm]6523-a fugitive from his future realm . Here , according to an ancient custom , [the sovereign]1435-the sovereign awaited the arrival of [[his]1435-the sovereign ministers]8730-his ministers and court ; and then , taking seat in [[his]1435-the sovereign state barge]6527-his state barge , proceeded by water to [Pianura]4-pianura , followed by an escort of [galleys]6528-galleys . A great tent hung with tapestries had been set up on [the river - bank]6529-the river - bank ; and here [Odo]234-odo awaited the approach of [the barge]6530-the barge . As it touched at [the landing - stage]6341-the landing - stage [he]234-odo stepped out , and [[his]234-odo prime minister]6532-his prime minister , [Count Trescorre]254-trescorre , advanced toward [him]234-odo , accompanied by [the dignitaries of [the court]814-the court]6533-the dignitaries of the court . [Trescorre]254-trescorre had aged in the intervening years . [His]254-trescorre delicate features had withered like [a woman]5452-a woman 's , and the fine irony of [his]254-trescorre smile had taken an edge of cruelty . [His]254-trescorre face suggested a worn engraving , the lines of which have been deepened by a too - incisive instrument . [The functionaries attending [him]254-trescorre]6536-the functionaries attending him were , with few exceptions , [the same who had figured in a like capacity at [[the late sovereign]6538-the late sovereign 's court]6539-the late sovereign 's court]6537-the same who had figured in a like capacity at the late sovereign 's court . With the passing of the years [they]6536-the functionaries attending him had grown heavier or thinner , more ponderous or stiffer in [their]6536-the functionaries attending him movements , and as [they]6536-the functionaries attending him advanced , in [their]6536-the functionaries attending him splendid but unwieldy court dress , [they]6536-the functionaries attending him seemed to [Odo]234-odo like superannuated marionettes whose springs and wires have rusted from disuse . [The barge]6530-the barge was a magnificent gilded Bucentaur , presented to [[the late Duke]4180-the late duke 's father]6542-the late duke 's father by [the Doge of [Venice]41-venice]6543-the doge of venice , and carved by [[[his]254-trescorre Serenity]6544-his serenity 's most famous sculptors in wood]6545-his serenity 's most famous sculptors in wood . [Tritons and sea - goddesses]6546-tritons and sea - goddesses encircled the prow and throned above the stern , and the interior of [the deck - house]5478-the deck - house was adorned with delicate rilievi and painted by [Tiepolo]510-tiepolo with scenes from the myth of Amphitrite . Here [the new Duke]6510-the new duke seated [himself]6510-the new duke , surrounded by [[his]6510-the new duke household]1173-his household , and presently [the heavy craft]6550-the heavy craft , rowed by [sixty galley - slaves]6551-sixty galley - slaves , was moving slowly up [the river]2315-the river toward [Pianura]4-pianura . In the clear spring light [the old walled city]6553-the old walled city , with [its]6553-the old walled city domes and towers , rose pleasantly among budding orchards and [fields]721-fields . Close at hand were the crenellations of [[Bracciaforte]398-bracciaforte 's keep]6555-bracciaforte 's keep , and just beyond , the ornate cupola of [the royal chapel]6556-the royal chapel , symbolising in [their]6557-their proximity the successive ambitions of [the ducal race]6558-the ducal race ; while [the round - arched campanile of [the Cathedral]3023-the cathedral]6559-the round - arched campanile of the cathedral and [the square tower of [the mediaeval town - hall]6562-the mediaeval town - hall]6561-the square tower of the mediaeval town - hall sprang up side by side , marking [the centre of [the free city]3801-the free city which [the Valseccas]6197-the valseccas had subjugated]6563-the centre of the free city which the valseccas had subjugated . It seemed to [the new Duke]6510-the new duke , who was given to such reflections , that [he]6510-the new duke could read [his]6510-the new duke race 's history in that broken skyline ; but [he]6510-the new duke was soon snatched from its perusal by the cheers of [the crowd who thronged [the river - bank]6529-the river - bank to greet [his]6510-the new duke approach]6567-the crowd who thronged the river - bank to greet his approach . As [the Bucentaur]485-the bucentaur touched at [the landing - stage]6341-the landing - stage and [Odo]234-odo stepped out on the red carpet strewn with flowers , while cannon thundered from the walls and the bells burst into renewed jubilation , [he]6510-the new duke felt [himself]6510-the new duke for the first time face to face with [[his]6510-the new duke people]1264-his people . The very ceremonial which in other cases kept [them]1264-his people apart was now a means of closer communication ; for it was to show [himself]6510-the new duke to [them]1264-his people that [he]6510-the new duke was making a public entry into [[his]6510-the new duke capital]6505-his capital , and it was to see [him]6510-the new duke that [the city]2261-the city had poured forth [her]2261-the city shouting throngs . The shouts rose and widened as [he]6510-the new duke advanced , enveloping [him]6510-the new duke in a mounting tide of welcome , in which cannon , bells and voices -- the decreed and the spontaneous acclamations -- were indistinguishably merged . In like manner , approbation of [[his]6510-the new duke person]6508-his person was mingled with a simple enjoyment of the show of which [he]6510-the new duke formed a part ; and it must have taken a more experienced head than [Odo]234-odo 's to distinguish between the two currents of enthusiasm on which [he]6510-the new duke felt [himself]6510-the new duke swept forward . The pageant was indeed brilliant enough to justify the popular transport ; and the fact that [the new Duke]6510-the new duke formed a worthy centre to so much magnificence was not lost on [[his]6510-the new duke splendour - loving subjects]6575-his splendour - loving subjects . [The late sovereign]6538-the late sovereign had so long held [himself]6538-the late sovereign aloof that [the city]2261-the city was unaccustomed to such shows , and as the procession wound into [the square]1592-the square before [the Cathedral]3023-the cathedral , where the thickest of [the crowd]1568-the crowd was massed , the very pealing of the church - bells was lost in the roar of human voices . [Don Serafino]267-cantapresto , [[the Bishop]1234-the bishop 's nephew]8265-the bishop 's nephew , and now [Master of the Horse]1314-master of the horse , rode first , on a splendid charger , preceded by four trumpets and followed by [[his]6510-the new duke esquires]6584-his esquires ; then came [the court dignitaries]6585-the court dignitaries , attended by [their]6585-the court dignitaries pages and [staffieri in gala liveries]6586-staffieri in gala liveries , [the marshals]6587-the marshals with [their]6587-the marshals staves , [the masters of ceremony]6588-the masters of ceremony , and [the clergy mounted on mules trapped with velvet]6589-the clergy mounted on mules trapped with velvet , each led by [two running footmen]6590-two running footmen . [The Duke]682-the duke rode next , alone and somewhat pale . [Two pages of arms , helmeted and carrying lances]6592-two pages of arms , helmeted and carrying lances , walked at [his]6510-the new duke horse 's bridle ; and behind [him]6510-the new duke came [[his]6510-the new duke household]1173-his household and [ministers]6594-ministers , with [[their]6594-ministers gentlemen]6595-their gentlemen and [a long train of [servants]748-servants]6596-a long train of servants , followed by the regiment of light horse which closed the procession . [The houses surrounding [the square]1592-the square]6598-the houses surrounding the square afforded the best point of view to those unwilling to mix with [the crowd]1568-the crowd in [the streets]744-the streets ; and among [the spectators thronging the windows and balconies , and leaning over the edge of the leads]6602-the spectators thronging the windows and balconies , and leaning over the edge of the leads , were [many who , from one motive or another , felt a personal interest in [the new Duke]6510-the new duke]6603-many who , from one motive or another , felt a personal interest in the new duke . [The Marchioness of Boscofolto]430-boscofolto had accepted a seat in the windows of [the Pievepelaghi palace]6605-the pievepelaghi palace , which formed an angle of [the square]1592-the square , and [she]430-boscofolto and [[her]430-boscofolto hostess]6607-her hostess -- [the same lady who had been relieved of [her]430-boscofolto diamond necklace by footpads suspected of wearing [the Duchess]899-the duchess 's livery]6608-the same lady who had been relieved of her diamond necklace by footpads suspected of wearing the duchess 's livery -- sat observing the scene behind the garlanded balconies of [the piano nobile]6610-the piano nobile . In the mezzanin windows of [a neighbouring wine - shop]6611-a neighbouring wine - shop [[the bookseller]5565-the bookseller [Andreoni]441-andreoni , with half a dozen members of [the philosophical society to which [Odo]234-odo had belonged]6614-the philosophical society to which odo had belonged]6613-the bookseller andreoni , with half a dozen members of the philosophical society to which odo had belonged , peered above the heads of [the crowd thronging the arcade]6615-the crowd thronging the arcade , and through a dormer of the leads [Carlo Gamba]282-gamba , [the assistant in [the ducal library]3754-the ducal library]6616-the assistant in the ducal library , looked out on the triumph of [[his]282-gamba former patron]6618-his former patron . Among the Church dignities grouped about [[his]234-odo Highness]941-his highness was [Father Ignazio]406-father ignazio , [[the late Duke]4180-the late duke 's confessor]6621-the late duke 's confessor , now [Prior of [the Dominicans]422-the dominicans]6622-prior of the dominicans , and said to be withdrawn from political life . Seated on [his]234-odo richly - trapped mule [he]234-odo observed the scene with impassive face ; while from [his]234-odo place in the long line of [minor clergy]6623-minor clergy , [the abate Crescenti , with eyes of infinite tenderness and concern]6624-the abate crescenti , with eyes of infinite tenderness and concern , watched [the young Duke]6625-the young duke solemnly ascending [the Cathedral steps]6626-the cathedral steps . In [the porch]6627-the porch [the Bishop]1234-the bishop waited , impressive as ever in [his]1234-the bishop white and gold dalmatic , against the red robes of [the chapter]6629-the chapter . Preceded by [two chamberlains]6630-two chamberlains [Odo]234-odo mounted the steps amid the sudden silence of [the people]1003-the people . The great bronze portals of [the Cathedral]3023-the cathedral , which were never opened save on occasions of state , swung slowly inward , pouring a wave of music and incense out upon [the hushed sunlit square]6633-the hushed sunlit square ; then [they]6630-two chamberlains closed again , engulphing the brilliant procession -- [the Duke]682-the duke , [the Bishop]1234-the bishop , [the clergy]1929-the clergy and [the court]814-the court -- and leaving [the populace]2736-the populace to scatter in search of the diversions prepared for [them]2736-the populace at [every street - corner]6639-every street - corner . It was not till late that night that [the new Duke]6510-the new duke found [himself]6510-the new duke alone . [He]6510-the new duke had withdrawn at last from the torch - lit balcony overlooking [the square]1592-the square , whither the shouts of [[his]6510-the new duke subjects]8419-his subjects had persistently recalled [him]6510-the new duke . Silence was falling on [the illuminated streets]6643-the illuminated streets , and the dimness of midnight upon the sky through which rocket after rocket had torn its brilliant furrows . In [the palace]768-the palace a profounder stillness reigned . Since [his]6510-the new duke accession [Odo]234-odo , out of respect for [the late Duke]4180-the late duke , had lodged in [one of the wings of [the great building]6647-the great building]6646-one of the wings of the great building ; but tradition demanded that [he]234-odo should henceforth inhabit [the ducal apartments]4349-the ducal apartments , and thither , at the close of the day 's ceremonies , [[his]6510-the new duke gentlemen]6649-his gentlemen had conducted [him]234-odo . [Trescorre]254-trescorre had asked permission to wait on [him]234-odo before [he]234-odo slept ; and [he]234-odo knew that [the prime minister]815-the prime minister would be kept late by [his]234-odo conference with [the secret police , whose nightly report could not be handed in till the festivities were over]6651-the secret police , whose nightly report could not be handed in till the festivities were over . Meanwhile [Odo]234-odo was in no mood for sleep . [He]234-odo sat alone in [the closet]997-the closet , still hung with [saints]6653-saints ' images and jewelled reliquaries , where [[his]234-odo cousin]670-his cousin had so often given [him]234-odo audience , and whence , through the open door , [he]234-odo could see the embroidered curtains and plumed baldachin of the state bed which was presently to receive [him]234-odo . All day [his]234-odo heart had beat with high ambitions ; but now a weight sank upon [his]234-odo spirit . The reaction from the tumultuous welcome of [the streets]744-the streets to the closely - guarded silence of [the palace]768-the palace made [him]234-odo feel how unreal was the fancied union between [himself]234-odo and [[his]234-odo people]1264-his people , how insuperable the distance that tradition and habit had placed between [them]6658-them . In [the narrow closet where [[his]234-odo predecessor]6660-his predecessor had taken refuge from the detested task of reigning]6659-the narrow closet where his predecessor had taken refuge from the detested task of reigning , [the new Duke]6510-the new duke felt the same moral lassitude steal over [him]234-odo . How was such a puny will as [his]234-odo to contend against the great forces of greed and prejudice ? All the influences arrayed against [him]234-odo -- tradition , superstition , the lust of power , the arrogance of race -- seemed concentrated in the atmosphere of [that silent room]6662-that silent room , with [its]6662-that silent room guarded threshold , [its]6662-that silent room pious relics , and lying on the desk in the embrasure of the window , the manuscript litany which [the late Duke]4180-the late duke had not lived to complete . Oppressed by [his]234-odo surroundings , [Odo]234-odo rose and entered [the bed - chamber]6664-the bed - chamber . A lamp burned before the image of [the Madonna]6665-the madonna at the head of the bed , and two lighted flambeaux flanked the picture of the Last Judgment on the opposite wall . [Odo]234-odo remembered the look of terror which [the Duke]682-the duke had fixed on the picture during [their]6658-them first strange conversation . A praying - stool stood beneath [it]6662-that silent room , and it was said that here , rather than before [the Virgin]3925-the virgin 's image , [the melancholy prince]6668-the melancholy prince performed [his]6668-the melancholy prince private devotions . The horrors of the scene were depicted with a childish minuteness of detail , as though [the painter]6669-the painter had sought to produce an impression of moral anguish by the accumulation of physical sufferings ; and just such puerile images of the wrath to come may have haunted the mysterious recesses of [the Duke]682-the duke 's imagination . [Crescenti]234-odo had told [Odo]234-odo how [the dying man]6490-the dying man 's thoughts had seemed to centre upon this dreadful subject , and how again and again , amid [his]234-odo ravings , [he]234-odo had cried out that the picture must be burned , as though the sight of it was become intolerable to [him]234-odo . [Odo]234-odo 's own mind , across which the events and emotions of the day still threw the fantastic shadows of an expiring illumination , was wrought to the highest state of impressionability . [He]234-odo saw in a flash all that the picture must have symbolised to [[his]234-odo cousin]670-his cousin 's fancy ; and in [his]234-odo desire to reconstruct that dying vision of fleshly retribution , [he]234-odo stepped close to the diptych , resting a knee on the stool beneath it . As [he]234-odo did so , the picture suddenly opened , disclosing the inner panel . [Odo]234-odo caught up one of the flambeaux , and in its light , as on a sunlit wave , there stepped forth to [him]234-odo the lost Venus of [Giorgione]427-giorgione . [He]234-odo knew the picture in an instant . There was no mistaking the glow of the limbs , the midsummer languor of the smile , the magical atmosphere in which the gold of sunlight , of autumn leaves , of amber grapes , seemed fused by some lost alchemy of the brush . As [he]234-odo gazed , the scene changed , and [he]234-odo saw [himself]234-odo in [a darkened room with cabalistic hangings]6673-a darkened room with cabalistic hangings . [He]234-odo saw [Heiligenstern]397-heiligenstern 's tall figure , towering in supernatural light , [the Duke]682-the duke leaning eagerly forward , [the Duchess with set lips and troubled eyes]6675-the duchess with set lips and troubled eyes , [the little prince]3148-the little prince bent wonderingly above the magic crystal ... A step in the antechamber announced [Trescorre]254-trescorre 's approach . [Odo]234-odo returned to the cabinet and [the minister]4767-the minister advanced with a low bow . [The two men]6359-the two men had had time to grow accustomed to the new relation in which [they]6359-the two men stood to [one another]6679-one another , yet there were moments when , to [Odo]234-odo , the past seemed to lie like fallen leaves beneath [Trescorre]254-trescorre 's steps -- [Donna Laura]243-donna laura , fond and foolish in [her]243-donna laura weeds , [Gamba]282-gamba , [Momola]241-momola , and [the pure featherhead Cerveno]6680-the pure featherhead cerveno , dying at nineteen of a distemper because [he]254-trescorre had stood in the other 's way . The impression was strong on [him]234-odo now -- but it was only momentary . Habit reasserted itself , and [the minister]4767-the minister effaced [the man]1626-the man . [Odo]234-odo signed to [Trescorre]254-trescorre to seat [himself]234-odo and [the latter]870-the latter silently presented [his]870-the latter report . [He]870-the latter was [a diligent and capable administrator]6684-a diligent and capable administrator , and however mixed might be the motives which attached [him]870-the latter to [[his]870-the latter sovereign]928-his sovereign , they did not interfere with the exact performance of [his]870-the latter duties . [Odo]234-odo knew this and was grateful for it . [He]234-odo knew that [Trescorre]254-trescorre , [ambitious of [the regency]9876-the regency]6686-ambitious of the regency , had intrigued against [him]234-odo to the last . [He]234-odo knew that an intemperate love of power was the mainspring of that seemingly dispassionate nature . But death had crossed [Trescorre]254-trescorre 's schemes ; and [he]234-odo was too adroit [an opportunist]6688-an opportunist not to see that [his]234-odo best chance now lay in making [himself]234-odo indispensable to [[his]234-odo new sovereign]6689-his new sovereign . Of all this [Odo]234-odo was aware ; but [his]234-odo own motives in appointing [Trescorre]254-trescorre did not justify [his]234-odo looking for great disinterestedness in [[his]234-odo minister]6690-his minister . The irony of circumstances had forced [them]6691-them upon each other , and [each]6223-each knew that [the other]905-the other understood the situation and was prepared to make the best of it . [The Duke]682-the duke presently rose , and handed back to [Trescorre]254-trescorre the reports of [the secret police]6695-the secret police . [They]6696-they were the documents [he]254-trescorre most disliked to handle . " [You]254-trescorre have acquitted [yourself]254-trescorre admirably of [your]254-trescorre disagreeable duties , "[254-trescorre] [he]254-trescorre said with a smile . " [I]254-trescorre hope [I]254-trescorre have done as well . At any rate the day is over . "[254-trescorre] [Trescorre]254-trescorre returned the smile , with [his]254-trescorre usual tinge of irony . " [Another]9912-another has already begun , "[254-trescorre] said [he]254-trescorre . " Ah , "[234-odo] said [Odo]234-odo , with a touch of impatience , " are [we]9913-we not to sleep on [our]9913-we laurels ? "[234-odo] [Trescorre]254-trescorre bowed . " [Austria]100-austria , [[your]254-trescorre Highness]8397-your highness , never sleeps . "[254-trescorre] [Odo]234-odo looked at [him]254-trescorre with surprise . " What do [you]254-trescorre mean ? "[234-odo] " That [I]234-odo have to remind [[your]254-trescorre Highness--]9915-your highness-- "[234-odo] " Of what-- ? "[254-trescorre] [Trescorre]254-trescorre had one of [his]254-trescorre characteristic pauses . " That [the Duke of [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro]9388-the duke of monte alloro is in failing health -- and that [her]9388-the duke of monte alloro Highness 's year of widowhood ended yesterday . "[254-trescorre] There was a silence . [Odo]234-odo , who had reseated [himself]234-odo , rose and walked to the window . The shutters stood open and [he]234-odo looked out over the formless obscurity of [the gardens]8159-the gardens . Above the intervening masses of foliage [the Borromini wing]6698-the borromini wing raised [its]6698-the borromini wing vague grey bulk . [He]234-odo saw lights in [[Maria Clementina]413-maria clementina 's apartments]6699-maria clementina 's apartments and wondered if [she]413-maria clementina still waked . An hour or two earlier [she]413-maria clementina had given [him]234-odo [her]413-maria clementina hand in the contra - dance at the state ball . It was [her]413-maria clementina first public appearance since [the late Duke]4180-the late duke 's death , and with the laying off of [her]413-maria clementina weeds [she]413-maria clementina had regained something of [her]413-maria clementina former brilliancy . At the moment [he]234-odo had hardly observed [her]413-maria clementina : [she]413-maria clementina had seemed a mere inanimate part of the pageant of which [he]234-odo formed the throbbing centre . But now the sense of [her]413-maria clementina nearness pressed upon [him]234-odo . [She]413-maria clementina seemed close to [him]234-odo , ingrown with [his]234-odo fate ; and with the curious duality of vision that belongs to such moments [he]234-odo beheld [her]413-maria clementina again as [she]413-maria clementina had first shone on [him]234-odo -- [the imperious child whom [he]234-odo had angered by stroking [her]413-maria clementina spaniel]6701-the imperious child whom he had angered by stroking her spaniel , [the radiant girl who had welcomed [him]234-odo on [his]234-odo return to [Pianura]4-pianura]6702-the radiant girl who had welcomed him on his return to pianura . [Trescorre]254-trescorre 's voice aroused [him]234-odo . " At any moment , "[4767-the minister] [the minister]4767-the minister was saying , " [[her]413-maria clementina Highness]8209-her highness may fall heir to [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro . It is the moment for which [Austria]100-austria waits . There is always [an Archduke]9918-an archduke ready -- and [[her]413-maria clementina Highness]8209-her highness is still [a young woman]9920-a young woman . "[4767-the minister] [Odo]234-odo turned slowly from the window . " [I]234-odo have told [you]234-odo that this is impossible , "[234-odo] [he]234-odo murmured . [Trescorre]254-trescorre looked down and thoughtfully fingered the documents in [his]254-trescorre hands . " [[Your]234-odo Highness]8397-your highness , "[4767-the minister] said [he]4767-the minister , " is as well - acquainted as [[your]234-odo ministers]9922-your ministers with the difficulties that beset [us]9923-us . [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro is [one of the richest states in [Italy]5-italy]9924-one of the richest states in italy . It is a pity to alienate such revenues from [Pianura]4-pianura . "[4767-the minister] [The new Duke]6510-the new duke was silent . [[His]6510-the new duke minister]6690-his minister 's words were merely the audible expression of [his]6510-the new duke own thoughts . [He]6510-the new duke knew that the future welfare of [Pianura]4-pianura depended on the annexation of [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro . [He]6510-the new duke owed it to [[his]6510-the new duke people]1264-his people to unite [the two sovereignties]6707-the two sovereignties . At length [he]6510-the new duke said : " [You]254-trescorre are building on an unwarrantable assumption . "[6510-the new duke] [Trescorre]254-trescorre raised an interrogative glance . " [You]254-trescorre assume [her]9925-her Highness 's consent . "[4767-the minister] [The minister]4767-the minister again paused ; and [his]4767-the minister pause seemed to flash an ironical light on the poverty of the other 's defences . " [I]4767-the minister come straight from [[her]9925-her Highness]8209-her highness , "[4767-the minister] said [he]4767-the minister quietly , " and [I]4767-the minister assume nothing that [I]4767-the minister am not in a position to affirm . "[4767-the minister] [Odo]234-odo turned on [him]4767-the minister with a start . " Do [I]234-odo understand that [you]4767-the minister have presumed-- ? "[234-odo] [[His]234-odo minister]6690-his minister raised a deprecating hand . " [Sir]8257-sir , "[6690-his minister] said [he]6690-his minister , " [[the Archduke]9928-the archduke 's envoy]9929-the archduke 's envoy is in [Pianura]4-pianura . "[6690-his minister] 4.2 . [Odo]234-odo , on [his]234-odo return to [Pianura]4-pianura , had taken it for granted that [de Crucis]462-de crucis would remain in [his]234-odo service . There had been little talk between [the two]812-the two on the way . [The one]6711-the one was deep in [his]6711-the one own wretchedness , and [the other]905-the other had too fine a tact to intrude on it ; but [Odo]234-odo felt the nearness of that penetrating sympathy which was almost a gift of divination . [He]234-odo was glad to have [de Crucis]462-de crucis at [his]234-odo side at a moment when any other companionship had been intolerable ; and in the egotism of [his]234-odo misery [he]234-odo imagined that [he]234-odo could dispose as [he]234-odo pleased of [[his]234-odo friend]2124-his friend 's future . After [the little Prince]3148-the little prince 's death , however , [de Crucis]462-de crucis had at once asked permission to leave [Pianura]4-pianura . [He]462-de crucis was perhaps not displeased by [Odo]234-odo 's expressions of surprise and disappointment ; but they did not alter [his]462-de crucis decision . [He]462-de crucis reminded [the new Duke]6510-the new duke that [he]462-de crucis had been called to [Pianura]4-pianura as [governor to [the late heir]6717-the late heir]6716-governor to the late heir , and that , death having cut short [his]462-de crucis task , [he]462-de crucis had now no farther pretext for remaining . [Odo]234-odo listened with a strange sense of loneliness . The responsibilities of [his]234-odo new state weighed heavily on the musing speculative side of [his]234-odo nature . Face to face with the sudden summons to action , with the necessity for prompt and not too - curious choice of means and method , [he]234-odo felt a stealing apathy of the will , an inclination toward the subtle duality of judgment that had so often weakened and diffused [his]234-odo energies . At such a crisis it seemed to [him]234-odo that , [de Crucis]462-de crucis gone , [he]234-odo remained without [a friend]8895-a friend . [He]234-odo urged [the abate]624-the abate to reconsider [his]234-odo decision , begging [him]624-the abate to choose a post about [[his]234-odo person]6508-his person . [De Crucis]462-de crucis shook [his]462-de crucis head . " The offer , "[462-de crucis] said [he]462-de crucis , " is more tempting to [me]462-de crucis than [[your]624-the abate Highness]8397-your highness can guess ; but [my]462-de crucis business [here]8091-here is at an end , and must be taken up elsewhere . [My]462-de crucis calling is that of [a pedagogue]9543-a pedagogue . When [I]462-de crucis was summoned to take charge of [Prince Ferrante]414-prince ferrante 's education [I]462-de crucis gave up [my]462-de crucis position in [the household of [Prince Bracciano]464-prince bracciano]9933-the household of prince bracciano not only because [I]462-de crucis believed that [I]462-de crucis could make [myself]462-de crucis more useful in training [a future sovereign]9934-a future sovereign than [the son of [a private nobleman]9936-a private nobleman]9935-the son of a private nobleman , but also , "[462-de crucis] [he]462-de crucis added with a smile , " because [I]462-de crucis was curious to visit a state of which [[your]624-the abate Highness]8397-your highness had so often spoken , and because [I]462-de crucis believed that [[my]462-de crucis residence [here]8091-here]9938-my residence here might enable [me]462-de crucis to be of service to [[your]624-the abate Highness]8397-your highness . In this [I]462-de crucis was not mistaken ; and [I]462-de crucis will gladly remain in [Pianura]4-pianura long enough to give [[your]624-the abate Highness]8397-your highness such counsels as [my]462-de crucis experience suggests ; but that business discharged , [I]462-de crucis must ask leave to go . "[462-de crucis] From this position [no entreaties]6721-no entreaties could move [him]462-de crucis ; and so fixed was [his]462-de crucis resolve that it confirmed the idea that [he]462-de crucis was still [a secret agent of [the Jesuits]2221-the jesuits]6722-a secret agent of the jesuits . Strangely enough , this did not prejudice [Odo]234-odo , who was more than ever under the spell of [de Crucis]462-de crucis 's personal influence . Though [Odo]234-odo had been acquainted with [many professed philosophers]6724-many professed philosophers [he]234-odo had never met among [them]6724-many professed philosophers [a character so nearly resembling the old stoical ideal of temperance and serenity]6725-a character so nearly resembling the old stoical ideal of temperance and serenity , and [he]234-odo could never be long with [de Crucis]462-de crucis without reflecting that the training which could form and nourish so noble a nature must be other than [the world]844-the world conceived it . [De Crucis]462-de crucis , however , frankly pointed out that [his]462-de crucis former connection with [the Jesuits]336-the jesuits was too well known in [Pianura]4-pianura not to be an obstacle in the way of [his]462-de crucis usefulness . " [I]462-de crucis own , "[462-de crucis] said [he]462-de crucis , " that before [the late Duke]4180-the late duke 's death [I]462-de crucis exerted such influence as [I]462-de crucis possessed to bring about [[your]9943-your Highness]8397-your highness 's appointment as [regent]9833-regent ; but the very connections that favoured [me]462-de crucis with [[your]9943-your predecessor]9946-your predecessor must stand in the way of [my]462-de crucis serving [[your]9943-your Highness]8397-your highness . Nothing could be more fatal to [your]9943-your prospects than to have it said that [you]9943-your had chosen [a former Jesuit]9948-a former jesuit as [[your]9943-your advisor]9949-your advisor . In the present juncture of affairs it is needful that [you]9943-your should appear to be in sympathy with [the liberals]9304-the liberals , and that whatever reforms [you]9943-your attempt should seem the result of popular pressure rather than of [your]9943-your own free choice . Such an attitude may not flatter [the sovereign]1435-the sovereign 's pride , and is in fact merely a higher form of expediency ; but it is one which [the proudest monarchs of [Europe]40-europe]9952-the proudest monarchs of europe are finding [themselves]9952-the proudest monarchs of europe constrained to take if [they]9952-the proudest monarchs of europe would preserve [their]9952-the proudest monarchs of europe power and use it effectually . "[462-de crucis] Soon afterward [de Crucis]462-de crucis left [Pianura]4-pianura ; but before leaving [he]462-de crucis imparted to [Odo]234-odo the result of [his]462-de crucis observations while in [the late Duke]4180-the late duke 's service . [De Crucis]462-de crucis 's view was that of [the more thoughtful men of [his]462-de crucis day who had not broken with [the Church]72-the church , yet were conscious that the whole social system of [Europe]40-europe]6728-the more thoughtful men of his day who had not broken with the church , yet were conscious that the whole social system of europe was in need of renovation . The movement of ideas in [France]22-france , and [their]6729-their rapid transformation into legislative measures of unforeseen importance , had as yet made little impression in [Italy]5-italy ; and [the clergy]1929-the clergy in particular lived in serene unconsciousness of any impending change . [De Crucis]462-de crucis , however , had been much in [France]22-france , and had frequented [the French churchmen]6731-the french churchmen , who ( save in [the highest ranks of the hierarchy]6732-the highest ranks of the hierarchy ) were keenly alive to the need of reform , and ready , in many instances , to sacrifice [their]6731-the french churchmen own privileges in the public cause . [These men]6733-these men , living in [[their]6733-these men provincial cures or [abbeys]6735-abbeys]6734-their provincial cures or abbeys , were necessarily in closer contact with [the people]1003-the people , better acquainted with [their]1003-the people needs and more competent to relieve [them]1003-the people , than the city demagogues theorising in [Parisian coffee - houses]6737-parisian coffee - houses on the Rights of [Man]511-man and the Code of Nature . But the voice of [the demagogues]6738-the demagogues carried farther than that of [the clergy]1929-the clergy ; and such revolutionary notions as crossed [the Alps]20-the alps had more to do with the founding of future Utopias than with the remedy of present evils . Even in [France]22-france the temperate counsels of [the clergy]1929-the clergy were being overruled by the sentimental imprudences of [the nobles]2190-the nobles and by the bluster of [the politicians]6742-the politicians . It was to put [Odo]234-odo on [his]234-odo guard against these two influences that [de Crucis]462-de crucis was chiefly anxious ; but the intelligent cooperation of [the clergy]1929-the clergy was sadly lacking in [his]462-de crucis administrative scheme . [He]462-de crucis knew that [Odo]234-odo could not count on the support of [the Church party]8954-the church party , and that [he]234-odo must make what use [he]234-odo could of [the liberals]9304-the liberals in [his]234-odo attempts at reform . [The clergy of [Pianura]4-pianura]6746-the clergy of pianura had been in power too long to believe in the necessity of conceding anything to the new spirit ; and since the banishment of [the Society of [Jesus]264-christ]9028-the society of jesus the presumption of the other orders had increased instead of diminishing . [The priests]8974-the priests , whatever [their]8974-the priests failings , had attached [the needy]6749-the needy by a lavish bounty ; and [they]8974-the priests had [a powerful auxiliary in [the Madonna of [the Mountain]98-the mountain]197-the madonna of the mountain , who drew [pilgrims]6751-pilgrims from [all parts of [Italy]5-italy]5093-all parts of italy and thus contributed to the material welfare of [the state]2921-the state as well as to its spiritual privileges]6750-a powerful auxiliary in the madonna of the mountain , who drew pilgrims from all parts of italy and thus contributed to the material welfare of the state as well as to its spiritual privileges . To [the common people]6754-the common people [their]6754-the common people Virgin was not only a protection against disease and famine , but a kind of oracle , who by divers signs and tokens gave evidence of divine approval or displeasure ; and it was naturally to [the priests]8974-the priests that [the faithful]8704-the faithful looked for a reading of these phenomena . This gave [the clergy]1929-the clergy a powerful hold on the religious sensibilities of [the people]1003-the people ; and more than once the manifest disapproval of [the Mountain Madonna]6759-the mountain madonna had turned the scales against some economic measure which threatened the rights of [[her]6759-the mountain madonna augurs]6760-her augurs . [De Crucis]462-de crucis understood the force of these traditional influences ; but [Odo]234-odo , in common with [the more cultivated men of [his]234-odo day]6761-the more cultivated men of his day , had lived too long in an atmosphere of polite scepticism to measure the profound hold of religion on the consciousness of [the people]1003-the people . [Christ]264-christ had been so long banished from [the drawing - room]2757-the drawing - room that it was has hard to believe that [He]264-christ still ruled in [field and vineyard]6764-field and vineyard . To [men of [Odo]234-odo]6252-men of odo 's stamp the piety of [the masses]6766-the masses was a mere superficial growth , a kind of mental mould to be dried off by the first beams of knowledge . [He]234-odo did not conceive it as a habit of thought so old that it had become instinctive , so closely intertwined with every sense that to hope to eradicate it was like trying to drain all the blood from [a man]8112-a man 's body without killing [him]8112-a man . [He]234-odo knew nothing of the unwearied workings of that power , patient as a natural force , which , to reach spirits darkened by ignorance and eyes dulled by toil , had stooped to a thousand disguises , humble , tender and grotesque -- peopling the earth with a new race of avenging or protecting deities , guarding the babe in the cradle and the cattle in [the stalls]1069-the stalls , blessing [the good man]6769-the good man 's vineyard or blighting the crops of [the blasphemer]6770-the blasphemer , guiding [the lonely traveller]6771-the lonely traveller over torrents and precipices , smoothing [the sea]5255-the sea and hushing the whirlwind , praying with [the mother]584-the mother over [[her]584-the mother sick child]6774-her sick child , and watching beside the dead in [plague - house]6775-plague - house and lazaret and galley -- entering into every joy and grief of the obscurest consciousness , penetrating to depths of misery which no human compassion ever reached , and redressing by a prompt and summary justice wrongs of which no human legislation took account . [Odo]234-odo 's first act after [his]234-odo accession had been to recall [the political offenders banished by [[his]234-odo predecessor]6660-his predecessor]6776-the political offenders banished by his predecessor ; and so general was the custom of marking the opening of a new reign by an amnesty to [political exiles]6778-political exiles , that [Trescorre]254-trescorre offered no opposition to the measure . [Andreoni]441-andreoni and [[his]441-andreoni friends]2637-his friends at once returned to [Pianura]4-pianura , and [Gamba]282-gamba at the same time emerged from [his]282-gamba mysterious hiding - place . [He]282-gamba was [the only one of the group who struck [Odo]234-odo as having any administrative capacity]6780-the only one of the group who struck odo as having any administrative capacity ; yet [he]282-gamba was more likely to be of use as [a pamphleteer]6781-a pamphleteer than as [an office - holder]6782-an office - holder . As to [the other philosophers]6783-the other philosophers , [they]6783-the other philosophers were what [their]6783-the other philosophers name implied : [thoughtful and high - minded men , with a generous conception of [their]6783-the other philosophers civic duties]6784-thoughtful and high - minded men , with a generous conception of their civic duties , and a noble readiness to fulfil [them]6783-the other philosophers at any cost , but untrained to action , and totally ignorant of the complex science of government . [Odo]234-odo found [the hunchback]8158-the hunchback changed . [He]234-odo had withered like [Trescorre]254-trescorre , but under the harsher blight of physical privations ; and [his]234-odo tongue had an added bitterness . [He]234-odo replied evasively to all enquiries as to what had become of [him]234-odo during [his]234-odo absence from [Pianura]4-pianura ; but on [Odo]234-odo 's asking for news of [Momola]241-momola and [the child]686-the child [he]234-odo said coldly : " [They]6783-the other philosophers are both dead . "[234-odo] " Dead ? "[234-odo] [Odo]234-odo exclaimed . " Together ? "[234-odo] " There was scarce an hour between [them]6783-the other philosophers , "[282-gamba] [Gamba]282-gamba answered . " [She]241-momola said [she]241-momola must keep alive as long as [the boy]839-the boy needed [her]241-momola -- after that [she]241-momola turned on [her]241-momola side and died . "[282-gamba] " But of what disorder ? How came [they]6783-the other philosophers to sicken at the same time ? "[8158-the hunchback] [The hunchback]8158-the hunchback stood silent , [his]8158-the hunchback eyes on the ground . Suddenly [he]8158-the hunchback raised them and looked full at [the Duke]682-the duke . " Those that saw [them]6783-the other philosophers called it the plague . "[8158-the hunchback] " The plague ? Good [God]249-god ! "[234-odo] [Odo]234-odo slowly returned [his]234-odo stare . " Is it possible-- "[234-odo] [he]234-odo paused--"that [she]241-momola too was at the feast of the Madonna ? "[234-odo] " [She]241-momola was [there]606-there , but it was not there that [she]241-momola contracted the distemper . "[234-odo] " Not there-- ? "[234-odo] " No ; for [she]241-momola dragged [herself]241-momola from [her]241-momola bed to go . "[234-odo] There was another silence . [The hunchback]8158-the hunchback had lowered [his]8158-the hunchback eyes . [The Duke]682-the duke sat motionless , resting [his]682-the duke head on [his]682-the duke hand . Suddenly [he]682-the duke made a gesture of dismissal ... Two months after [his]682-the duke state entry into [Pianura]4-pianura [Odo]234-odo married [[[his]234-odo cousin]670-his cousin 's widow]6792-his cousin 's widow . It surprised [him]682-the duke , in looking back , to see how completely the thought of [Maria Clementina]413-maria clementina had passed out of [his]682-the duke life , how wholly [he]682-the duke had ceased to reckon with [her]413-maria clementina as one of the factors in [his]682-the duke destiny . At [[her]6792-his cousin 's widow child]9171-her child 's death - bed [he]682-the duke had seen in [her]6792-his cousin 's widow only [the stricken mother]6794-the stricken mother , centred in [her]6792-his cousin 's widow loss , and recalling , in an agony of tears , [the little prince]3148-the little prince 's prophetic vision of [the winged playmates who came to [him]682-the duke carrying toys from [Paradise]198-paradise]6796-the winged playmates who came to him carrying toys from paradise . After [Prince Ferrante]414-prince ferrante 's death [she]6792-his cousin 's widow had gone on a long visit to [[her]6792-his cousin 's widow uncle of [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro]6797-her uncle of monte alloro ; and since [her]6792-his cousin 's widow return to [Pianura]4-pianura [she]6792-his cousin 's widow had lived in [the dower - house]6480-the dower - house , refusing [Odo]234-odo 's offer of [a palace in [the town]593-the town]6799-a palace in the town . [She]6792-his cousin 's widow had first shown [herself]6792-his cousin 's widow to [the public]4018-the public on the day of the state entry ; and now , [her]6792-his cousin 's widow year of widowhood over , [she]6792-his cousin 's widow was again [the consort of [a reigning Duke of [Pianura]4-pianura]6803-a reigning duke of pianura]6802-the consort of a reigning duke of pianura . [No one]725-no one was more ignorant than [[her]6792-his cousin 's widow husband]1112-her husband of the motives determining [her]6792-his cousin 's widow act . As [Duchess of [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro]6806-duchess of monte alloro [she]6792-his cousin 's widow might have enjoyed the wealth and independence which [[her]6792-his cousin 's widow uncle]9184-her uncle 's death had bestowed on [her]6792-his cousin 's widow , but in marrying again [she]6792-his cousin 's widow resigned the right to [her]6792-his cousin 's widow new possessions , which became vested in the crown of [Pianura]4-pianura . Was it love that had prompted the sacrifice ? As [she]6792-his cousin 's widow stood beside [him]1112-her husband on the altar steps of [the Cathedral]3023-the cathedral , as [she]6792-his cousin 's widow rode [home]1346-home beside [him]1112-her husband between [[their]6810-their shouting subjects]6811-their shouting subjects , [Odo]234-odo asked [himself]234-odo the question again and again . The years had dealt lightly with [her]6792-his cousin 's widow , and [she]6792-his cousin 's widow had crossed the threshold of the thirties with the assured step of [a woman who has no cause to fear what awaits [her]6792-his cousin 's widow]6812-a woman who has no cause to fear what awaits her . But [her]6792-his cousin 's widow blood no longer spoke [her]6792-his cousin 's widow thoughts , and the transparence of youth had changed to a brilliant density . [He]234-odo could not penetrate beneath the surface of [her]6792-his cousin 's widow smile : [she]6792-his cousin 's widow seemed to [him]1112-her husband like a beautiful toy which might conceal a lacerating weapon . Meanwhile between [himself]234-odo and any better understanding of [her]6792-his cousin 's widow stood the remembrance of [their]6810-their talk in [the hunting - lodge of [Pontesordo]2-pontesordo]1708-the hunting - lodge of pontesordo . What [she]6792-his cousin 's widow had offered then [he]234-odo had refused to take : was [she]6792-his cousin 's widow [the woman to forget such a refusal]6814-the woman to forget such a refusal ? Was it not rather to keep [its]6815-its memory alive that [she]6792-his cousin 's widow had married [him]234-odo ? Or was [she]6792-his cousin 's widow but [the flighty girl [he]234-odo had once imagined [her]6792-his cousin 's widow]6816-the flighty girl he had once imagined her , driven hither and thither by spasmodic impulses , and incapable of consistent action , whether for good or ill ? The barrier of [their]6810-their past -- of all that lay unsaid and undone between [them]6810-their -- so completely cut [her]6792-his cousin 's widow off from [him]234-odo that [he]234-odo had , in [her]6792-his cousin 's widow presence , the strange sensation of [a man who believes [himself]234-odo to be alone yet feels that [he]234-odo is watched ... The first months of [their]6810-their marriage]6817-a man who believes himself to be alone yet feels that he is watched ... the first months of their marriage were oppressed by this sense of constraint ; but gradually habit bridged the distance between [them]6810-their and [he]234-odo found [himself]234-odo at once nearer to [her]6792-his cousin 's widow and less acutely aware of [her]6792-his cousin 's widow . In the second year [an heir]6818-an heir was born and died ; and the hopes and grief thus shared drew [them]6810-their insensibly into the relation of [the ordinary husband]6819-the ordinary husband and [wife]6820-wife , knitted together at the roots in spite of superficial divergencies . In [his]234-odo passionate need of sympathy and counsel [Odo]234-odo longed to make the most of this enforced community of interests . Already [his]234-odo first zeal was flagging , [his]234-odo belief in [his]234-odo mission wavering : [he]234-odo needed the encouragement of a kindred faith . [He]234-odo had no hope of finding in [Maria Clementina]413-maria clementina that pure passion for justice which seemed to [him]234-odo the noblest ardour of the soul . [He]234-odo had read it in [one woman]6821-one woman 's eyes , but these had long been turned from [him]234-odo . Unconsciously perhaps [he]234-odo counted rather on [[his]234-odo wife]1713-his wife 's less generous qualities : the passion for dominion , the blind arrogance of temper that , for the mere pleasure of making [her]6792-his cousin 's widow power felt , had so often drawn [her]6792-his cousin 's widow into public affairs . Might not this waste force -- which implied , after all , a certain prodigality of courage -- be used for good as well as evil ? Might not [his]234-odo influence make of the undisciplined creature at [his]234-odo side an unconscious instrument in the great work of order and reconstruction ? [His]234-odo first appeal to [her]6792-his cousin 's widow brought the answer . At [his]234-odo request [[his]234-odo ministers]8730-his ministers had drawn up a plan of financial reorganisation , which should include the two duchies ; for [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro , though wealthier than [Pianura]290-pianura , was in even greater need of fiscal reform . As a first step towards replenishing the treasury [the Duke]682-the duke had declared [himself]682-the duke ready to limit [his]682-the duke private expenditure to a fixed sum ; and [he]682-the duke now asked [the Duchess]899-the duchess to pledge [herself]899-the duchess in the same manner . [Maria Clementina]413-maria clementina , since [[her]413-maria clementina uncle]9184-her uncle 's death , had been in receipt of a third of the annual revenues of [Monte Alloro]99-monte alloro . This should have enabled [her]413-maria clementina to pay [her]413-maria clementina debts and put some dignity and order into [her]413-maria clementina establishment ; but the first year 's income had gone in the building of [a villa]5264-a villa on [the Piana]94-the piana , in imitation of [the country - seats along [the Brenta]149-the brenta]6828-the country - seats along the brenta ; the second was spent in establishing a menagerie of wild animals like that of [the French Queen at [Versailles]28-versailles]6829-the french queen at versailles ; and rumour had it that [the Duchess]899-the duchess carried [her]899-the duchess imitation of [[her]899-the duchess royal cousin]6831-her royal cousin so far as to be involved in an ugly quarrel with [[her]899-the duchess jewellers]6832-her jewellers about a necklace for which [she]899-the duchess owed a thousand ducats . All these reports had of course reached [Odo]234-odo ; but [he]234-odo still hoped that an appeal to [her]899-the duchess love of dominion might prove stronger than the habit of self - indulgence . [He]234-odo said to [himself]234-odo that nothing had ever been done to rouse [her]899-the duchess ambition , that hitherto , if [she]899-the duchess had meddled in politics , it had been merely from thwarted vanity or the desire to gratify some personal spite . Now [he]234-odo hoped to take [her]899-the duchess by higher passions , and by associating [her]899-the duchess with [his]234-odo own schemes to utilise [her]899-the duchess dormant energies . For the first moments [she]899-the duchess listened with the strained fixity of [a child]1186-a child ; then [her]899-the duchess attention flickered and died out . The life - long habit of referring every question to a personal standpoint made it difficult for [her]899-the duchess to follow a general argument , and [she]899-the duchess leaned back with the resigned eyelids of piety under the pulpit . [Odo]234-odo , resolved to be patient , and seeing that the subject was too large for [her]899-the duchess , tried to take it apart , putting it before [her]899-the duchess bit by bit , and at such an angle that [she]899-the duchess should catch [her]899-the duchess own reflection in it . [He]234-odo thought to take [her]899-the duchess by the [Austrian]199-austrian side , touching on the well - known antagonism between [Vienna]73-vienna and [Rome]11-rome , on the reforms of [the Tuscan Grand - Duke]6834-the tuscan grand - duke , on the Emperor [Joseph]512-joseph 's open defiance of [the Church]1212-the church 's feudal claims . But [she]899-the duchess scented a personal application . " [[My]899-the duchess cousin]9817-my cousin [the Emperor]9956-the emperor should be [a priest]592-a priest [himself]9956-the emperor , "[899-the duchess] [she]899-the duchess shrugged , " for [he]9956-the emperor belongs to [the preaching order]9958-the preaching order . [He]9956-the emperor never goes to [France]22-france but [he]9956-the emperor gives [the poor Queen]9959-the poor queen such a scolding that [her]9959-the poor queen eyes are red for a week . Has [Joseph]512-joseph been trying to set [[our]9960-our house]9030-our house in order ? "[899-the duchess] Discouraged , but more than ever bent on patience , [he]512-joseph tried the chord of vanity , of [her]899-the duchess love of popularity . [The people]1003-the people called [her]899-the duchess the beautiful [Duchess]419-duchess -- why not let history name [her]899-the duchess the great ? But the mention of history was unfortunate . It reminded [her]899-the duchess of [her]899-the duchess lesson - books , and of the stupid Greeks and Romans , whose dates [she]899-the duchess could never recall . [She]899-the duchess hoped [she]899-the duchess should never be anything so dull as [an historical personage]6837-an historical personage ! And besides , greatness was for [the men]6838-the men -- it was enough for [a princess]6839-a princess to be virtuous . And [she]899-the duchess looked as edifying as [her]899-the duchess own epitaph . [He]512-joseph caught this up and tried to make [her]899-the duchess distinguish between [the public]4018-the public and the private virtues . But the word " responsibility "[512-joseph] slipped from [him]512-joseph and [he]512-joseph felt [her]899-the duchess stiffen . This was preaching , and [she]899-the duchess hated preaching even more than history . [Her]899-the duchess attention strayed again and [he]512-joseph rallied [his]512-joseph forces in a last appeal . But [he]512-joseph knew it was a lost battle : every argument broke against the close front of [her]899-the duchess indifference . [He]512-joseph was talking a language [she]899-the duchess had never learned -- it was all as remote from [her]899-the duchess as Church Latin . [A princess]6839-a princess did not need to know Latin . [She]899-the duchess let [her]899-the duchess eye linger suggestively on the clock . It was a fine hunting morning , and [she]899-the duchess had meant to kill a stag in [the Caccia del Vescovo]200-the caccia del vescovo . When [he]512-joseph began to sum up , and the question narrowed to a direct appeal , [her]899-the duchess eyes left the clock and returned to [him]512-joseph . Now [she]899-the duchess was listening . [He]512-joseph pressed on to the matter of retrenchment . Would [she]899-the duchess join [him]512-joseph , would [she]899-the duchess help to make the great work possible ? At first [she]899-the duchess seemed hardly to understand ; but as [his]512-joseph meaning grew clear to her--"Is the money no longer [ours]9962-ours ? "[899-the duchess] [she]899-the duchess exclaimed . [He]512-joseph hesitated . " [I]512-joseph suppose it is as much ours as ever , "[512-joseph] [he]512-joseph said . " And how much is that ? "[899-the duchess] [she]899-the duchess asked impatiently . " It is [ours]9962-ours as a trust for [[our]9962-ours people]9963-our people . "[899-the duchess] [She]899-the duchess stared in honest wonder . These were new signs in [her]899-the duchess heaven . " A trust ? A trust ? [I]512-joseph am not sure that [I]512-joseph know what that means . Is the money [ours]9962-ours or [theirs]9963-our people ? "[512-joseph] [He]512-joseph hesitated . " In strict honour , it is [ours]9962-ours only as long as [we]9962-ours spend it for [their]9963-our people benefit . "[512-joseph] [She]899-the duchess turned aside to examine an enamelled patch - box by [Van Blarenberghe]247-vanna which [the court jeweller]6842-the court jeweller had newly received from [Paris]27-paris . When [she]899-the duchess raised [her]899-the duchess eyes [she]899-the duchess said : " And if [we]9962-ours do not spend it for [their]9963-our people benefit-- ? "[899-the duchess] [Odo]234-odo glanced about [the room]782-the room . [He]234-odo looked at the delicate adornment of the walls , the curtains of Lyons damask , the crystal girandoles , the toys in porcelain of [Saxony]201-saxony and Sevres , in bronze and ivory and Chinese lacquer , crowding the tables and cabinets of inlaid wood . Overhead floated a rosy allegory by [Luca Giordano]513-luca giordano ; underfoot lay a carpet of [the royal manufactory of [France]22-france]6844-the royal manufactory of france ; and through the open windows [he]512-joseph heard the plash of the garden fountains and saw the alignment of the long green alleys set with the statues of [Roman patriots]6845-roman patriots . " Then , "[512-joseph] said [he]512-joseph -- and the words sounded strangely in [his]512-joseph own ears--"then [they]9963-our people may take it from [us]9962-ours some day -- and all this with it , to the very toy [you]899-the duchess are playing with . "[899-the duchess] [She]899-the duchess rose , and from [her]899-the duchess fullest height dropped a brilliant smile on [him]512-joseph ; then [her]899-the duchess eyes turned to the portrait of [the great fighting Duke set in the monumental stucchi of the chimney - piece]6846-the great fighting duke set in the monumental stucchi of the chimney - piece . " If [you]512-joseph take after [[your]512-joseph ancestors]9964-your ancestors [you]512-joseph will know how to defend [it]9964-your ancestors , "[899-the duchess] [she]899-the duchess said . 4.3 . [The new Duke]6510-the new duke sat in [[his]512-joseph closet]3521-his closet . The walls had been stripped of [their]6849-their pious relics and lined with books , and above the fireplace hung the Venus of [Giorgione]427-giorgione , liberated at last from [her]427-giorgione long imprisonment . The windows stood open , admitting the soft September air . Twilight had fallen on [the gardens]8159-the gardens , and through it a young moon floated above [the cypresses]6851-the cypresses . On just such an evening three years earlier [he]512-joseph had ridden down [the slope of [the Monte Baldo]503-monte baldo]6852-the slope of the monte baldo with [Fulvia Vivaldi]362-fulvia at [his]512-joseph side . How often , since , [he]512-joseph had relived the incidents of that night ! With singular precision [they]6853-they succeeded each other in [his]512-joseph thoughts . [He]512-joseph felt the wild sweep of the storm across [the lake]9807-the lake , the warmth of [her]362-fulvia nearness , the sense of [her]362-fulvia complete trust in [him]512-joseph ; then [their]6853-they arrival at [the inn]1050-the inn , the dazzle of light as [they]6853-they crossed the threshold , and [de Crucis]462-de crucis confronting [them]6853-they within . [He]512-joseph heard [her]362-fulvia voice pleading with [him]512-joseph in every accent that pride and tenderness and a noble loyalty could command ; [he]512-joseph felt [her]362-fulvia will slowly dominating [his]512-joseph , like a supernatural power forcing [him]512-joseph into [his]512-joseph destined path ; [he]512-joseph felt -- and with how profound an irony of spirit!--the passion of self - dedication in which [he]512-joseph had taken up [his]512-joseph task . [He]512-joseph had known moments of happiness since ; moments when [he]512-joseph believed in [himself]512-joseph and in [his]512-joseph calling , and felt [himself]512-joseph indeed [the man [she]362-fulvia thought [him]512-joseph]6856-the man she thought him . That was in the exaltation of the first months , when [his]512-joseph opportunities had seemed as boundless as [his]512-joseph dreams , and [he]512-joseph had not yet learned that [the sovereign]1435-the sovereign 's power may be a kind of spiritual prison to [the man]1626-the man . Since then , indeed , [he]512-joseph had known another kind of happiness , had been aware of a secret voice whispering within [him]512-joseph that [she]362-fulvia was right and had chosen wisely for [him]512-joseph ; but this was when [he]512-joseph had realised that [he]512-joseph lived in [a prison]5813-a prison , and had begun to admire the sumptuous adornment of [its]5813-a prison walls . For a while the mere external show of power amused [him]512-joseph , and [his]512-joseph imagination was charmed by the historic dignity of [his]512-joseph surroundings . In such a setting , against the background of such a past , it seemed easy to play [the benefactor]6860-the benefactor and friend of [the people]1003-the people . [His]512-joseph sensibility was touched by the contrast , and [he]512-joseph saw [himself]512-joseph as [a picturesque figure linking the new dreams of liberty and equality to the feudal traditions of a thousand years]6862-a picturesque figure linking the new dreams of liberty and equality to the feudal traditions of a thousand years . But this masquerading soon ceased to divert [him]512-joseph . The round of court ceremonial wearied [him]512-joseph , and books and art lost [their]6863-their fascination . The more [he]512-joseph varied [his]512-joseph amusements the more monotonous they became , the more [he]512-joseph crowded [his]512-joseph life with petty duties the more empty of achievement it seemed . At first [he]512-joseph had hoped to bury [his]512-joseph personal disappointments in the task of reconstructing [his]512-joseph little state ; but on every side [he]512-joseph felt a mute resistance to [his]512-joseph efforts . [The philosophical faction]6864-the philosophical faction had indeed poured forth pamphlets celebrating [his]512-joseph reforms , and comparing [his]512-joseph reign to the return of the Golden Age . But it was not for [the philosophers]8362-the philosophers that [he]512-joseph laboured ; and the benefits of free speech , a free press , a secular education did not , after all , reach those over whom [his]512-joseph heart yearned . It was [the people [he]512-joseph longed to serve]6866-the people he longed to serve ; and [the people]1003-the people were hungry , were fever - stricken , were crushed with tithes and taxes . It was hopeless to try to reach [them]1003-the people by the diffusion of popular knowledge . [They]1003-the people must first be fed and clothed ; and before [they]1003-the people could be fed and clothed the chains of feudalism must be broken . [Men like [Gamba]282-gamba and [Andreoni]441-andreoni]6868-men like gamba and andreoni saw this clearly enough ; but it was not from [them]1003-the people that help could come . [The nobility]1665-the nobility and [clergy]6870-clergy must be coaxed or coerced into sympathy with the new movement ; and to accomplish this exceeded [Odo]234-odo 's powers . In [France]22-france , the revolt from feudalism had found [some of [[its]22-france boldest leaders]6872-its boldest leaders in [the very class that had most to lose by the change]6873-the very class that had most to lose by the change]6871-some of its boldest leaders in the very class that had most to lose by the change ; but in [Italy]5-italy fewer causes were at work to set such disinterested passions in motion . South of the [Alps]20-the alps liberalism was merely one of the new fashions from [France]22-france : [the men]6838-the men ran after the pamphlets from [Paris]27-paris as [the women]823-the women ran after the cosmetics ; and the politics went no deeper than the powder . Even among [the freest intellects]6876-the freest intellects liberalism resulted in a new way of thinking rather in a new way of living . Nowhere among [the better classes]6877-the better classes was there any desire to attack existing institutions . [The Church]72-the church had never troubled the Latin consciousness . [The Renaissance]6878-the renaissance had taught [cultivated Italians]6879-cultivated italians how to live at peace with a creed in which [they]6879-cultivated italians no longer believed ; and [their]6879-cultivated italians easy - going scepticism was combined with a traditional conviction that [the priest]1732-the priest knew better than any one how to deal with [the poor]8713-the poor , and that [the clergy]1929-the clergy were of distinct use in relieving the individual conscience of its obligation to [its fellows]6883-its fellows . It was against such deep - seated habits of thought that [Odo]234-odo had to struggle . Centuries of fierce individualism , or of sullen apathy under a foreign rule , had left [the Italians]6884-the italians incapable of any concerted political action ; but suspicion , avarice and vanity , combined with a lurking fear of [the Church]1212-the church , united all parties in a kind of passive opposition to reform . Thus [the Duke]682-the duke 's resolve to put [the University]9247-the university under lay direction had excited the enmity of [the Barnabites , who had been at its head since the suppression of the Society of Jesus]6888-the barnabites , who had been at its head since the suppression of the society of jesus ; [his]682-the duke efforts to partition among [the peasantry]8358-the peasantry [the Caccia del Vescovo]9214-the caccia del vescovo , [that great waste domain of [the see of [Pianura]4-pianura]4-pianura]6891-that great waste domain of the see of pianura , had roused a storm of fear among [all who laid claim to feudal rights]6892-all who laid claim to feudal rights ; and [his]682-the duke own personal attempts at retrenchment , which necessitated the suppression of numerous court offices , had done more than anything else to increase [his]682-the duke unpopularity . Even [the people , in whose behalf these sacrifices were made]6893-the people , in whose behalf these sacrifices were made , looked askance at [his]682-the duke diminished state , and showed a perverse sympathy with [the dispossessed officials who had taken so picturesque a part in the public ceremonials of [the court]814-the court]6894-the dispossessed officials who had taken so picturesque a part in the public ceremonials of the court . All [Odo]234-odo 's philosophy could not fortify [him]234-odo against such disillusionments . [He]234-odo felt the lack of [Fulvia]362-fulvia 's unquestioning faith not only in the abstract beauty of the new ideals but in their immediate adaptability to the complex conditions of life . Only [a woman]5452-a woman 's convictions , nourished on sentiment and self - sacrifice , could burn with that clear unwavering flame : [his]682-the duke own beliefs were at the mercy of every wind of doubt or ingratitude that blew across [his]682-the duke unsheltered sensibilities . It was more than a year since [he]234-odo had had news of [Fulvia]362-fulvia . For a while [they]6897-they had exchanged letters , and it had been a consolation to tell [her]5452-a woman of [his]682-the duke struggles and experiments , of [his]682-the duke many failures and few results . [She]5452-a woman had encouraged [him]682-the duke to continue the struggle , had analysed [his]682-the duke various plans of reform , and had given [her]5452-a woman enthusiastic support to the partitioning of [the Bishop]1234-the bishop 's fief and the secularisation of [the University]9247-the university . [Her]5452-a woman own life , [she]5452-a woman said , was too uneventful to write of ; but [she]5452-a woman spoke of the kindness of [[her]5452-a woman hosts]6900-her hosts , [the Professor]2482-the professor and [[his]2482-the professor wife]1713-his wife , of the simple unceremonious way of living in [the old Calvinist city]6903-the old calvinist city , and of the number of [distinguished persons drawn thither by]6904-distinguished persons drawn thither by [its]6903-the old calvinist city atmosphere of intellectual and social freedom . [Odo]234-odo suspected a certain colourlessness in the life [she]5452-a woman depicted . The tone of [her]5452-a woman letters was too uniformly cheerful not to suggest a lack of emotional variety ; and [he]234-odo knew that [Fulvia]362-fulvia 's nature , however much [she]5452-a woman fancied it under the rule of reason , was in reality fed by profound currents of feeling . Something of [her]5452-a woman old ardour reappeared when [she]5452-a woman wrote of the possibility of publishing [[her]5452-a woman father]1415-her father 's book . [[Her]5452-a woman friends in [Geneva]182-geneva]6906-her friends in geneva , having heard of [her]5452-a woman difficulty with [the Dutch publisher]6907-the dutch publisher , had undertaken to vindicate [her]5452-a woman claims ; and [they]6906-her friends in geneva had every hope that the matter would be successfully concluded . The joy of renewed activity with which this letter glowed would have communicated itself to [Odo]234-odo had [he]234-odo received it at a different time ; but it came on the day of [his]234-odo marriage , and since then [he]234-odo had never written to [her]5452-a woman . Now [he]234-odo felt a sudden longing to break the silence between [them]6908-them , and seating [himself]234-odo at [his]234-odo desk [he]234-odo began to write . A moment later there was a knock on the door and [one of [[his]234-odo gentlemen]6649-his gentlemen]6909-one of his gentlemen entered . [The Count Vittorio Alfieri]306-alfieri , with a dozen horses and [as many servants]6911-as many servants , was newly arrived at [the Golden Cross]205-the golden cross , and desired to know when [he]306-alfieri might have the honour of waiting on [[his]306-alfieri Highness]941-his highness . [Odo]234-odo felt the sudden glow of pleasure that the news of [Alfieri]306-alfieri 's coming always brought . Here was [a friend]8895-a friend at last ! [He]234-odo forgot the constraint of [their]6908-them last meeting in [Florence]88-florence , and remembered only the happy interchange of ideas and emotions that had been one of the quickening influences of [his]306-alfieri youth . [Alfieri]306-alfieri , in the intervening years , was grown to be one of [the foremost figures in [Italy]5-italy]6914-the foremost figures in italy . [His]306-alfieri love for [the Countess of [Albany]148-albany]514-the countess of albany , persisting through the vicissitudes of [her]514-the countess of albany tragic marriage , had rallied the scattered forces of [his]306-alfieri nature . Ambitious to excel for [her]514-the countess of albany sake , to show [himself]306-alfieri worthy of such a love , [he]306-alfieri had at last shaken off the strange torpor of [his]306-alfieri youth , and revealed [himself]306-alfieri as [the poet for whom [Italy]5-italy waited]6915-the poet for whom italy waited . In ten months of feverish effort [he]306-alfieri had poured forth fourteen tragedies -- among them [the Antigone]515-the antigone , the Virginia , and the Conjuration of [the Pazzi]516-the pazzi . [Italy]5-italy started up at the sound of a new voice vibrating with passions [she]514-the countess of albany had long since unlearned . Since [Filicaja]517-filicaja 's thrilling appeal to [[his]517-filicaja enslaved country]6916-his enslaved country [no poet]6917-no poet had challenged the old Roman spirit which [Petrarch]334-petrarch had striven to rouse . While [the literati]6918-the literati were busy discussing [Alfieri]306-alfieri 's blank verse , while [the grammarians]6919-the grammarians wrangled over [his]306-alfieri syntax and ridiculed [his]306-alfieri solecisms , [the public]4018-the public , heedless of such niceties , was glowing with the new wine which [he]306-alfieri had poured into the old vessels of classic story . " Liberty "[4018-the public] was the cry that rang on the lips of all [[his]306-alfieri heroes]6921-his heroes , in accents so new and stirring that [[his]306-alfieri audience]6922-his audience never wearied of its repetition . It was no secret that [his]306-alfieri stories of [ancient Greece]6923-ancient greece and [Rome]11-rome were but allegories meant to teach the love of freedom ; yet the Antigone had been performed in [the private theatre of the Spanish Ambassador at [Rome]11-rome]6924-the private theatre of the spanish ambassador at rome , the Virginia had been received with applause on the public boards at [Turin]17-turin , and after the usual difficulties with the censorship [the happy author]6925-the happy author had actually succeeded in publishing [his]306-alfieri plays at [Siena]206-siena . These volumes were already in [Odo]234-odo 's hands , and a manuscript copy of the Odes to Free [America]137-america was being circulated among [the liberals]9304-the liberals in [Pianura]4-pianura , and had been brought to [his]306-alfieri notice by [Andreoni]441-andreoni . To [those hopeful spirits who looked for the near approach of a happier era]6927-those hopeful spirits who looked for the near approach of a happier era , [Alfieri]306-alfieri was [the inspired spokesman of reform]6928-the inspired spokesman of reform , [the heaven - sent prophet who was to lead [[his]306-alfieri country]4373-his country out of bondage]6929-the heaven - sent prophet who was to lead his country out of bondage . The eyes of [the Italian reformers]6931-the italian reformers were fixed with passionate eagerness on the course of events in [England]49-england and [France]22-france . The conclusion of peace between [England]49-england and [America]137-america , recently celebrated in [Alfieri]306-alfieri 's fifth Ode , seemed to the most sceptical convincing proof that the rights of [man]2185-man were destined to a speedy triumph throughout the civilised world . It was not of [a united Italy]6933-a united italy that [these enthusiasts]6934-these enthusiasts dreamed . [They]6934-these enthusiasts were not so much [patriots]6935-patriots as [philanthropists]6936-philanthropists ; for the teachings of [Rousseau]340-rousseau and [his]6937-his school , while intensifying the love of [man]2185-man for [man]2185-man , had proportionately weakened the sense of patriotism , of the interets du clocher . [The new man]6940-the new man prided [himself]6940-the new man on being [a citizen of [the world]844-the world]6941-a citizen of the world , on sympathising as warmly with [the poetic savage of Peru]6943-the poetic savage of peru as with [[his]6940-the new man own prosaic and narrow - minded neighbours]6944-his own prosaic and narrow - minded neighbours . Indeed , the prevalent belief that [the savage]6945-the savage 's mode of life was much nearer the truth than that of civilised [Europeans]518-europeans , made it appear superfluous to enter into the grievances and difficulties of what was but a passing phase of human development . To cast off clothes and codes , and live in a peaceful socialism " under the amiable reign of Truth and Nature , "[6946-such dreamers] seemed on the whole much easier than to undertake the systematic reform of existing abuses . To [such dreamers]6946-such dreamers -- whose ideas were those of [the majority of intelligent men in [France]22-france and [Italy]5-italy]6947-the majority of intelligent men in france and italy -- [Alfieri]306-alfieri 's high - sounding tirades embodied the noblest of political creeds ; and even the soberer judgment of [statesmen]8460-statesmen and [men of affairs]6949-men of affairs was captivated by the grandeur of [his]306-alfieri verse and the heroic audacity of [his]306-alfieri theme . For the first time in centuries [the Italian Muse]6950-the italian muse spoke with the voice of [a man]8112-a man ; and [every man]6952-every man 's heart in [Italy]5-italy sprang up at the call . In the midst of these triumphs , fate in the shape of [Cardinal York]519-cardinal york had momentarily separated [Alfieri]306-alfieri from [[his]306-alfieri mistress]8825-his mistress , despatching [the too - tender Countess]6954-the too - tender countess to a discreet retreat in [Alsace]207-alsace , and signifying to [her]6954-the too - tender countess turbulent adorer that [he]306-alfieri was not to follow [her]6954-the too - tender countess . Distracted by this prohibition , [Alfieri]306-alfieri had resumed the nomadic habits of [his]306-alfieri youth , now wandering from [one Italian city]6955-one italian city to another , now pushing as far as [Paris]27-paris , which [he]306-alfieri hated but was always revisiting , now dashing across [the Channel]208-the channel to buy thoroughbreds in [England]49-england -- for [his]306-alfieri passion for horses was unabated .
