[He]306-alfieri was lately returned from such an expedition , having led [his]306-alfieri cavalcade across [the Alps]20-the alps in person , with a boyish delight in the astonishment which [this fantastic exploit]6956-this fantastic exploit excited . The meeting between [the two friends]2475-the two friends was all that [Odo]234-odo could have wished . Though affecting to scorn [the courts of [princes]2145-princes]6958-the courts of princes , [Alfieri]306-alfieri was not averse to showing [himself]306-alfieri there as [the poet of the democracy]6960-the poet of the democracy , and to hearing [[his]306-alfieri heroes]6921-his heroes mouth [their]6921-his heroes tyrannicidal speeches on the boards of royal and ducal stages . [He]306-alfieri had lately made some stay in [Milan]14-milan , where [he]306-alfieri had arrived in time to see [his]306-alfieri Antigone performed before [the vice - regal court]6962-the vice - regal court , and to be enthusiastically acclaimed as [the high - priest of liberty]6963-the high - priest of liberty by [a community living placidly under the Austrian yoke]6964-a community living placidly under the austrian yoke . [Alfieri]306-alfieri was not [the man to be struck by such incongruities]6965-the man to be struck by such incongruities . It was [his]306-alfieri fate to formulate creeds in which [he]306-alfieri had no faith : to recreate the political ideals of [Italy]5-italy while bitterly opposed to any actual effort at reform , and to be regarded as the mouthpiece of the Revolution while [he]306-alfieri execrated the Revolution with the whole force of [his]306-alfieri traditional instincts . As usual [he]306-alfieri was too deeply engrossed in [his]306-alfieri own affairs to feel much interest in any others ; but it was enough for [Odo]234-odo to clasp the hand of [the man who had given a voice to the highest aspirations of [[his]306-alfieri countrymen]6967-his countrymen]6966-the man who had given a voice to the highest aspirations of his countrymen . [The poet]2275-the poet gave more than [he]306-alfieri could expect from [the friend]662-the friend ; and [he]306-alfieri was satisfied to listen to [Alfieri]306-alfieri 's account of [his]306-alfieri triumphs , interspersed with bitter diatribes against [the public whose applause [he]306-alfieri courted]6970-the public whose applause he courted , and [the Pope to whom , on bended knee , [he]306-alfieri had offered a copy of [his]306-alfieri plays]6971-the pope to whom , on bended knee , he had offered a copy of his plays . [Odo]234-odo eagerly pressed [Alfieri]306-alfieri to remain in [Pianura]4-pianura , offering to put one of [the ducal villas]6972-the ducal villas at [his]306-alfieri disposal , and suggesting that [the Virginia]520-virginia should be performed before [the court]814-the court on [the Duchess]899-the duchess 's birthday . " It is true , "[234-odo] [he]234-odo said , " that [we]9965-we can offer [you]306-alfieri but [an indifferent company of [actors]2050-actors]9966-an indifferent company of actors ; but it might be possible to obtain [one or two of [the leading tragedians]9969-the leading tragedians from [Turin]17-turin or [Milan]14-milan]9968-one or two of the leading tragedians from turin or milan , so that the principal parts should at least be worthily filled . "[234-odo] [Alfieri]306-alfieri replied with a contemptuous gesture . " [[Your]234-odo Highness]8397-your highness , [[our]9965-we leading tragedians]9971-our leading tragedians are monkeys trained to dance to the tune of [Goldoni]288-goldoni and [Metastasio]300-metastasio . The best are no better than the worst . [We]9965-we have [no tragedians]9972-no tragedians in [Italy]5-italy because -- hitherto -- [we]9965-we have had [no tragic dramatist]9973-no tragic dramatist . "[306-alfieri] [He]306-alfieri drew [himself]306-alfieri up and thrust a hand in [his]306-alfieri bosom . " Ah ! "[306-alfieri] [he]306-alfieri exclaimed , " if [I]306-alfieri could see the part of [Virginia]520-virginia acted by [the lady who recently recited , before a small company in [Milan]14-milan]9974-the lady who recently recited , before a small company in milan , [my]306-alfieri Odes to Free [America]137-america ! There indeed were fire , sublimity and passion ! And the countenance had not lost its freshness , the eye its lustre . But , "[306-alfieri] [he]306-alfieri suddenly added , " [[your]9974-the lady who recently recited , before a small company in milan Highness]8397-your highness knows of whom [I]306-alfieri speak . [The lady]660-the lady is [Fulvia Vivaldi]362-fulvia , [the daughter of the philosopher at whose feet [we]9978-we sat in [our]9978-we youth]9977-the daughter of the philosopher at whose feet we sat in our youth . "[306-alfieri] [Fulvia Vivaldi]362-fulvia ! [Odo]234-odo raised [his]234-odo head with a start . [She]362-fulvia had left [Geneva]182-geneva then , had returned to [Italy]5-italy . [The Alps]20-the alps no longer divided [them]6975-them -- a scant day 's journey would bring [him]306-alfieri to [her]362-fulvia side ! It was strange how the mere thought seemed to fill [the room]782-the room with [her]362-fulvia presence . [He]234-odo felt [her]362-fulvia in the quickened beat of [his]234-odo pulses , in the sudden lightness of the air , in a lifting and widening of the very bounds of thought . From [Alfieri]306-alfieri [he]234-odo learned that [she]362-fulvia had lived for some months in [the household of [the distinguished naturalist]6978-the distinguished naturalist]6977-the household of the distinguished naturalist , [Count Castiglione , with whose daughter 's education [she]362-fulvia was charged]6979-count castiglione , with whose daughter 's education she was charged . In such surroundings [her]362-fulvia wit and learning could not fail to attract [the best company of [Milan]14-milan]6980-the best company of milan , and [she]362-fulvia was become [one of the most noted figures of [the capital]3062-the capital]6981-one of the most noted figures of the capital . There had been some talk of offering [her]362-fulvia the chair of poetry at [the Brera]209-the brera ; but the report of [her]362-fulvia liberal views had deterred [the faculty]6983-the faculty . Meanwhile the very fact that [she]362-fulvia represented [the new school of thought]6984-the new school of thought gave an added zest to [her]362-fulvia conversation in [a society which made up for [its]6985-a society which made up for its mild servitude under the austrian by much talk of liberalism and independence mild servitude under [the Austrian]521-the austrian by much talk of liberalism and independence]6985-a society which made up for its mild servitude under the austrian by much talk of liberalism and independence . [The Signorina Vivaldi]362-fulvia became the fashion . [The literati]6918-the literati celebrated [her]362-fulvia scholarship , the sonneteers [her]362-fulvia eloquence and beauty ; and [no foreigner on the grand tour]6987-no foreigner on the grand tour was content to leave [Milan]14-milan without having beheld [the fair prodigy]6988-the fair prodigy and heard [her]362-fulvia recite [Petrarch]334-petrarch 's Ode to [Italy]5-italy , or the latest elegy of [Pindamonte]522-pindamonte . [Odo]234-odo scarce knew with what feelings [he]234-odo listened . [He]234-odo could not but acknowledge that such a life was better suited to one of [Fulvia]362-fulvia 's gifts and ambitions than the humdrum existence of [a Swiss town]6989-a swiss town ; yet [his]234-odo first sensation was one of obscure jealousy , of reluctance to think of [her]362-fulvia as having definitely broken with the past . [He]234-odo had pictured [her]362-fulvia as adrift , like [himself]234-odo , on [a dark sea of uncertainties]6990-a dark sea of uncertainties ; and to learn that [she]362-fulvia had found [a safe anchorage]6991-a safe anchorage was almost to feel [himself]234-odo deserted . [The court]814-the court was soon busy with preparations for the coming performance . [A celebrated actress from [Venice]41-venice]6993-a celebrated actress from venice was engaged to play the part of [Virginia]520-virginia , and the rehearsals went rapidly forward under [the noble author]6994-the noble author 's supervision . At last the great day arrived , and for the first time in the history of [the little theatre]5400-the little theatre , operetta and pastoral were replaced by the buskined Muse of tragedy . [The court]814-the court and [all the nobility]6997-all the nobility were present , and though it was no longer thought becoming for [ecclesiastics]4770-ecclesiastics to visit [the theatre]1559-the theatre , [the easy - going Bishop]7000-the easy - going bishop appeared in a side - box in company with [[his]234-odo chaplains]7001-his chaplains and [the Vicar - general]1934-the vicar - general . The performance was brilliantly successful . Frantic applause greeted the tirades of [the young Icilius]523-the young icilius . Every outburst against the abuse of privileges and the insolence of [the patricians]7003-the patricians was acclaimed by [ministers]6594-ministers and [courtiers]5586-courtiers , and the loudest in approval were [the Marquess Pievepelago]7006-the marquess pievepelago , [the recognised representative of [the clericals]7008-the clericals]7007-the recognised representative of the clericals , [the Marchioness of [Boscofolto]97-boscofolto , whose harsh enforcement of [her]7009-the marchioness of boscofolto , whose harsh enforcement of her feudal rights was among the bitterest grievances of the peasantry feudal rights was among the bitterest grievances of [the peasantry]8358-the peasantry]7009-the marchioness of boscofolto , whose harsh enforcement of her feudal rights was among the bitterest grievances of the peasantry , and [the good Bishop]7011-the good bishop , who had lately roused [himself]7011-the good bishop from [his]7011-the good bishop habitual indolence to oppose the threatened annexation of [the Caccia del Vescovo]200-the caccia del vescovo . [One and all]7012-one and all proclaimed [their]7012-one and all ardent sympathy with [the proletariat]7013-the proletariat , [their]7012-one and all scorn of tyranny and extortion in high places ; and if [the Marchioness]1174-the marchioness , on [her]1174-the marchioness return [home]1346-home , ordered [one of [[her]1174-the marchioness linkmen]7017-her linkmen]7016-one of her linkmen to be flogged for having trod on [her]1174-the marchioness gown ; if [Pievepelago]266-the marchioness the next morning refused to give audience to [a poor devil of [a pamphleteer that was come to ask [his]266-the marchioness intercession with [the Holy Office]3229-the holy office]7019-a pamphleteer that was come to ask his intercession with the holy office]7018-a poor devil of a pamphleteer that was come to ask his intercession with the holy office ; if [the Bishop]1234-the bishop at the same moment concluded the purchase of [six able - bodied [Turks]524-turks from the galleys of [his]1234-the bishop Serenity [the Doge of [Genoa]23-genoa]7023-the doge of genoa]7022-six able - bodied turks from the galleys of his serenity the doge of genoa -- it is probable that , like [the illustrious author of the drama]7024-the illustrious author of the drama , [all]7025-all were unconscious of any incongruity between [their]7025-all sentiments and actions . As to [Odo]234-odo , seated in the state box , with [Maria Clementina]413-maria clementina at [his]234-odo side , and [the court dignitaries grouped in the background]7026-the court dignitaries grouped in the background , [he]234-odo had not listened to a dozen lines before all sense of [his]234-odo surroundings vanished and [he]234-odo became the passive instrument on which [the poet]2275-the poet played [his]2275-the poet mighty harmonies . All the incidental difficulties of life , all the vacillations of an unsatisfied spirit , were consumed in that energising emotion which seemed to leave every faculty stripped for action . Profounder meaning and more subtle music [he]234-odo had found in [the great poets of the past]7028-the great poets of the past ; but here was an appeal to the immediate needs of the hour , uttered in notes as thrilling as a trumpet - call , and brought home to every sense by the vivid imagery of the stage . Once more [he]234-odo felt the old ardour of belief that [Fulvia]362-fulvia 's nearness had fanned in [him]234-odo . [His]234-odo convictions had flagged rather than [his]234-odo courage : now they started up as at [her]362-fulvia summons , and [he]234-odo heard the ring of [her]362-fulvia voice in every line . [He]234-odo left [the theatre]1559-the theatre still vibrating with this new inrush of life , and jealous of any interruption that should check it . [The Duchess]899-the duchess 's birthday was being celebrated by illuminations and fireworks , and throngs of [merry - makers]7031-merry - makers filled [the moonlit streets]7032-the moonlit streets ; but [Odo]234-odo , after appearing for a moment at [[his]234-odo wife]1713-his wife 's side on [the balcony]7034-the balcony above [the public square]7035-the public square , withdrew quietly to [[his]234-odo own apartments]7036-his own apartments . The casement of [[his]234-odo closet]3521-his closet stood wide , and [he]234-odo leaned against the window - frame , looking out on the silent radiance of [the gardens]8159-the gardens . As [he]234-odo stood there [he]234-odo saw two figures flit across the farther end of [one of [the long alleys]5288-the long alleys]7039-one of the long alleys . The moonlight surrendered [them]7041-them for a moment , the shade almost instantly reclaiming them -- [strayed revellers]7042-strayed revellers , doubtless , escaping from the lights and music of [the Duchess]899-the duchess 's circle . A knock roused [the Duke]682-the duke and [he]682-the duke remembered that [he]682-the duke had bidden [Gamba]282-gamba wait on [him]682-the duke after the performance . [He]682-the duke had been curious to hear what impression [Alfieri]306-alfieri 's drama had produced upon the hunchback ; but now any interruption seemed unwelcome , and [he]682-the duke turned to [Gamba]282-gamba with a gesture of dismissal . [The latter]870-the latter however remained on the threshold . " [[Your]682-the duke Highness]8397-your highness , "[682-the duke] [he]682-the duke said , " [the bookseller Andreoni]9980-the bookseller andreoni craves the privilege of an audience . "[682-the duke] " [Andreoni]441-andreoni ? At this hour ? "[282-gamba] " For reasons so urgent that [he]9980-the bookseller andreoni makes no doubt of [your]682-the duke Highness 's consent ; and to prove [his]9980-the bookseller andreoni good faith , and the need of presenting [himself]9980-the bookseller andreoni at so undue an hour , and in this private manner , [he]9980-the bookseller andreoni charged [me]682-the duke to give this to [[your]682-the duke Highness]8397-your highness . "[682-the duke] [He]682-the duke laid in [the Duke]682-the duke 's hand a small object in blackened silver , which on nearer inspection proved to be the ducal coat - of - arms . [Odo]234-odo stood gazing fixedly at this mysterious token , which seemed to come as an answer to [his]234-odo inmost thoughts . [His]234-odo heart beat high with confused hopes and fears , and [he]234-odo could hardly control the voice in which [he]234-odo answered : " Bid [Andreoni]441-andreoni come to [me]234-odo . "[234-odo] 4.4 . [The bookseller]5565-the bookseller began by excusing [himself]5565-the bookseller for the liberty [he]5565-the bookseller had taken . [He]5565-the bookseller explained that [the Signorina Fulvia Vivaldi]362-fulvia , in whose behalf [he]5565-the bookseller came , was in urgent need of aid , and had begged [him]5565-the bookseller to wait on [the Duke]682-the duke as soon as the court had risen from the play . " [She]362-fulvia is in [Pianura]4-pianura , then ? "[234-odo] [Odo]234-odo exclaimed . " Since yesterday , [[your]682-the duke Highness]8397-your highness . Three days since [she]362-fulvia was ordered by [the police]8784-the police to leave [Milan]14-milan within twenty - four hours , and [she]362-fulvia came at once to [Pianura]4-pianura , knowing that [[my]441-andreoni wife]9391-my wife and [I]441-andreoni would gladly receive [her]362-fulvia . But today [we]9985-we learned that [the Holy Office]3229-the holy office was advised of [her]362-fulvia presence [here]8091-here , and of the reason of [her]362-fulvia banishment from [Lombardy]81-lombardy ; and this fresh danger has forced [her]362-fulvia to implore [[your]441-andreoni Highness]8397-your highness 's protection . "[441-andreoni] [Andreoni]441-andreoni went on to explain that the publication of [[her]7049-her father]1415-her father 's book was the immediate cause of [Fulvia]362-fulvia 's persecution . The Origin of Civilisation , which had been printed some months previously in [Amsterdam]179-amsterdam , had stirred [Italy]5-italy more profoundly than any book since [Beccaria]372-beccaria 's great work on Crime and Punishment . [The author]5563-the author 's historical investigations were but a pretext for the development of [his]5563-the author political theories , which were set forth with singular daring and audacity , and supported by all the arguments that [his]5563-the author long study of the past commanded . The temperate and judicial tone which [he]5563-the author had succeeded in preserving enhanced the effect of [his]5563-the author arraignment of Church and state , and while [his]5563-the author immense erudition commended [his]5563-the author work to the learned , its directness of style gave it an immediate popularity with [the general reader]7052-the general reader . It was an age when every book or pamphlet bearing on the great question of personal liberty was eagerly devoured by [an insatiable public]7053-an insatiable public ; and a few weeks after [Vivaldi]362-fulvia 's volume had been smuggled into [Italy]5-italy it was the talk of [every club and coffee - house from [Calabria]211-calabria to [Piedmont]60-piedmont]7054-every club and coffee - house from calabria to piedmont . The inevitable result soon followed . [The Holy Office]3229-the holy office got wind of the business , and the book was at once put on the Index . In [Naples]59-naples and [Bologna]79-bologna it was publicly burned , and in [Modena]90-modena [a professor of the University]7056-a professor of the university who was found to have a copy in [his]7056-a professor of the university possession was fined and removed from [his]7056-a professor of the university chair . In [Milan]14-milan , where [the strong liberal faction among [the nobility , and the comparative leniency of the Austrian rule]7058-the nobility , and the comparative leniency of the austrian rule]7057-the strong liberal faction among the nobility , and the comparative leniency of the austrian rule , permitted a more unrestrained discussion of political questions , the Origin of Civilisation was received with open enthusiasm , and the story of the difficulties that [Fulvia]362-fulvia had encountered in its publication made [her]362-fulvia [the heroine of the moment]7059-the heroine of the moment . [She]362-fulvia had never concealed [her]362-fulvia devotion to [[her]362-fulvia father]1415-her father 's doctrines , and in the first glow of filial pride [she]362-fulvia may have yielded too openly to the desire to propagate [them]7061-them . Certain it is that [she]362-fulvia began to be looked on as having shared in the writing of the book , or as being at least an active exponent of its principles . Even in [Lombardy]81-lombardy it was not well to be too openly associated with the authorship of a condemned book ; and [Fulvia]362-fulvia was suddenly advised by [the police]8784-the police that [her]362-fulvia presence in [Milan]14-milan was no longer acceptable to [the government]2558-the government . The news excited great indignation among [[her]362-fulvia friends]3119-her friends , and [Count Castiglione]525-count castiglione and [several other gentlemen of rank]7065-several other gentlemen of rank hastened to intervene in [her]362-fulvia behalf ; but [the governor]4711-the governor declared [himself]4711-the governor unwilling to take issue with [the Holy Office]3229-the holy office on a doctrinal point , and privately added that it would be well for [the Signorina Vivaldi]362-fulvia to withdraw from [Lombardy]81-lombardy before [the clergy]1929-the clergy brought any direct charge against [her]362-fulvia . To ignore this hint would have been to risk not only [her]362-fulvia own safety but that of [the gentlemen who had befriended [her]362-fulvia]7069-the gentlemen who had befriended her ; and [Fulvia]362-fulvia at once set out for [Pianura]4-pianura , [the only place in [Italy]5-italy where [she]362-fulvia could count on friendship and protection]7070-the only place in italy where she could count on friendship and protection . [Andreoni]441-andreoni and [[his]441-andreoni wife]1713-his wife would gladly have given [her]362-fulvia [a home]5040-a home ; but on learning that [the Holy Office]3229-the holy office was on [her]362-fulvia track , [she]362-fulvia had refused to compromise [them]7074-them by remaining under [their]7074-them roof , and had insisted that [Andreoni]441-andreoni should wait on [the Duke]682-the duke and obtain a safe - conduct for [her]362-fulvia that very night . [Odo]234-odo listened to this story with an agitation compounded of strangely contradictory sensations . To learn that [Fulvia]362-fulvia , at the very moment when [he]234-odo had pictured [her]362-fulvia as separated from [him]234-odo by the happiness and security of [her]362-fulvia life , was in reality [a proscribed wanderer with none but [himself]234-odo to turn to]7076-a proscribed wanderer with none but himself to turn to , filled [him]234-odo with a confused sense of happiness ; but the discovery that , in [his]234-odo own dominions , [the political refugee]7077-the political refugee was not safe from the threats of [the Holy Office]3229-the holy office , excited a different emotion . All these considerations , however , were subordinate to the thought that [he]234-odo must see [Fulvia]362-fulvia at once . It was impossible to summon [her]362-fulvia to [the palace]768-the palace at that hour , or even to secure [her]362-fulvia safety till morning , without compromising [Andreoni]441-andreoni by calling attention to the fact that [a suspected person]7080-a suspected person was under [his]234-odo roof ; and for a moment [Odo]234-odo was at a loss how to detain [her]362-fulvia in [Pianura]4-pianura without seeming to go counter to [her]362-fulvia wishes . Suddenly [he]234-odo remembered that [Gamba]282-gamba was fertile in expedients , and calling in the hunchback , asked what plan [he]282-gamba could devise . [Gamba]282-gamba , after a moment 's reflection , drew a key from [his]282-gamba pocket . " May it please [[your]9989-your Highness]8397-your highness , "[282-gamba] [he]282-gamba said , " this unlocks the door of [the hunting - lodge at [Pontesordo]2-pontesordo]9991-the hunting - lodge at pontesordo . [The place]1030-the place has been deserted these many years , because of [its]1030-the place bad name , and [I]282-gamba have more than once found [it]1030-the place a convenient shelter when [I]282-gamba had reasons for wishing to be private . At this season there is no fear of poison from [the marshes]3363-the marshes , and if [[your]9989-your Highness]8397-your highness desires [I]282-gamba will see that [the lady]660-the lady finds [her]660-the lady way there before sunrise . "[282-gamba] The sun had hardly risen the next morning when [the Duke]682-the duke [himself]682-the duke set forth . [He]682-the duke rode alone , dressed like [one of [[his]682-the duke own esquires]7083-his own esquires]7082-one of his own esquires , and gave the word unremarked to [the sleepy sentinel at the gate]7084-the sleepy sentinel at the gate . As it closed behind [him]682-the duke and [he]682-the duke set out down [the long road]7085-the long road that led to the chase , it seemed to [him]682-the duke that the morning solitude was thronged with spectral memories . Melancholy and fanciful [they]7086-they flitted before [him]682-the duke , now in the guise of [Cerveno]394-cerveno and [Momola]241-momola , now of [Maria Clementina]413-maria clementina and [himself]682-the duke . Every detail of the scene was interwoven with the fibres of early association , from the far off years when , as [a lonely child on [the farm at [Pontesordo]2-pontesordo]7088-the farm at pontesordo]7087-a lonely child on the farm at pontesordo , [he]682-the duke had gazed across [the marsh]724-the marsh at [the mysterious woodlands of the chase]7090-the mysterious woodlands of the chase , to the later day when , in [the deserted hunting - lodge]7091-the deserted hunting - lodge , [the Duchess]899-the duchess had flung [her]899-the duchess whip at the face in the Venice mirror . [He]682-the duke pressed forward impatiently , and presently [the lodge]9166-the lodge rose before [him]682-the duke in [its]9166-the lodge grassy solitude . The level sunbeams had not yet penetrated the surrounding palisade of boughs , and [the house]1917-the house lay in a chill twilight that seemed an emanation from [its]1917-the house mouldering walls . As [Odo]234-odo approached , [Gamba]282-gamba appeared from the shadow and took [his]282-gamba horse ; and the next moment [he]282-gamba had pushed open the door , and stood in [Fulvia]362-fulvia 's presence . [She]362-fulvia was seated at the farther end of [the room]782-the room , and as [she]362-fulvia rose to meet [him]682-the duke it chanced that [her]362-fulvia head , enveloped in its black travelling - hood , was relieved for a moment against the tarnished background of the broken mirror . The impression struck a chill to [his]682-the duke heart ; but it was replaced by a glow of boyish happiness as [their]7096-them eyes met and [he]682-the duke felt [her]362-fulvia hands in [his]682-the duke . For a moment all [his]682-the duke thoughts were lost in the mere sense of [her]362-fulvia nearness . [She]362-fulvia seemed simply an enveloping atmosphere in which [he]682-the duke drew fresh breath ; but gradually [her]362-fulvia outline emerged from this haze of feeling , and [he]682-the duke found [himself]682-the duke looking at [her]362-fulvia with the wondering gaze of [a stranger]3469-a stranger . [She]362-fulvia had been [a girl of sixteen]7098-a girl of sixteen when [they]7096-them first met . Twelve years had passed since then , and [she]362-fulvia was now [a woman of twenty - eight]7099-a woman of twenty - eight , belonging to [a race in which beauty ripens early and as soon declines]7100-a race in which beauty ripens early and as soon declines . But some happy property of nature -- whether the rare mould of [her]362-fulvia features or the gift of the spirit that informed [them]7096-them -- had held [her]362-fulvia loveliness intact , preserving the clear lines of youth after its bloom was gone , and making [her]362-fulvia seem like [a lover]5936-a lover 's memory of [herself]362-fulvia . So [she]362-fulvia appeared at first , a bright imponderable presence gliding toward [him]682-the duke out of the past ; but as [her]362-fulvia hands lay in [his]682-the duke the warm current of life was renewed between [them]7096-them , and [the woman dispossessed the shade]7102-the woman dispossessed the shade . 4.5 . Unpublished fragment from [Mr. Arthur Young]274-arthur 's diary of [his]274-arthur travels in [Italy]5-italy in the year 1789 . October 1st . Having agreed with [a vetturino]7103-a vetturino to carry [me]0-i to [Pianura]4-pianura , set out this morning from [Mantua]3-mantua . [The country]818-the country mostly arable , with [rows of elm and maple pollard]7105-rows of elm and maple pollard . Dined at [Casal Maggiore]212-casal maggiore , in [an infamous filthy inn]7106-an infamous filthy inn . At dinner was joined by [a gentleman who had taken the other seat in [the vettura]7108-the vettura as far as [Pianura]4-pianura]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura . [We]7109-we engaged in conversation and [I]0-i found [him]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura [a man of lively intelligence and the most polished address]7110-a man of lively intelligence and the most polished address . Though dressed in the foreign style , en abbe , [he]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura spoke English with as much fluency as [myself]0-i , and but for the philosophical tone of [his]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura remarks [I]0-i had taken [him]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura for an ecclesiastic . Altogether [a striking and somewhat perplexing character]7111-a striking and somewhat perplexing character : able , keen , intelligent , evidently used to the best company , yet acquainted with the condition of [the people]1003-the people , the methods of farming , and other economical subjects such as are seldom thought worthy of attention among [Italians of quality]7113-italians of quality . It appeared [he]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura was newly from [France]22-france , where [he]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura had been as much struck as [myself]0-i by the general state of ferment . Though owning that there was much reason for discontent , and that the conduct of [the court]814-the court and [ministers]6594-ministers was blind and infatuated beyond belief , [he]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura yet declared [himself]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura gravely apprehensive of the future , saying that [the people]1003-the people knew not what [they]1003-the people wanted , and were unwilling to listen to those that might have proved [[their]1003-the people best advisors]7117-their best advisors . Whether by this [he]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura meant [the clergy]1929-the clergy [I]0-i know not ; though [I]0-i observed [he]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura spoke favourably of that body in [France]22-france , pointing out that , long before the recent agitations , [they]1003-the people had defended the civil rights of [the Third Estate]7119-the third estate , and citing many cases in which [[the country]818-the country curates]7121-the country curates had shown [themselves]7121-the country curates [the truest friends of [the people]1003-the people]7122-the truest friends of the people : a fact [my]0-i own observation hath confirmed . [I]0-i remarked to [him]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura that [I]0-i was surprised to find how little talk there was in [Italy]5-italy of the distracted conditions in [France]22-france ; and this though [the country]818-the country is overrun with [French refugees]7125-french refugees , or [emigres]7126-emigres , as [they]7125-french refugees call [themselves]7125-french refugees , who bring with [them]7125-french refugees reports that might well excite the alarm of [neighbouring governments]7127-neighbouring governments . [He]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura said [he]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura had remarked the same indifference , but that this was consonant with the Italian character , which never looked to the morrow ; and [he]7107-a gentleman who had taken the other seat in the vettura as far as pianura added that the mild disposition of [the people]1003-the people , and [their]1003-the people profound respect for religion , were sufficient assurance against any political excess . To this [I]0-i could not forbear replying that [I]0-i could not regard as excesses the just protests of [the poor]8713-the poor against the unlawful tyranny of [the privileged classes]7130-the privileged classes , nor forbear to hail with joy the dawn of that light of freedom which hath already shed so sublime an effulgence on [the wilds of [the New World]213-the new world]7131-the wilds of the new world . [The abate]624-the abate took this in good part , though [I]0-i could see [he]624-the abate was not wholly of [my]0-i way of thinking ; but [he]624-the abate declared that in [his]624-the abate opinion different races needed different laws , and that [the sturdy and temperate American colonists]7133-the sturdy and temperate american colonists were fitted to enjoy a greater measure of political freedom than [the more volatile French and Italians]7134-the more volatile french and italians -- as though liberty were not destined by [the Creator]526-the creator to be equally shared by [all mankind]7135-all mankind ! ( Footnote : [I]0-i let this passage stand , though the late unhappy events in [France]22-france have , alas ! proved that [[my]0-i friend]3178-my friend [the abate]624-the abate was nearer right than [myself]0-i . June , 1794 . ) In the afternoon through [a poor country]7138-a poor country to [Ponte di Po]121-ponte di po , [a miserable village on the borders of]7139-a miserable village on the borders of [the duchy]1310-the duchy , where [we]7141-our lay , not slept , in [our]7141-our clothes , at [the worst inn [I]0-i have yet encountered]7142-the worst inn i have yet encountered . Here [our]7141-our luggage was plumbed for [Pianura]290-pianura . The impertinence of [the petty sovereigns]7143-the petty sovereigns to travellers in [Italy]5-italy is often intolerable , and [the customs officers]7144-the customs officers show the utmost insolence in the search for seditious pamphlets and other contraband articles ; but here [I]0-i was agreeably surprised by the courtesy of [the officials]7145-the officials and the despatch with which [our]7141-our luggage was examined . On [my]0-i remarking this , [[my]0-i companion]8794-my companion replied that [the Duke of [Pianura]4-pianura]9832-the duke of pianura was [a man of liberal views]7148-a man of liberal views , anxious to encourage [foreigners]7149-foreigners to visit [[his]9832-the duke of pianura state]7150-his state , and the last to put petty obstacles in the way of travel . [I]0-i answered , this was the report [I]0-i had heard of [him]9832-the duke of pianura ; and it was in the hope of learning something more of the reforms [he]9832-the duke of pianura was said to have effected , that [I]0-i had turned aside to visit [the duchy]1310-the duchy . [[My]0-i companion]8794-my companion replied that [[his]9832-the duke of pianura Highness]941-his highness had in fact introduced some innovations in [the government]2558-the government ; but that changes which seemed the most beneficial in one direction often worked mischief in another , so that [the wisest ruler]7155-the wisest ruler was perhaps not [he]7155-the wisest ruler that did the greatest amount of good , but [he]7155-the wisest ruler that was cause of the fewest evils . The 2nd . From [Ponte di Po]121-ponte di po to [Pianura]4-pianura the most convenient way is by water ; but [the river Piana]7156-the river piana being greatly swollen by the late rains , [[my]0-i friend , who seems well - acquainted with [the country]818-the country]7157-my friend , who seems well - acquainted with the country , proposed driving thither : a suggestion [I]0-i readily accepted , as it gave [me]0-i a good opportunity to study [the roads and farms of [the duchy]1310-the duchy]7159-the roads and farms of the duchy . Crossing [the Piana]94-the piana , drove near four hours over [horrible roads across [waste land]9315-waste land , thinly wooded , without [houses or cultivation]7163-houses or cultivation]7161-horrible roads across waste land , thinly wooded , without houses or cultivation . On [my]0-i expressing surprise that [the territory of so enlightened [a prince]8186-a prince]7164-the territory of so enlightened a prince would lie thus neglected , [the abate]624-the abate said [this land]7167-this land was [a fief of [the see of [Pianura]4-pianura]7169-the see of pianura]7168-a fief of the see of pianura , and that [the Duke]682-the duke was desirous of annexing [it]7167-this land to [the duchy]1310-the duchy . [I]0-i asked if it were true that [[his]682-the duke Highness]941-his highness had given [[his]682-the duke people]1264-his people a constitution modelled on that of [the Duke of [Tuscany]18-tuscany]7174-the duke of tuscany . [He]682-the duke said [he]682-the duke had heard the report ; but that for [his]682-the duke part [he]682-the duke must deplore any measure tending to debar [the clergy]1929-the clergy from the possession of land . Seeing [my]0-i surprise , [he]682-the duke explained that , in [Italy]5-italy at least , [the religious orders]5879-the religious orders were far better landlords than [the great nobles]7177-the great nobles or [the petty sovereigns , who , being for the most part absent from [[their]7178-the petty sovereigns , who , being for the most part absent from their estates , left their peasantry to be pillaged by rapacious middlemen and stewards estates]7179-their estates , left [[their]7178-the petty sovereigns , who , being for the most part absent from their estates , left their peasantry to be pillaged by rapacious middlemen and stewards peasantry]7180-their peasantry to be pillaged by [rapacious middlemen]7181-rapacious middlemen and [stewards]7182-stewards]7178-the petty sovereigns , who , being for the most part absent from their estates , left their peasantry to be pillaged by rapacious middlemen and stewards : an argument [I]0-i have heard advanced by [other travellers]7183-other travellers , and have [myself]0-i had frequent occasion to corroborate . On leaving [[the Bishop]1234-the bishop 's domain]7185-the bishop 's domain , remarked an improvement in the roads . [Flat land]7186-flat land , well irrigated , and divided as usual into small holdings . The pernicious metayer system exists everywhere , but [I]0-i am told [the Duke]682-the duke is opposed to it , though it is upheld not only by [the landed class]7188-the landed class , but by [the numerous economists that write on agriculture from [their]7189-the numerous economists that write on agriculture from their closets closets]7189-the numerous economists that write on agriculture from their closets , but would doubtless be sorely puzzled to distinguish a beet - root from a turnip . The 3rd . Set out early to visit [Pianura]4-pianura . [The city]2261-the city clean and well - kept . [The Duke]682-the duke has introduced street - lamps , such as are used in [Turin]17-turin , and [the pavement]2726-the pavement is remarkably fair and even . [Few beggars]7193-few beggars are to be seen and [the people]1003-the people have a thriving look . Visited [the Cathedral and Baptistery]7195-the cathedral and baptistery , in the Gothic style , more curious than beautiful ; also [[the Duke]682-the duke 's picture gallery]7197-the duke 's picture gallery . Learning that [the Duchess]899-the duchess was to ride out in the afternoon , had the curiosity to walk abroad to see [her]899-the duchess . A good view of [her]899-the duchess as [she]899-the duchess left [the palace]768-the palace . Though no longer in [her]899-the duchess first youth [she]899-the duchess is [one of [the handsomest women [I]0-i have seen]7201-the handsomest women i have seen]7200-one of the handsomest women i have seen . Remarked a decided likeness to [the Queen of [France]22-france]7202-the queen of france , though the eye and smile are less engaging . [The people in]7203-the people in [the streets]744-the streets received [her]899-the duchess sullenly , and [I]0-i am told [her]899-the duchess debts and disorders are the scandal of [the town]593-the town . [She]899-the duchess has , of course , [her]899-the duchess cicisbeo , and [the Duke]682-the duke is [the devoted slave of [a learned lady]7208-a learned lady , who is said to exert an unlimited influence over [him]682-the duke , and to have done much to better the condition of [the people]1003-the people]7207-the devoted slave of a learned lady , who is said to exert an unlimited influence over him , and to have done much to better the condition of the people . A new part for [[a prince]8186-a prince 's mistress]7211-a prince 's mistress to play ! In the evening to [the theatre]1559-the theatre , [a handsome building , well - lit with wax , where [Cimarosa]527-cimarosa 's Due [Baroni]528-baroni]7213-a handsome building , well - lit with wax , where cimarosa 's due baroni was agreeably sung . The 4th . [[My]0-i lord]7214-my lord Hervey , in [Florence]88-florence , having favoured [me]0-i with a letter to [Count Trescorre]254-trescorre , [[the Duke]682-the duke 's prime minister]7216-the duke 's prime minister , [I]0-i waited on [that gentleman]7217-that gentleman yesterday . [[His]682-the duke excellency]8647-his excellency received [me]0-i politely and assured [me]0-i that [he]8647-his excellency knew [me]0-i by reputation and would do all [he]8647-his excellency could to put [me]0-i in the way of investigating the agricultural conditions of [the duchy]1310-the duchy . Contrary to the Italian custom , [he]8647-his excellency invited [me]0-i to dine with [him]8647-his excellency the next day . As a rule [these great nobles]7220-these great nobles do not open [their]7220-these great nobles doors to [foreigners]7149-foreigners , however well recommended . Visited , by appointment , the press of [the celebrated [Andreoni]441-andreoni , who was banished during [the late Duke]4180-the late duke 's reign for suspected liberal tendencies , but is now restored to favour and placed at the head of the Royal Typography]7222-the celebrated andreoni , who was banished during the late duke 's reign for suspected liberal tendencies , but is now restored to favour and placed at the head of the royal typography . [Signor Andreoni]441-andreoni received [me]0-i with every mark of esteem , and after having shown [me]0-i some of the finest examples of [his]441-andreoni work -- such as [the Pindar]7224-the pindar , [the Lucretius]529-the lucretius and [the Dante]7225-the dante -- accompanied [me]0-i to [a neighbouring coffee - house]7226-a neighbouring coffee - house , where [I]0-i was introduced to [several lovers of agriculture]7227-several lovers of agriculture . Here [I]0-i learned some particulars of [the Duke]682-the duke 's attempted reforms . [He]441-andreoni has undertaken the work of draining [the vast marsh of [Pontesordo]2-pontesordo]7229-the vast marsh of pontesordo , to [the west of [the city]2261-the city]7230-the west of the city , notorious for [its]2261-the city mal'aria ; has renounced the monopoly of corn and tobacco ; has taken [the University]9247-the university out of the hands of [the Barnabites]4313-the barnabites , and introduced the teaching of the physical sciences , formerly prohibited by [the Church]1212-the church ; has spent since [his]441-andreoni accession near 200,000 liv . on improving [the roads]2942-the roads throughout [the duchy]1310-the duchy , and is now engaged in framing a constitution which shall deprive [the clergy]1929-the clergy of the greatest part of [their]1929-the clergy privileges and confirm [the sovereign]1435-the sovereign 's right to annex [ecclesiastical territory]7239-ecclesiastical territory for the benefit of [the people]1003-the people . In spite of these radical measures , [[his]441-andreoni Highness]941-his highness is not popular with [the masses]6766-the masses . [He]441-andreoni is accused of irreligion by [the monks]1356-the monks that [he]441-andreoni has removed from [the University]9247-the university , and [[his]441-andreoni mistress]8825-his mistress , [the daughter of [a noted free - thinker who was driven from [Piedmont]60-piedmont by [the Inquisition]5948-the inquisition]7247-a noted free - thinker who was driven from piedmont by the inquisition]7246-the daughter of a noted free - thinker who was driven from piedmont by the inquisition , is said to have an unholy influence over [him]441-andreoni . [I]0-i am told these rumours are diligently fomented by [[the late Duke]4180-the late duke 's minister]7250-the late duke 's minister , now [Prior of [the Dominican monastery]7252-the dominican monastery]7251-prior of the dominican monastery , [a man of bigoted views but great astuteness]7253-a man of bigoted views but great astuteness . The truth is , [the people]1003-the people are so completely under the influence of [the friars]1652-the friars that a word is enough to turn [them]1003-the people against [[their]1003-the people truest benefactors]7256-their truest benefactors . In the afternoon [I]0-i was setting out to visit [[the Bishop]1234-the bishop 's gallery]7258-the bishop 's gallery when [[Count Trescorre]254-trescorre 's secretary]7259-count trescorre 's secretary waited on [me]0-i with an invitation to inspect [the estates of [the Marchioness of [Boscofolto]97-boscofolto]9096-the marchioness of boscofolto]7260-the estates of the marchioness of boscofolto : an offer [I]0-i readily accepted -- for what are the masterpieces of [Raphael]332-raphael or Cleomenes to the sight of a good turnip field or of a well - kept dairy ? [I]0-i had heard of [Boscofolto]97-boscofolto , which was given by [the late Duke]4180-the late duke to [[his]4180-the late duke mistress]8825-his mistress , as [one of [the most productive estates of [the duchy]1310-the duchy]7265-the most productive estates of the duchy]7264-one of the most productive estates of the duchy ; but great was [my]0-i disappointment on beholding [it]97-boscofolto . [Fine gardens]7267-fine gardens there are , to be sure , clipt walks , leaden statues , and water - works ; but as for [the farms]7268-the farms , all is dirt , neglect , disorder . Spite of [the lady]660-the lady 's wealth , all are let out alla meta , and farmed on principles that would disgrace [a savage]7270-a savage . The spade used instead of the plough , the hedges neglected , mole - casts in [the pastures]1128-the pastures , [good land]7272-good land run to waste , [the peasants]8472-the peasants starving and indebted -- where , with a little thrift and humanity , all had been smiling plenty ! Learned that on [the owner]2834-the owner 's death [this great property]7275-this great property reverts to [the Barnabites]408-the barnabites . From [Boscofolto]97-boscofolto to [the church of the Madonna del Monte , where is one of their]7276-the church of the madonna del monte , where is one of their wonder - working images , said to be annually visited by [close on thirty thousand pilgrims]7277-close on thirty thousand pilgrims ; but there is always some exaggeration in such figures . [A fine building , richly adorned , and hung with an extraordinary number of votive offerings]7278-a fine building , richly adorned , and hung with an extraordinary number of votive offerings : silver arms , legs , hearts , wax images , and paintings . Some of these latter are clearly the work of [village artists]7279-village artists , and depict the miraculous escape of [the peasantry]8358-the peasantry from various calamities , and the preservation of [their]8358-the peasantry crops from floods , drought , lightning and so forth . [These poor wretches]7281-these poor wretches had done more to better [their]7281-these poor wretches crops by spending [their]7281-these poor wretches savings in good ploughshares and harrows than by hanging gew - gaws on a wooden idol . [The Rector]1602-the rector received [us]7283-us civilly and showed [us]7283-us the treasury , full of jewels and costly plate , and [the buildings where [the pilgrims]1588-the pilgrims are lodged]7284-the buildings where the pilgrims are lodged . Learned that the Giubileo or centenary festival of [the Madonna]6665-the madonna is shortly to be celebrated with great pomp . [The poorer classes]7287-the poorer classes delight in these ceremonies , and [I]0-i am told this is to surpass all previous ones , [the clergy]1929-the clergy intending to work on the superstitions of [the people]1003-the people and thus turn [them]1003-the people against the new charter . It is said [the Duke]682-the duke hopes to counteract these designs by offering a jewelled diadem to [the Virgin]3925-the virgin ; but this will no doubt do [him]682-the duke a bad turn with the esprits libres . [These little states]7292-these little states are as full of intrigues as a foul fruit of maggots . [The 5th]7293-the 5th . To dinner at [Count Trescorre]254-trescorre 's where , as usual , [I]0-i was [the plainest - dressed man in [the company]1753-the company]7294-the plainest - dressed man in the company . Have long since ceased to be concerned by this : why should [a mere English farmer]7296-a mere english farmer compete in elegance with [these Monsignori and Illustrissimi]7297-these monsignori and illustrissimi ? Surprised to find among [the company]1753-the company [my]0-i travelling - companion of the other day . Learned that [he]7299-his is [the abate de Crucis]4750-the abate de crucis , [a personal friend of [the Duke]682-the duke 's]7301-a personal friend of the duke 's . [He]7299-his greeted [me]0-i cordially , and on hearing [my]0-i name , said that [he]7299-his was acquainted with [my]0-i works in the translation of [Mons . Freville]530-mons . freville , and now understood how it was that [I]0-i had got the better of [him]7299-his in [our]7303-our farming disputations on the way hither . Was surprised to be told by [Count Trescorre]254-trescorre that [the Duke]682-the duke desired [me]0-i to wait on [him]7299-his that evening . Though in general not ambitious of such honours , yet in this case nothing could be more gratifying . [The 6th]7305-the 6th . Yesterday evening to [the palace]768-the palace , where [[his]7299-his Highness]941-his highness received [me]0-i with great affability . [He]7299-his was in [[his]7299-his private apartments]7308-his private apartments , with the abate [de Crucis]462-de crucis and [several other learned men]7309-several other learned men ; among [them]7309-several other learned men [the famous abate Crescenti]7310-the famous abate crescenti , [librarian to [[his]7299-his Highness]941-his highness and [author of the celebrated Chronicles of the Italian States]7313-author of the celebrated chronicles of the italian states]7311-librarian to his highness and author of the celebrated chronicles of the italian states . Happy indeed is [the prince who surrounds [himself]7314-the prince who surrounds himself with scholars instead of courtiers with [scholars]5088-scholars instead of [courtiers]5586-courtiers]7314-the prince who surrounds himself with scholars instead of courtiers ! Yet [I]0-i can not say that the impression [his]7299-his Highness produced on [me]0-i was one of HAPPINESS . [His]7299-his countenance is sad , almost careworn , though with a smile of engaging sweetness ; [his]7299-his manner affable without condescension , and open without familiarity . [I]0-i am told [he]7299-his is oppressed by the cares of [his]7299-his station ; and from a certain irresolution of voice and eye , that bespeaks not so much weakness as a speculative cast of mind , [I]0-i can believe [him]7299-his less fitted for active government than for the meditations of the closet . [He]7299-his appears , however , zealous to perform [his]7299-his duties ; questioned [me]0-i eagerly about [my]0-i impressions of [Italy]5-italy , and showed a flattering familiarity with [my]0-i works , and a desire to profit by what [he]7299-his was pleased to call [my]0-i exceptional knowledge of agriculture . [I]0-i thought [I]0-i perceived in [him]7299-his a sincere wish to study the welfare of [[his]7299-his people]1264-his people ; but was disappointed to find among [[his]7299-his chosen associates]7318-his chosen associates not [one practical farmer]7319-one practical farmer or [economist]7320-economist , but only [the usual closet - theorists that are too busy planning Utopias to think of planting turnips]7321-the usual closet - theorists that are too busy planning utopias to think of planting turnips . The 7th . Visited [[his]7299-his Highness 's estate at [Valsecca]234-odo]7322-his highness 's estate at valsecca . Here [he]7299-his has converted a handsome seat into [a school of agriculture]7323-a school of agriculture , tearing down [an immense orangery]7324-an immense orangery to plant mulberries , and replacing [costly gardens]7325-costly gardens and statuary by [well - tilled fields]7326-well - tilled fields : a good example to [[his]7299-his wealthy subjects]7327-his wealthy subjects . Unfortunately [[his]7299-his bailiff]7328-his bailiff is not what [we]7329-we should call [a practical farmer]7330-a practical farmer ; and [many acres of valuable ground]7331-many acres of valuable ground are given up to [a botanic garden]7332-a botanic garden , where exotic plants are grown at great expense , and rather for curiosity than use : a common error of [noble agriculturists]7333-noble agriculturists . In the afternoon with [the abate de Crucis]4750-the abate de crucis to [the Benedictine monastery]3770-the benedictine monastery , [a league beyond [the city]2261-the city]7336-a league beyond the city . Here [I]0-i saw the best farming in [the duchy]1310-the duchy . [The Prior]7339-the prior received [us]7329-we politely and conversed with intelligence on drainage , crops and irrigation . [I]0-i urged on [him]7339-the prior the cultivation of turnips and [he]7339-the prior appeared struck by [my]0-i arguments . [The tenants on [this great estate]7341-this great estate]7340-the tenants on this great estate appeared better housed and fed than any [I]0-i have seen in [Pianura]4-pianura . [The monks]1356-the monks have a school of agriculture , less pretentious but better - managed than [[the Duke]682-the duke 's]7344-the duke 's . Some of [them]1356-the monks study physics and chemistry , and there are [good chirurgeons among [them]1356-the monks , who care for [the poor]8713-the poor without pay]7345-good chirurgeons among them , who care for the poor without pay . [The aged and infirm peasants]7347-the aged and infirm peasants are housed in [a neat almshouse]7348-a neat almshouse , and [the sick]7349-the sick nursed in [a clean well - built lazaret]7350-a clean well - built lazaret . Altogether an agreeable picture of rural prosperity , though [I]0-i had rather it had been the result of FREE LABOUR than of [MONASTIC BOUNTY]7351-monastic bounty . [The 8th]7352-the 8th . By appointment , to [[the Duke]682-the duke 's [Egeria]217-egeria]7354-the duke 's egeria . [This lady]6024-this lady , [the Signorina F.V.]531-the signorina f.v. , having heard that [I]0-i was in [Pianura]4-pianura , had desired [the Signor Andreoni]441-andreoni to bring [me]0-i to [her]6024-this lady . [I]0-i had expected [a female of the loud declamatory type]7356-a female of the loud declamatory type : something of [the Corilla Olimpica order]7357-the corilla olimpica order ; but in this was agreeably disappointed . [The Signorina V.]532-the signorina v. is modestly lodged , lives in the frugal style of [the middle class]2325-the middle class , and refuses to accept a title , though [she]6024-this lady is thus debarred from going to court . Were it not indiscreet to speculate on [a lady]695-a lady 's age , [I]0-i should put [hers]695-a lady at somewhat above thirty . Though without [the Duchess]899-the duchess 's commanding elegance [she]695-a lady has , [I]0-i believe , more beauty of a quiet sort : a countenance at once soft and animated , agreeably tinged with melancholy , yet lit up by the incessant play of thought and emotion that succeed each other in [her]695-a lady talk . Better conversation [I]0-i never heard ; and can heartily confirm the assurances of those who had told [me]0-i that [the lady was as agreeable in discourse as learned in the closet]7361-the lady was as agreeable in discourse as learned in the closet . ( Footnote : It has before now been observed that the FREE and VOLATILE manners of [foreign ladies]7362-foreign ladies tend to blind [the English traveller]7363-the english traveller to the inferiority of [their]7363-the english traveller PHYSICAL charms . Note by [a Female Friend of the Author]7364-a female friend of the author . ) On entering , found [a numerous company assembled to compliment [[my]0-i hostess]7366-my hostess on [her]7366-my hostess recent appointment as [doctor of [the University]9247-the university]7367-doctor of the university]7365-a numerous company assembled to compliment my hostess on her recent appointment as doctor of the university . This is an honour not uncommonly conferred in [Italy]5-italy , where female learning , perhaps from its rarity , is highly esteemed ; but [I]0-i am told [the ladies]1106-the ladies thus distinguished seldom speak in public , though [their]1106-the ladies degree entitles [them]1106-the ladies to a chair in [the University]9247-the university . In [the Signorina V. 's society]7371-the signorina v. 's society [I]0-i found [the most advanced reformers of [the duchy]1310-the duchy]7372-the most advanced reformers of the duchy : among others [Signor Gamba]282-gamba , [the famous pamphleteer]7374-the famous pamphleteer , author of a remarkable treatise on taxation , which had nearly cost [him]282-gamba [his]282-gamba liberty under [the late Duke]4180-the late duke 's reign . [He]282-gamba is [a man of extreme views and sarcastic tongue]7376-a man of extreme views and sarcastic tongue , with an irritability of manner that is perhaps the result of bodily infirmities . [His]282-gamba ideas , [I]0-i am told , have much weight with [the fair doctoress]7377-the fair doctoress ; and in the lampoons of the day the new constitution is said to be the offspring of [their]1106-the ladies amours , and to have inherited [its father]8118-its father 's deformity . The company presently withdrawing , [[my]0-i hostess]7366-my hostess pressed [me]0-i to remain . [She]7366-my hostess was eager for news from [France]22-france , spoke admiringly of the new constitution , and recited in a moving manner an Ode of [her]7366-my hostess own composition on the Fall of [the Bastille]218-the bastille . Though living so retired [she]7366-my hostess makes no secret of [her]7366-my hostess connection with [the Duke]682-the duke ; said [he]682-the duke had told [her]7366-my hostess of [his]682-the duke conversation with [me]0-i , and asked what [I]0-i thought of [his]682-the duke plan for draining [the marsh of [Pontesordo]2-pontesordo]7381-the marsh of pontesordo . On [my]0-i attempting to reply to this in detail , [I]0-i saw that , like [some of the most accomplished of [her]7366-my hostess sex]7382-some of the most accomplished of her sex , [she]7366-my hostess was impatient of minutiae , and preferred general ideas to particular instances ; but when the talk turned on the rights of [the people]1003-the people [I]0-i was struck by the energy and justice of [her]7366-my hostess remarks , and by a tone of resolution and courage that made [me]0-i to say to [myself]0-i : " Here is the hand that rules the state . "[7366-my hostess] [She]7366-my hostess questioned [me]0-i earnestly about the state of affairs in [France]22-france , begged [me]0-i to lend [her]7366-my hostess what pamphlets [I]0-i could procure , and while making no secret of [her]7366-my hostess republican sympathies , expressed [herself]7366-my hostess with a moderation not always found in [her]7366-my hostess sex . Of [the clergy]1929-the clergy alone [she]7366-my hostess appeared intolerant : a fact hardly to be wondered at , considering the persecution to which [she]7366-my hostess and [[her]7366-my hostess father]1415-her father have been subjected . [She]7366-my hostess detained [me]0-i near two hours in such discourse , and on [my]0-i taking leave asked with some show of feeling what [I]0-i , as [a practical economist]7386-a practical economist , would advise [the Duke]682-the duke to do for the benefit of [[his]682-the duke people]1264-his people ; to which [I]0-i replied , " Plant turnips , [madam]8129-madam ! "[0-i] and [she]7366-my hostess laughed heartily , and said no doubt [I]0-i was right . But [I]0-i fear all the heads here are too full of fine theories to condescend to such simple improvements ... 4.6 . [Fulvia]362-fulvia , in the twilight , sat awaiting [the Duke]682-the duke . [The room in which [she]362-fulvia sat]7390-the room in which she sat looked out on [a stone - flagged cloister enclosing a plot of ground planted with yews]7391-a stone - flagged cloister enclosing a plot of ground planted with yews ; and at the farther end of [this cloister]7392-this cloister a door communicated by a covered way with [the ducal gardens]856-the ducal gardens . [The house]1917-the house had formed a part of [the convent of the Perpetual Adoration]4361-the convent of the perpetual adoration , which had been sold by [the nuns]5678-the nuns when [they]5678-the nuns moved to [the new buildings [the late Duke]4180-the late duke had given [them]5678-the nuns]7397-the new buildings the late duke had given them . A portion had been torn down to make way for [the Marquess of [[Cerveno]394-cerveno 's palace]7400-cerveno 's palace]7399-the marquess of cerveno 's palace , and in [the remaining fragment]7401-the remaining fragment , [a low building wedged between high walls , [Fulvia]362-fulvia]7402-a low building wedged between high walls , fulvia had found [a lodging]7403-a lodging . [[Her]362-fulvia whole dwelling]7404-her whole dwelling consisted of [[the Abbess]5723-the abbess 's parlour]5925-the abbess 's parlour , in which [she]362-fulvia now sat , and [the two or three adjoining cells]7407-the two or three adjoining cells . The tall presses in [the parlour]1679-the parlour had been filled with [[her]362-fulvia father]1415-her father 's books , and surmounted by [his]1415-her father globes and other scientific instruments . But for this [the apartment]2431-the apartment remained as unadorned as in [[her]362-fulvia predecessor]7411-her predecessor 's day ; and [Fulvia]362-fulvia , in [her]362-fulvia austere black gown , with a lawn kerchief folded over [her]362-fulvia breast , and the unpowdered hair drawn back from [her]362-fulvia pale face , might [herself]362-fulvia have passed for [the head of [a religious community]7413-a religious community]7412-the head of a religious community . [She]362-fulvia cultivated with almost morbid care this severity of dress and surroundings . There were moments when [she]362-fulvia could hardly tolerate the pale autumnal beauty which [her]362-fulvia glass reflected , when even this phantom of youth and radiance became a stumbling - block to [her]362-fulvia spiritual pride . [She]362-fulvia was not ashamed of being [the Duke of [[Pianura]4-pianura 's mistress]7415-pianura 's mistress]7414-the duke of pianura 's mistress ; but [she]362-fulvia had a horror of being thought like [the mistresses of [other princes]7417-other princes]7416-the mistresses of other princes . [She]362-fulvia loathed all that the position represented in [men]8356-men 's minds ; [she]362-fulvia had refused all that , according to the conventions of the day , it entitled [her]362-fulvia to claim : wealth , patronage , and the rank and estates which it was customary for [the sovereign]1435-the sovereign to confer . [She]362-fulvia had taken nothing from [Odo]234-odo but [his]234-odo love , and [the little house in which [he]234-odo had lodged [her]362-fulvia]7420-the little house in which he had lodged her . Three years had passed since [Fulvia]362-fulvia 's flight to [Pianura]4-pianura . From the moment when [she]362-fulvia and [Odo]234-odo had stood face to face again , it had been clear to [him]234-odo that [he]234-odo could never give [her]362-fulvia up , to [her]362-fulvia that [she]362-fulvia could never leave [him]234-odo . Fate seemed to have thrown [them]7421-them together in derision of [their]7421-them long struggle , and [both]7422-both felt that lassitude of the will which is the reaction from vain endeavour . The discovery that [he]234-odo needed [her]362-fulvia , that the task for which [he]234-odo had given [her]362-fulvia up could after all not be accomplished without [her]362-fulvia , served to overcome [her]362-fulvia last resistance . If the end for which both strove could best be attained together -- if [he]234-odo needed the aid of [her]362-fulvia unfaltering faith as much as [she]362-fulvia needed that of [his]234-odo wealth and power -- why should any personal scruple stand between [them]7421-them ? Why should [she]362-fulvia who had given all else to the cause -- ease , fortune , safety , and even the happiness that lay in [her]362-fulvia hand -- hesitate to make the final sacrifice of a private ideal ? According to the standards of [her]362-fulvia day there was no dishonour to [a woman]5452-a woman in being [the mistress of [a man whose rank forbade [his]234-odo marrying [her]362-fulvia]7425-a man whose rank forbade his marrying her]7424-the mistress of a man whose rank forbade his marrying her : the dishonour lay in the conduct which had come to be associated with such relations . Under the old dispensation the influence of [[the prince]8981-the prince 's mistress]7427-the prince 's mistress had stood for the last excesses of moral and political corruption ; why might it not , under the new law , come to represent as unlimited a power for good ? So love , [the casuist]7428-the casuist , argued ; and during those first months , when happiness seemed at last its own justification , [Fulvia]362-fulvia lived in every fibre . But always , even then , [she]362-fulvia was on the defensive against that higher tribunal which [her]362-fulvia own conception of life had created . In spite of [herself]362-fulvia [she]362-fulvia was [a child of the new era]7429-a child of the new era , of the universal reaction against the falseness and egotism of the old social code . A standard of conduct regulated by the needs of [the race]7430-the race rather than by individual passion , a conception of each existence as a link in the great chain of human endeavour , had slowly shaped itself out of the wild theories and vague " codes "[362-fulvia] of [the eighteenth - century moralists]7431-the eighteenth - century moralists ; and with this sense of the sacramental nature of human ties , came a renewed reverence for moral and physical purity . [Fulvia]362-fulvia was of [those who require that [their]7432-those who require that their lives shall be an affirmation of themselves lives shall be an affirmation of [themselves]7432-those who require that their lives shall be an affirmation of themselves]7432-those who require that their lives shall be an affirmation of themselves ; and the lack of inner harmony drove [her]362-fulvia to seek some outward expression of [her]362-fulvia ideals . [She]362-fulvia threw [herself]362-fulvia with renewed passion into the political struggle . The best , the only justification of [her]362-fulvia power , was to use it boldly , openly , for the good of [the people]1003-the people . All the repressed forces of [her]362-fulvia nature were poured into this single channel . [She]362-fulvia had no desire to conceal [her]362-fulvia situation , to disguise [her]362-fulvia influence over [Odo]234-odo . [She]362-fulvia wished it rather to be so visible a factor in [his]234-odo relations with [[his]234-odo people]1264-his people that [she]362-fulvia should come to be regarded as the ultimate pledge of [his]234-odo good faith . But , like all the casuistical virtues , this position had the rigidity of something created to fit a special case ; and the result was a fixity of attitude , which spread benumbingly over [her]362-fulvia whole nature . [She]362-fulvia was conscious of the change , yet dared not struggle against it , since to do so was to confess the weakness of [her]362-fulvia case . [She]362-fulvia had chosen to be regarded as a symbol rather than [a woman]5452-a woman , and there were moments when [she]362-fulvia felt as isolated from life as some marble allegory in its niche above the market - place . It was the desire to associate [herself]362-fulvia with [the Duke]682-the duke 's public life that had induced [her]362-fulvia , after much hesitation , to accept the degree which [the University]9247-the university had conferred on [her]362-fulvia . [She]362-fulvia had shared eagerly in the work of reconstructing [the University]102-the university , and had been the means of drawing to [Pianura]290-pianura [several teachers of distinction from [Padua]109-padua and [Pavia]12-pavia]7438-several teachers of distinction from padua and pavia . It was [her]362-fulvia dream to build up a seat of learning which should attract [students]5084-students from [all parts of [Italy]5-italy]5093-all parts of italy ; and though [many young men of good family]7441-many young men of good family had withdrawn from the classes when [the Barnabites]408-the barnabites were dispossessed , [she]362-fulvia was confident that [they]7441-many young men of good family would soon be replaced by [scholars from [other states]7443-other states]7442-scholars from other states . [She]362-fulvia was resolved to identify [herself]362-fulvia openly with the educational reform which seemed to [her]362-fulvia one of the most important steps toward civic emancipation ; and [she]362-fulvia had therefore acceded to the request of [the faculty]6983-the faculty that , on receiving [her]362-fulvia degree , [she]362-fulvia should sustain a thesis before [the University]9247-the university . This ceremony was to take place a few days hence , on [the Duke]682-the duke 's birthday ; and , as the new charter was to be proclaimed on the same day , [Fulvia]362-fulvia had chosen as the subject of [her]362-fulvia discourse the Constitution recently promulgated in [France]22-france . [She]362-fulvia pushed aside the bundle of political pamphlets which [she]362-fulvia had been studying , and sat looking out at the strip of [garden beyond the arches of the cloister]7447-garden beyond the arches of the cloister . The narrow horizon bounded by convent walls symbolised fitly enough the life [she]362-fulvia had chosen to lead : a life of artificial restraints and renunciations , passive , conventual almost , in which even the central point of [her]362-fulvia love burned , now , with a calm devotional glow . The door in [the cloister]1488-the cloister opened and [the Duke]682-the duke crossed [the garden]8185-the garden . [He]682-the duke walked slowly , with the listless step [she]362-fulvia had observed in [him]682-the duke of late ; and as [he]682-the duke entered [she]362-fulvia saw that [he]682-the duke looked pale and weary . " [You]682-the duke have been at work again , "[362-fulvia] [she]362-fulvia said . " A cabinet - meeting ? "[362-fulvia] " Yes , "[682-the duke] [he]682-the duke answered , sinking into [the Abbess]5723-the abbess 's high carved chair . [He]682-the duke glanced musingly about [the dim room]7452-the dim room , in which the shadow of [the cloister]1488-the cloister made an early dusk . Its atmosphere of monastic calm , of which the significance did not escape [him]682-the duke , fell soothingly on [his]682-the duke spirit . It simplified [his]682-the duke relation to [Fulvia]362-fulvia by tacitly restricting it within the bounds of a tranquil tenderness . Any other setting would have seemed less in harmony with [their]7454-their fate . Better , perhaps , than [Fulvia]362-fulvia , [he]682-the duke knew what ailed [them]7454-their both . Happiness had come to [them]7454-their , but it had come too late ; it had come tinged with disloyalty to [their]7454-their early ideals ; it had come when delay and disillusionment had imperceptibly weakened the springs of passion . For it is the saddest thing about sorrow that it deadens the capacity for happiness ; and to [Fulvia]362-fulvia and [Odo]234-odo the joy [they]7454-their had renounced had returned with [an exile]7455-an exile 's alien face . Seeing that [he]682-the duke remained silent , [she]362-fulvia rose and lit the shaded lamp on the table . [He]682-the duke watched [her]362-fulvia as [she]362-fulvia moved across [the room]782-the room . [Her]362-fulvia step had lost none of its flowing grace , of that harmonious impetus which years ago had drawn [his]682-the duke boyish fancy in its wake . As [she]362-fulvia bent above the lamp , the circle of light threw [her]362-fulvia face into relief against the deepening shadows of [the room]782-the room . [She]362-fulvia had changed , indeed , but as those change in whom the springs of life are clear and abundant : it was a development rather than a diminution . The old purity of outline remained ; and deep below the surface , but still visible sometimes to [his]682-the duke lessening insight , [the old girlish spirit]7458-the old girlish spirit , radiant , tender and impetuous , stirred for a moment in [her]362-fulvia eyes . The lamplight fell on the pamphlets [she]362-fulvia had pushed aside . [Odo]234-odo picked one up . " What are these ? "[234-odo] [he]234-odo asked . " [They]9997-they were sent to [me]234-odo by [the English traveller whom [Andreoni]441-andreoni brought [here]8091-here]9998-the english traveller whom andreoni brought here . "[234-odo] [He]234-odo turned a few pages . " The old story , "[234-odo] [he]234-odo said . " Do [you]362-fulvia never weary of it ? "[234-odo] " An old story ? "[362-fulvia] [she]362-fulvia exclaimed . " [I]362-fulvia thought it had been the newest in [the world]844-the world . Is it not being written , chapter by chapter , before [our]10001-our very eyes ? "[362-fulvia] [Odo]234-odo laid the treatise aside . " Are [you]362-fulvia never afraid to turn the next page ? "[234-odo] [he]234-odo asked . " Afraid ? Afraid of what ? "[234-odo] " That it may be written in blood . "[362-fulvia] [She]362-fulvia uttered a quick exclamation ; then [her]362-fulvia face hardened , and [she]362-fulvia said in a low tone : " [De Crucis]462-de crucis has been with [you]234-odo . "[362-fulvia] [He]234-odo made the half - resigned , half - impatient gesture of [the man who feels [himself]234-odo drawn into a familiar argument from which there is no issue]7459-the man who feels himself drawn into a familiar argument from which there is no issue . " [He]462-de crucis left yesterday for [Germany]131-germany . "[234-odo] " [He]462-de crucis was here too long ! "[362-fulvia] [she]362-fulvia said , with an uncontrollable escape of bitterness . [Odo]234-odo sighed . " If [you]362-fulvia would but let [me]234-odo bring [him]462-de crucis to [you]362-fulvia , [you]362-fulvia would see that [his]462-de crucis influence over [me]234-odo is not what [you]362-fulvia think it . "[234-odo] [She]362-fulvia was silent a moment ; then [she]362-fulvia said : " [You]234-odo are tired tonight . Let [us]10002-us not talk of these things . "[362-fulvia] " As [you]362-fulvia please , "[234-odo] [he]234-odo answered , with an air of relief ; and [she]362-fulvia rose and went to the harpsichord . [She]362-fulvia played softly , with a veiled touch , gliding from one crepuscular melody to another , till [the room]782-the room was filled with drifts of sound that seemed like the voice of its own shadows . There had been times when [he]234-odo could have yielded [himself]234-odo to this languid tide of music , letting it loosen the ties of thought till [he]234-odo floated out into the soothing dimness of sensation ; but now the present held [him]234-odo . To [Fulvia]362-fulvia , too , [he]234-odo knew the music was but a forced interlude , a mechanical refuge from thought . [She]362-fulvia had deliberately narrowed [their]7461-their intercourse to one central idea ; and it was [her]362-fulvia punishment that silence had come to be merely an intensified expression of this idea . When [she]362-fulvia turned to [Odo]234-odo [she]362-fulvia saw the same consciousness in [his]234-odo face . It was useless for [them]7461-their to talk of other things . With a pang of unreasoning regret [she]362-fulvia felt that [she]362-fulvia had become to [him]234-odo the embodiment of a single thought -- a formula , rather than [a woman]5452-a woman . " Tell [me]362-fulvia what [you]234-odo have been doing , "[362-fulvia] [she]362-fulvia said . The question was a relief . At once [he]234-odo began to separation of [his]234-odo work . All [his]234-odo thoughts , all [his]234-odo time , were given to the constitution which was to define the powers of [Church and state]7463-church and state . The difficulties increased as the work advanced ; but the gravest difficulty was one of which [he]234-odo dared not tell [her]362-fulvia : [his]234-odo own growing distrust of the ideas for which [he]234-odo laboured . [He]234-odo was too keenly aware of the difference in [their]7461-their mental operations . With [Fulvia]362-fulvia , ideas were either rejected or at once converted into principles ; with [himself]234-odo , they remained stored in the mind , serving rather as commentaries on life than as incentives to action . This perpetual accessibility to new impressions was a quality [she]362-fulvia could not understand , or could conceive of only as a weakness . [Her]362-fulvia own mind was like a garden in which nothing is ever transplanted . [She]362-fulvia allowed for no intermediate stages between error and dogma , for no shifting of the bounds of conviction ; and this security gave [her]362-fulvia the singleness of purpose in which [he]234-odo found [himself]234-odo more and more deficient . [Odo]234-odo remembered that [he]234-odo had once thought [her]362-fulvia nearness would dispel [his]234-odo hesitations . At first it had been so ; but gradually the contact with [her]362-fulvia fixed enthusiasms had set up within [him]234-odo an opposing sense of the claims ignored . The element of dogmatism in [her]362-fulvia faith showed the discouraging sameness of the human mind . [He]234-odo perceived that to a spirit like [Fulvia]362-fulvia 's it might become possible to shed blood in the cause of tolerance . The rapid march of events in [France]22-france had necessarily produced an opposite effect on minds so differently constituted . To [Fulvia]362-fulvia the year had been a year of victory , a glorious affirmation of [her]362-fulvia political creed . Step by step [she]362-fulvia had seen , as in some old allegorical painting , error fly before the shafts of truth . Where [Odo]234-odo beheld a conflagration [she]362-fulvia saw a sunrise ; and all that was bare and cold in [her]362-fulvia own life was warmed and transfigured by that ineffable brightness . [She]362-fulvia listened patiently while [he]234-odo enlarged on the difficulties of the case . The constitution was framed in all its details , but with its completion [he]234-odo felt more than ever doubtful of the wisdom of granting it . [He]234-odo would have welcomed any postponement that did not seem an admission of fear .
